PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity of thanking the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and officers of the Australian Taxation Office for their consideration last evening in agreeing to respond to a difficult amendment in respect of section 46e of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Although one agrees that the thrust of the amendments is sound but complicated, one must acknowledge that some of the tax consequences that could flow from some of these amendments for some taxpayers could be unfair. Therefore, we must issue a warning that those who embark on schemes in this area of asset revaluation and disposal do so very much at their peril.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to a second issue relating to sections 108 and 109 of the Act, the ability of the Commissioner of Taxation to decide the legitimacy of transactions, including inter-corporate loans, is not a unique exercise of the Taxation Commissioner's powers. In fact, there are many situations outlined in the Income Tax Assessment Act requiring the Commissioner's discretion. In some cases this is appropriate. However, in recent years we have seen a widening of this discretion that is quite extraordinary. When the Commissioner's discretionary powers first emerged in the Act, in most cases they were exercised usually for the benefit of the taxpayer. For example, section 46 rebates for private companies required the exercise of the Commissioner's discretion to allow that further 50 per cent rebate in respect of private company dividends. However, nowadays what has emerged works very much against ordinary taxpayers. Nowadays the emphasis has changed and the discretionary powers appear to be largely directed against the taxpayer and in favour of the Commissioner.

Yesterday evening when this Committee was deliberating on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 I referred to the deletion of sections 108 and 109 and their replacement with stronger provisions. These new amendments seek to overcome a possible remote loophole due to a conflict in the use of the words `income' in sections 108 and 109 and `profits' in section 44. There are some people in the accounting profession who are somewhat concerned about the open-ended nature of the Commissioner's discretion in regard to sections 108 and 109. Secondly, the new amendments may create greater problems for the Taxation Office than they solve. Therefore, I ask whether the Taxation Commissioner could issue a ruling in the area of discretionary powers so far as the new ambit of sections 108 and 109 is concerned. Does the Taxation Commissioner acknowledge that some of these new amendments, although designed to close certain loopholes because of the conflict of wording between profits and income in the relevant sections, open up the potential for new technical loopholes that could be used by astute tax avoiders simply because profits may have been declared to be earned when in effect they have not been earned? We acknowledge, of course, that the Taxation Commissioner has this extraordinary power under section 44. Will he have to rely on this power even more as a result of these changes? Now that the Minister is in the chamber-I thank him for his presence-I await his response because of his extensive knowledge in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 10, after clause 9, insert the following clause:
``Losses and outgoings
``9a. Section 51 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following sub-section:
`(8) A deduction is not allowable under subsection (1) in respect of expenditure for the purpose of the advertising or promotion of-
(a) tobacco, substances containing tobacco, synthetic tobacco or any substance intended or designed for smoking;
(b) cigarettes, cigars or other items intended or designed to be used for smoking; or
(c) smoking pipes or any other accessories, items or devices intended or designed to be used principally for or in association with smoking.'.''.

This amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 which was circulated during the second reading stage is an insertion after clause 9 of the Bill and deals with the matter of tax deductibility of tobacco advertising. While I have canvassed a number of the matters which are of importance to that amendment, I would like to cover several of them again and emphasise their relevance to this particular piece of legislation.

In terms of the costs to Australia, the consumption of tobacco and tobacco products causes 23,000 deaths every year. Without doubt, it is the most important cause of drug related deaths. The Government paper, part of its drug initiative last year, clearly identified that 80 per cent of drug related deaths were related to the consumption of tobacco and tobacco products. Only 10 per cent were related to alcohol and only a couple of per cent to hard drugs. So the figure of 23,000 deaths per year is very significant. It is equivalent to 66 deaths every day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I believe that Senator Coulter is speaking on an issue related to sales tax. I understand that we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Is it in order to debate this other section which we have not yet come to?

—Senator Coulter is moving proposed new clause 9a. It is within the ambit of the Bill and he is entitled to move it. The question of whether the Committee wishes to accept it is up to the Committee to decide.

—I am very pleased that Senator Watson interjected, because it gives me an opportunity to correct a misunderstanding. The amendment removes the tax deductibility from the advertising of tobacco products. It has nothing to do with sales tax, as Senator Watson implied, and it is appropriate at this point in the discussion of the Bill.
—We are debating section 46e at the moment.

—No, we are debating proposed new clause 9a which has been circulated. The costs of consumption of tobacco products also weigh very heavily in the financial balance sheets of this country. The estimate of the cost of smoking related illness to business-and much emphasis has been put by both the Government and the Opposition on the need to make Australian business more competitive-is $940m per year in sick leave and decreased productivity. The social health and medical costs are roughly $1,000m per year, which is divided up as $400m in hospital costs, $250m in costs related to deaths and a further $350m in the social costs of lost wages and lost productivity. Undoubtedly we are dealing with an industry, the advertising of which costs this country very dearly.

SPEECH.PARA: The tobacco industry has claimed at various times that the advertising of tobacco products does not, in fact, lead to increased consumption. It has cited figures-I believe erroneously- which indicate that the decrease in the advertising of tobacco products has been accompanied by an increase in the consumption of tobacco. I do not think the figures bear that out. But if we take its figures at face value and accept its assumption, we would have to conclude that the advertising of tobacco represents an enormous loss of productive capability in this country in that Australia spends between $100m and $150m a year on advertising something which is apparently quite unnecessary. The industry could get on quite well without it. So even on the industry's own basis, there is no need for that advertising to continue.

The Committee will remember that several weeks ago I asked Senator Walsh a question relating to tobacco advertising along the lines that the advertising of tobacco is a tax deductibility, that the cost of advertising comes out of the gross income of a tobacco company before tax, whereas any other public interest group in the community which chooses to advertise the adverse consequences of tobacco would not get tax deductibility. It would have to collect money from people's incomes on which tax had been paid. So there is a very significant difference in equity between those who would promote the consumption of a proven extremely dangerous product and those who would seek to advertise the hazards of consuming that product. The amendment seeks to bring into balance, fairness and equity the relationship between those two forces in the community.

I recall that Senator Walsh, in his reply, drew attention to the fact that this is not a unique occurrence, that there have been a number of other occasions on which the tax deductibility of advertising has been used in a disadvantageous and unfair way. If I recall correctly, Senator Walsh's example related to the sugar cane farmers and the National Party of Australia in Queensland during the recent election campaign. One could also instance the mining industry in Western Australia in relation to Aboriginal land rights and the very extensive tax deductible advertising campaign that was used by the Australian Mining Industry Council to defeat fair and just land rights legislation that was proposed by the Western Australian Government. The Committee will have noticed that the Victorian Government, a Labor government, has recently moved to ban certain forms of tobacco advertising and to increase the tax on tobacco. Revenue gained from this source will be used to support sport and the arts. Similar moves have been suggested in Western Australia and South Australia. It would seem appropriate that the Federal Government should support this proposed amendment which is in line with a healthy society and equity.

Finally, I point out that the amendment, as it is related to a taxation Bill, does not seek to ban tobacco advertising. It merely seeks to remove the tax deductibility from tobacco advertising and to make tobacco companies pay for that advertising out of net income, not gross income, which would bring them exactly into line with anybody else in the community who wished to advertise the disadvantages of smoking or the consumption of tobacco products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

SPEECH.PARA: It is improper and disgraceful to seek to use the tax laws to impose a moral position on the Australian people. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather surprised to hear Senator Walsh make the remarks he did, in particular in view of the fact that he has acknowledged that this particular facility of tax deductibility has been used in socially disadvantageous ways. SPEECH.PARA: At present massive amounts of money are spent by the tobacco industry on advertising, roughly between $100m and $150m per year, but the amount which is spent and which can be spent, because of the inequity of this law, by those who oppose tobacco consumption is minuscule. Increasingly, we are seeing young people, particularly young girls, taking up smoking. There is no adequate patron for the opposite point of view, namely, that tobacco is hazardous to health. I am rather surprised that both the Government and the Opposition place a mere financial consideration above the considerations of social justice and equity and of the health of 23,000 Australians per year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 37 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 sets the rate for provisional tax for the coming financial year. The extraordinary thing about this rate is that it is 11 per cent. In other words there is an assumption, in setting the Budget figures, that there is to be an 11 per cent increase in the incomes of people who pay provisional tax in the following year. That is an extraordinary assumption, particularly in view of the fact that the inflation rate in the Budget Papers is 6.5 per cent, yet the increase in incomes is supposed to be 11 per cent for the purposes of budgeting. That means a 4.5 per cent real increase in the incomes. This is extraordinary, particularly in the circumstances of the stock market fall, which will clearly have a significant impact on provisional taxpayers, because provisional tax is paid by those with investment income and people who do not pay pay as you earn (PAYE) tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 37, which sets this rate, is a clear example of where the Budget is at risk-and the Budget achievement is at serious risk. We have in the Budget Papers an expectation that non-PAYE income will increase by 10.2 per cent. Of course that income is also at risk following the fall in the stock market, as there is no doubt that there is not an investor in Australia who would not have suffered at least a paper loss. If those people have been involved in share trading, there is no doubt that they will crystallise their losses in order to have a tax deduction. They may well repurchase that stock, but the reality is that anyone who has suffered a severe loss in the stock market over the last few weeks will be unlikely, if he is a trader, to ride that out if he can crystallise the loss and therefore wipe out his tax liability for the current year. Even without that kind of activity, there is no doubt that the prospects for the non-PAYE taxpayers of Australia this year are nowhere near as buoyant as this clause assumes by setting 11 per cent as the expectation rate for the increase in incomes of provisional taxpayers for provisional tax purposes.

This raises once again the serious question of the genuineness of the prospect of achievement of the balanced Budget, which we have been told is of such great significance and is such a wonderful achievement. There is no doubt in my mind that unless there is a massive burst of inflation, above the 6.5 per cent that the Government based its assumptions on, these objectives will not be reached. Of course, it is possible that there will be a massive burst of inflation because the 10 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar in the last week or so will considerably add to Australia's cost structure, and it will in fact damage the Australian economy, although it may provide some assistance to exporters.

But when we recognise that a reduction in the value of the Australian dollar will only add dramatically to the cost of imports, and that imports will be absolutely necessary if there is to be any increase in investment in new plant and equipment in Australia-and it is investment on which Australia's economic future depends-so the cost of investment in new plant and equipment will naturally increase, and inflation will increase. Our prospects of structural change, which this Government talks about but does little to bring about, will be diminished and the prospects of the achievement of any kind of real recovery will be diminished. In that instance there is absolutely no chance whatsoever, it seems to me, that provisional taxpayers will face in real terms, when it comes to pass, an 11 per cent increase in their incomes overall throughout Australia.

I regard this clause, which further undermines the integrity of the Budget-this has already been massively undermined as has been the capacity of the Government to deliver what it promised under this Budget-as absolute nonsense. I am pleased to see that one part of the clause recognises that the insidious capital gains tax should not include income for the purpose of assessing what the uplift factor should be for provisional tax for the following year. That, of course, is a reasonable measure. I am grateful that the Government has recognised yet another of the ludicrous consequences of the capital gains tax.

We have seen non-stop amendments to the tax law to fix up the mess created by the capital gains tax. This legislation is another part of that. My complaint is that the capital gains tax creates so many of these ludicrous problems. It is self-evident that the great majority of the amendments that we are having to deal with at the moment in this legislation emerge from the introduction of a capital gains tax which, as I mentioned in the second reading debate, is part of a campaign against the accumulation of capital. As a result of being against the accumulation of capital, it is against the capacity of Australia to invest in new plant and equipment to get us out of the economic disaster that we are now in.

According to leading commentators this morning, including a spokesman from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, we face the risk of even greater disaster, particularly if the current world market crises precipitate any sort of problem in commodity prices. We should listen when respected organisations such as the Commonwealth Bank warn of such a serious risk to our economic future and say that the stock market fall around the world does not simply affect stock markets but affects world economies. It certainly affects the Australian economy. As Senator Stone pointed out on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program this morning, two of the prerequisites that Senator Walsh had earlier mentioned for Australia having to take some action to change its approach are a massive outflow in capital from Australia and a fall in the Australian dollar. That appears to be happening now. It is nonsense for Senator Walsh to pretend that there has not been any kind of outflow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, you are getting a long way away from the clauses of the taxation legislation. You must look to those. You cannot engage in a general discussion on the economy except insofar as the economy affects the taxation laws.

—The reality is that this Bill specifically says that there will be an 11 per cent increase, for provisional tax purposes, in the incomes of people who do not pay pay as you earn tax. I am demonstrating that that 11 per cent figure is arrant nonsense and that the Government now knows that. At this point the Government is still proceeding-when it knows that figure is nonsense-with this amendment which would result in an 11 per cent increase in the earnings of people who pay provisional tax. I am saying that that is arrant nonsense and I am establishing very clearly the reasons why it is arrant nonsense and why it is dishonest of the Government to proceed with a Bill which simply cannot achieve its objectives and which the Government and certainly Senator Walsh recognise by now should be changed. This is one of the changes that should and must be made to the Government's economic strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has to recognise that there is a real crisis, that it is not just a matter of a few people losing some money on the stock market. It is a crisis which affects tax collections in Australia and which this Bill clearly sets in a wrong framework. As I have pointed out, it is a crisis which will affect the whole of our economy and therefore it will affect even those people who are not investors in the stock market. I regard the Government's continuation with this clause of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) as another example of its refusal to face reality. It has to make some effective changes to its strategy and it has to acknowledge that the basis on which this Budget was set no longer applies. I am not saying that the Government should display some panic response; all I am saying is that it should face reality and the reality at this stage appears to be that there will not be an 11 per cent increase in provisional tax collections.

I make it clear that the Opposition shares Senator Watson's concern about the matters he has raised today, particularly the question of discretion. We dealt with that matter yesterday and I was grateful that last night the Minister said that he would look into the problems with which we were concerned about proposed amendments to section 14zka of the Taxation Administration Act 1953. I am grateful that the Minister said that he would refer this question to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) because, as you will recall, Mr Chairman, the way this section is now arranged it seems to suggest that under section 207 the power to waive additional tax which is given to the Commissioner should be directed in those instances where the delay and the accumulation of penalty tax as a result of that delay have been due to the actions of the Commissioner rather than to any devious activity or deliberate stalling by the taxpayer.

Last night the Minister said, `But you have to pay this penalty tax only if you are guilty, if you have been found to have avoided paying your tax'. That misses the point of the question, which relates very simply to whether that penalty should be increased because of the lack of action, for whatever reason, by the Commissioner. I am grateful that the Minister is at least referring that question to the Treasurer. I want to make it clear that following the defeat of our amendments last night, there is no doubt that there is an unacceptable retrospective element in this Bill. However, we will not be opposing it on that account because, obviously, more important issues need correction. For example the capital gains tax is related to provisional tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put up an amendment.
—Regrettably, our amendments were defeated by the Australian Democrats supporting the Government, which is most unfortunate because there is no doubt--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—The clause before the Committee provides for the 1987-88 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1986-87 taxable income increased by 11 per cent and by applying the 1987-88 rates of tax and the Medicare levy. My colleague Senator Michael Baume has given us an economic speech indicating that some of those forecasts are perhaps illusory. Therefore, prima facie I submit that it would appear that the provisional income tax earner is being required to pay an excessive amount by way of provisional tax this year when neither the Government's projections nor the economic circumstances of the business community would support this figure. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the point raised by Senator Watson and also by Senator Michael Baume, I now realise that the Government made a serious mistake in programming this Bill for today. It should have been programmed for tomorrow, when there would have been less verbosity. Provisional taxpayers, almost by definition, are separate from wage and salary earners. Therefore, the estimated increase in the level of wages does not have any one to one relevance, if any relevance at all, to the level of income subject to provisional tax. I shall confirm the position with my officials, but my recollection, having been involved in the revenue committee over the past four or five years, is that the Commissioner of Taxation gives the Treasurer an estimate of what the Commissioner believes the level of income subject to provisional tax will be, and annually a figure is written in. There have been figures of 10 per cent and 11 per cent in previous years when we have been in government-there may have been some higher or lower, but that is the estimate. If, as Senator Baume asserts, the actual figure will be lower than the Commissioner estimates-and, to say the least, one should acknowledge that the Commissioner is likely to be a better judge of that than Senator Baume-any individual has the right to exercise the option to vary the provisional tax at which the individual has been assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the other matters raised by Senator Watson last night concerning clause 15 in the Bill and the proposed new sections 108 and 109, Senator Watson asked that the Government request the Commissioner to issue guidelines as to the manner in which the Commissioner will exercise his powers under the revised section 108 to determine whether or not a loan represents a disguised distribution of profits, particularly as regards legitimate intercorporate loans. There are a number of decisions of appellate bodies which give an indication of the manner in which the Commissioner should exercise his powers and, on the surface, it would seem unlikely that legitimate intercorporate loans would be put at risk. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

There will be a 20.4 per cent increase in Medicare collections, and this is explained in the Budget Papers, which reveal that about half of the increase is attributable to the full year effect of the rise in rate from one per cent to 1 1/4 per cent which took place in December last year. That rate rise was despite the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the previous election that there would be no rise in the Medicare levy. It is absolutely vital that every year this Parliament has the opportunity to see whether it is getting value for money out of Medicare. This Government and no doubt the Minister for Finance are very keen to ensure that the opportunities for seeing whether we are getting value for money out of Medicare are limited. They are certainly diminished by not allowing an annual review of the Medicare rate which would be the consequence of the Government's Bill. That is why we are amending it in the way we are. On 1 August we saw major changes relating to after hours visits and consulting physicians which were having a disastrous impact particularly on asthmatics, sufferers from Parkinson's disease and diabetes and people who have permanent problems of that order. Occupants of private hospitals have seen how they are no longer getting value from Medicare. They are not getting value from the levy because there has been a dramatic reduction in what they get from paying the levy and from paying the taxes which fund Medicare as to at least two-thirds of its real cost.

There is no doubt that there is a discriminatory element in what happens under Medicare at present. If one has treatment from a doctor in a private hospital, one is not entitled to the same rebate as if one had exactly the same treatment from a doctor in other circumstances. This amendment, which was first discussed in 1984-honourable senators will be familiar with it-refers to an item that I do not think has been satisfactorily dealt with. It relates to the problem of supplying goods to the disabled. The taxation law, as it currently stands, says that goods which are specifically developed or produced for disabled people are tax exempt under the schedule. I am not referring to all goods because I think every government has dealt with this matter in a very compassionate and reasonable way. However, I am referring to a different set of goods-materials that can be used by the disabled but also can be used in a general way by anybody in the community. I have given the example of a computer, which is probably the easiest one to grasp. Computers are on the general list and attract sales tax. A constituent who had a disabled son first brought this problem to my attention. The son was born with his hands attached to his shoulders. This is a particularly disabling problem, especially for a child who attends a normal school. As honourable senators would be aware, if possible children with disabilities attend ordinary schools and I support this arrangement very strongly.

In this circumstance, the father in some general discussions with a number of people-some of whom I know-came up with the idea of dividing the keyboard into two and having it mounted so the child could use the keyboard with his own hands. The computer, which has a capacity to display graphics, was put into a package so that he could take it to school to do his drawings and write along with the other children in grade one. A problem arose because the cost of the redesigned computer was not tax deductible. The family was not very well off. After some discussions, private companies provided the equipment at cost, hence overcoming the problem of sales tax, and the modifications were done by a number of professionals free of charge. That is a very graphic example of the types of things that could occur right across the board.

I have tried to draft the amendment in such a way as not to leave it open to abuse. Hence, at the end of the amendment I have added the words `and subject to such conditions, as are prescribed'. My intention there is to have this matter dealt with in the same way as we deal with a number of other items in the taxation schedule. For example, people are required to go through certain screening processes in respect of some items in the schedule. Items 114b, 115, 115a and 115b lay down requirements to be met before a person can receive a rebate for sales tax. In this situation, I envisage that a medical practitioner, a physiotherapist, or a person of that order, could certify that a particular piece of equipment is specifically useful for a person with a physical or mental disability. The certification would have to be initiated by a person who is disabled. Hence, it is not just an across the board exercise. It would be carefully positioned with regard to those items.

At the end of the day, if we look at what has happened in the example I raised, we will see that the level of abuse has been absolutely minimal. I think we are talking about an exercise which could be very beneficial to people who are disabled. I think my amendment would assist the disabled.

I realise the Government's difficulties with taxation. I am not unmindful of the need to raise taxes. In fact, I feel quite happy that my party is able to move such amendments. We have supported the Government in a whole range of additional tax measures such as the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, and the like. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Amendment Bill 1987. Senator Short will lead for the Opposition on this legislation. I take the opportunity to mention a couple of points about which we have been concerned because of the lack of detail in the Bill. The Government has brought forward legislation in this area and other areas without including all the detail and leaving a great deal to be filled in later by way of regulation. The Opposition has been dissatisfied with that approach. On this occasion, as on other occasions, we will be expressing that dissatisfaction. I think my colleague Senator Short is now ready to lead for the Opposition; so I will step aside in his favour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) for his graciousness in allowing me time to get ready to speak. That I was not ready is the fault of the Government in not calling for a division on the amendment moved during consideration of the previous Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now debating the Migration Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill has several purposes. Basically, it proposes four changes to the Migration Act. Firstly, it seeks to impose a fee for reconsideration of certain immigration decisions; secondly, it sets out to ensure that a request for an entry permit or visa is valid only if the prescribed fee and form are lodged; thirdly, it seeks to impose an immigration clearance fee-that is the euphemistic term; in fact, it is a new tax-on passengers on international flights seeking to enter Australia after 1 January 1988; and, fourthly, it seeks to introduce an alternative penalty mechanism for breaches of the principal Act in various respects.

Principally, the Bill is about tax changes. The Opposition will not be voting against the Bill as a whole because it is part of the Government's Budget package. However, we have some strong concerns about and criticisms of the Bill. The Bill raises many concerns about the fundamental direction and administration of government policy. I put that in the context not just of migration policy but of policy generally. The first point I make about the Bill is that it breaks yet another promise of this Government; it dishonours a commitment that was given in May this year and repeated right through until the election and, indeed, until the Budget was presented on 14 September. That commitment was that the Government would not increase any existing taxes or raise any new taxes.

It is quite clear from this Bill, and there have been other examples, that the Government did not even intend to honour that commitment. On 28 May-I think, the day after the election was called-the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in talking about the Budget, said:
On the receipts side let me confirm that there will be no tax increases in the 1987-88 Budget.
The following day he said:
The Government has made it quite plain that it does not intend to introduce new taxes or increase taxes in the Budget.
The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in launching the Australian Labor Party's policy for the July 1987 election, said on 23 June:
In the completed Budget in September there will be no new taxes and no tax increases.
On Budget night, in his Budget Speech, the Treasurer repeated the myth when he said:
Turning to the revenue side, I repeat that we have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes or introduce new taxes.
Those statements quite simply are not true. This Bill gives two lies to that proposition. First, it seeks to impose a new tax in the form of a $5 fee--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fee?

—It is a so-called fee; I am using the Minister's word. In fact, it is a tax to be imposed on passengers flying into Australia on international airlines. Secondly, the Bill seeks to impose another charge. One could argue about the euphemistic use of that word and about the definition of `taxes', `charges' and `fees'. They are all government impositions and therefore would commonly be regarded by people as taxes. The Bill seeks to impose a charge of $240 on people who wish to have reconsidered certain migration rulings that have been made against them. I shall return to some of those points later in my remarks. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:

`, but the Senate is of the opinion that the imposition of a fee of $5 on Australian citizens returning to their own country by international air travel is an obnoxious attack on the fundamental right of Australians to enter their own country'.

Last night I gave a contingent notice of motion that the Opposition would move to have consideration of this Bill in committee postponed until the Senate had been presented with the draft regulations which are to be made pursuant to the Bill and which, in many respects, are the core of the legislation. Without the regulations the $5 fee would not be imposable nor would the $240 charge for reconsideration.

It is quite wrong for the Government to expect the Parliament to pass this Bill without the Parliament having the opportunity to consider these key regulations because they underpin the Bill. Yet that is precisely what the Government has been planning to do. I understand from our Whip, Senator Reid, that the Government may now be planning to adjourn the debate after the conclusion of the second reading debate before the Bill goes into committee. If that is so, I assume that it is so because of the contingency motion I have moved on behalf of the Opposition in this place last night which, I understand, the Australian Democrats broadly supported. If that is the case, I welcome the Government's acceptance of our argument. But I will be seeking an assurance from the Government that we will not go into the committee stage of the debate until we have seen the proposed regulations and had an opportunity to consider them adequately.

Several fundamental weaknesses of this Government are highlighted by its method of handling this Bill. Let me list them. They are very important, not just in relation to the consideration of this Bill but in relation to the consideration of Government legislation generally. Firstly, the Bill demonstrates the almost inherent tendency for this Government to legislate from the hip or, perhaps, from the lip. The method of going about this Migration Amendment Bill has been extraordinarily untidy. The timing has been astray. The very fact that the Government introduced the Bill without having finalised the regulations is an indication of that. But there are other indications. The Government has established the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. It will inquire into a very wide range of immigration policies and procedures. The findings of the Committee will be very relevant, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, said, to the general question of consideration of appeals against migration decisions and the like.

There has been no attempt by the Government to co-relate this Bill with the FitzGerald inquiry which will report in the first half, or thereabouts, of next year. The Administrative Review Council report on migration matters and procedures last year had some pertinent things to say relevant to this Bill. Again, they do not appear to have been picked up. So the first concern we have is the tendency, the penchant, of this Government to legislate in a very untidy fashion and in a quite unco-ordinated way.

The second weakness of this Government which this Bill highlights is its arrogance to Parliament. The Government's treatment of Parliament is, to put the most generous blush on it, cavalier. But it is much more than cavalier. It shows a total disregard for parliamentary proprieties. The Government seems to see Parliament as a mere rubber stamp or a cypher for the Executive. That is not only wrong in principle, it is undemocratic and it is extraordinarily dangerous because it bypasses most of the normal procedures and constitutional arrangements we have always lived by in terms of the consideration of legislation affecting every citizen of Australia.

This Bill is the latest in a long line of examples of such treatment. We saw it in only the last week or so in the Government's handling of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. A major Bill was introduced without the Government having any intention of showing the Senate, before the Bill was passed, the regulations which contained the very standards the Bill was supposed to be about. The Migration Amendment Bill we are now debating-at least until the last few hours; it may have changed in the last few hours-has been similarly approached.

The third concern I have about the Government's treatment of legislation relates to my second point; it is the increasing tendency of this Government to bypass Parliament's constitutional role in enacting legislation which affects the life of every Australian. This Government is becoming increasingly a government of regulation rather than a government of legislation. There is a world of difference between the two. Government by legislation enables the Parliament and its elected representatives to consider fully, properly and appropriately the Government's proposals for the conduct of government and for legislation which affects, in some shape or form, the life of every Australian.

On the other hand, government by regulation bypasses most of that process. The Government argues-it argued in the case of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill-that it is not a government by regulation and that it is not bypassing Parliament because the regulations can be disallowed in the Parliament. That is a totally inadequate response to the concern about government by regulation because, although the Parliament can disallow regulations, it is a very inflexible procedure. The Parliament either accepts them or rejects them. There is no scope for the modification of regulations, nor is there any scope for proper and deliberative debate about them. Government by regulation, which this Government has embarked on at a breakneck speed ought to be of great concern.

Fourthly, we have seen an increasing tendency by this Government to be a government by Press release. Many of the Government's policy announcements are now made outside the Parliament by Press release. Legislation is subsequently brought into this place to legitimise the announcements made in the Press release. But often, when the legislation comes into the Parliament, it is different from the details that were set out in the Press release. Again I refer to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill of a couple of weeks ago. In the last session of the last Parliament we had several important tax Bills. The legislation was very different from the Press releases announcing changes to the taxation laws. They are always backdated in application to the date of the Press release even if the legislation differs from it. That, of course, is nothing more than blatant retrospectivity. That is a principle which we on this side of the House have said time and again is not only obnoxious but also bad government.

Fifthly, I am extremely concerned about the seemingly inexorable growth in this country of administrative law whereby more and more of the real decision-making processes are being taken over by the legal profession, the members of which are not elected representatives of the people. In that context I can do no better than to quote my colleague in the other place the honourable member for Dundas, Mr Ruddock, who said in the debate on this Migration Amendment Bill in the House of Representatives on 28 October:

The role of the Parliament and of the Minister are being usurped in this Bill and in a wide range of other legislation. We are going down the same track as we did in the family law area, where decisions about the way in which people's rights should be dealt with are made not by elected people representing the community but by judicial officers.
Talking about family law, he said:

Important decisions about custody are determined ultimately not by the guide-posts set by this Parliament but by the courts. Judicial officers, unelected people, are exercising discretions. And we wonder why we have problems in the family law area.

He went on to point out, very rightly, that this is precisely what is happening in the immigration area, where we have seen a tremendous growth in administrative law. Indeed, this Bill that we are debating today outlines a new approach and expands the appeals process. The courts will be usurping the function of this Parliament in dealing with appeals. When one takes all these factors into account, it is quite clear why the Opposition has considerable reservations of principle about the Migration Amendment Bill and why the Australian people, and not just those directly affected by this Bill, should have considerable reservations, too.

I want in a moment to turn more specifically to some of the details of the Bill. But before doing so I want to raise a matter which, although not included in this Bill, is very relevant to our overall migration policy and to some of the points of principle that I have been discussing. I refer to the reports that the Government will hand over control of the business migration program to the private sector-reports which Senator Reynolds, who I notice is here today, appeared to confirm in response to my question to her on this matter in the Senate yesterday. I will quote just one of the reports to which I referred and questioned the Minister about in the Senate yesterday. It is from the Australian of yesterday's date and it states:
The Federal Government is planning to hand over administration of the $1.2 billion-a-year business migration program to the private sector.

No indication was given as to how that move could be effected in a way which would do other than encourage speculators, in the form of immigration advisers, coming into the area. No indication was given of how the legitimate migration consultants could be protected or indeed how the reputation of legitimate business migrants could be protected. This is an absolute minefield, in my view. The Opposition is extremely concerned about it. We will, of course, have to wait on the detail to cast a final assessment on it, but unless extraordinary safeguards are built in, the Government is, in my view, putting a dynamite bomb into the midst of immigration policy in this country. Whilst I am a supporter of a much greater involvement of the private sector in doing things nowadays done by government, I cannot think of a less appropriate role for the private sector than that of making decisions on the immigration applications of business migrants to Australia. I am sure that we will hear a lot more about that subject.

I turn now to several of the specific provisions of the Bill. In doing so, I want to make it clear that, while we are critical of several aspects of the Bill, we support the overall intent of the Bill to broaden and at the same time speed up the review process. Over recent years there has been an enormous build-up in delays of unheard appeals. There has been an absolute explosion in them. In the last 18 months or so the number of appeals on the waiting list has increased, according to Mr Young, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in the other House, from 6,000 to 26,000. So in that case the borderline or marginal appeals-the important ones; the ones likely to have a decision affected by the appeal process-were being delayed by up to 18 months. I understand that in 1985-86 there were 3,688 unresolved cases. In 1986-87 that had grown to the staggering figure of 10,866 cases. So we are not in any way objecting to the intent of the Bill to change that situation. Indeed, we support it. What we question is whether this Bill will really tackle these problems effectively and meaningfully.

There are three particular aspects on which I wish to comment. Two of these concerns relate to clause 7 of the Bill. They are, firstly, the delegation of legislative power contained in that clause and, secondly, the imposition of a fee to be set initially at $5 on all passengers on international flights to Australia as from 1 January 1988, including, as I stressed before, Australian citizens returning to Australia after visits abroad. My third specific concern relates to clause 9 of the Bill. Clause 9 provides for the making of regulations for the reconsideration or review of certain migration decisions on payment of a fee, as I said, to be set initially at $240.

So far as the first of these three points is concerned-that is, the delegation of legislative power-I think it is very important indeed that the Senate take note of the report of its own Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on this matter dated 21 October. Let me just quote from that report. Commenting on the fact that arrangements for the collection of the $5 fee and its amount would be prescribed by regulations, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said:

Whilst the proposed amount of the fee ($5) may be regarded as no more than recovery of costs, the Committee in the past consistently objected to imposition of fees, which may be regarded as a form of taxation-
I stress that comment for the benefit of Senator Reynolds. This is the unanimous all-party report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It said that the imposition of fees:

may be regarded as a form of taxation, by regulation, without a limit set by legislation. The Committee has argued that the Parliament should not lightly delegate its taxing powers. The Committee has taken the view that a ceiling amount on such a fee should be prescribed in legislation.
Accordingly, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee drew the attention of honourable senators to clause 7 of the Bill. It said:
. . . in that by enabling the setting of a fee by regulation without an upper limit, the Bill may be considered to be an inappropriate delegation of legislation power.
That is a very damning comment by one of the most highly respected, informed and authoritative committees of the Senate.

Another point I wish to raise concerns both the principle and the imposition of the $5 fee on travellers and the method of its imposition. It is a tax. As I said before, it represents another broken promise by the Government. It is interesting to note that the Hawke Government was the first Government to introduce a fee for people to become Australian citizens. Now it has broken another record. It has added a further infamous string to its bow by becoming the first Australian Government to impose a tax on Australians returning to their own country. In my view, and in the view of the Opposition, that is simply obnoxious.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your departure tax?

—That is not to come in. That is a departure tax, it is not an entry tax. As I said, the principle of the new $5 tax and its introduction, via the delegation of legislative power, are objectionable. But so too is the method of its imposition. According to the Bill and to the explanatory memorandum, the tax is to be:

SPEECH.PARA: collectible by the international airline operator who brought the passenger to Australia. The operator will be responsible for the payment of the fee to the Commonwealth.
The explanatory memorandum goes on to say:
Arrangements relating to the collection of the fee and its payment to the Commonwealth will be able to be prescribed in regulations. The fee is initially intended to be $5.

I point out to the Senate that there are two significant words there. The first word is `initially'. There is no guarantee that it will stay at $5, and the one thing we can be absolutely certain of is that it will not stay there, it will escalate at an enormous rate. The second word in the explanatory memorandum which I found very interesting is that the fee is initially `intended' to be $5. This fee will not operate until 1 January. I wonder what it will be when it comes in on 1 January.

The concept of an actual fee at all came out of the blue on Budget night. I understand that there had been no discussion with the industry about this matter despite the fact that, as I said, the fee is not coming in until 1 January. There should have been ample time to discuss the matter and to try to work it out with the industry, at least to work out the mechanics of it. As I said, there was no consultation with the industry. I am now told that since the Budget, the industry is being consulted right, left and centre, while the Government is trying to work out how the fee can be collected. There are some enormous problems there. The shadow Minister for Tourism raised some of these in the House of Representatives on 28 October. I will not go in to them in detail at the moment, as time precludes that, but they are matters of great concern. But I refer honourable senators to page 1574 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 28 October, as it makes very interesting reading indeed.

Finally, the third point I wish to raise is the provision for the review of certain immigration appeals that is contained in clause 9 of the Bill, which prescribes regulations which will enable all of this to work. I understand and welcome the proposition that we will not be considering the Bill beyond the second reading stage until we have seen those regulations, so I will refrain from making further comment until that time.
