To date, these have been the only requests made, under the freedom of information legislation, for access to certified lists. No doubt there will be some more. I would think the Government will not be printing rolls again for at least another 18 to 20 months.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that, according to the weekly report of the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Treasurer on the foreign exchange markets for the week ended last Friday, 30 October, `the Bank made large sales of foreign currency in the middle of the week'? Is the Minister also aware, from the same source, that compared with the turnover in our foreign exchange markets, both spot and forward, averaging about $20 billion a day in the previous week, daily turnover last Thursday, 29 October, was a record $37 billion? Is he still convinced that these levels of activity derive solely from Australian importers purchasing forward the foreign exchange they will need in the months ahead for their imports? Even in the unlikely event that the Minister is-or, indeed, ever was-aware, has it yet been brought to his attention that such external payments leads and lags are also classified by the Australian Statistician, for obvious reasons, as capital outflow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a cheap and nasty start to this revision of history. It does not surprise me that people like Senator Stone want to revise history because, after all, it was Senator Stone who advised Potter Partners in August 1985-just as the biggest bull run in history on the stock exchange was about to take off-that it should unload its share portfolio. The Treasurer said the other day that anybody who takes Senator Stone's advice on financial or economic matters deserves all he gets. The revision of history is Senator Stone's quite false assertion that I said that currency transactions were all attributable to traders-importers and exporters. Of course, I said no such thing. Indeed, the absolute statement was made by Senator Stone, who said that if the Reserve Bank is buying Australian dollars-or, to look at it the other way, selling foreign currencies-obviously somebody is selling dollars. That is true. Senator Stone, however, then went on to say that the only original cause of those transactions is people withdrawing capital from the country. That blithely ignores the fact that people are always buying and selling Australian dollars, simply to facilitate international trade. It has nothing to do with capital movements.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that I am still astounded that Senator Stone refuses to acknowledge any qualitative distinction between the buying and selling of currency to facilitate international trade and the withdrawal of hot money from the country or the sale of assets in Australia by foreigners. I do not know why-well, I suppose I do know why-Senator Stone does not know to whom the Reserve Bank has been selling currency. He has admitted that, I think. He does not know whether it is overseas residents who have been purchasers of foreign exchange or, if they have been, the degree to which they have done so. That begs the question: Why is Senator Stone continually trying to talk down the dollar? One can discern a political motive for doing it. However, it is absolutely impossible to discern any responsible economic motive. In keeping with the custom or behaviour pattern he established many years ago, when he does not have information he tries to substitute posturing and dogmatic assertion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and concerns the Minister's heavy responsibility in seeking out means for reducing government expenditures which are consistent with both social justice and economic efficiency. The question is in three parts: firstly, has the Minister seen a copy of Mr Howard's list of proposed expenditure cuts which he promised to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on 26 October? Secondly, has the Minister assessed the equity and economic efficiency characteristics of the items on that list? Thirdly, has the Minister received and examined expenditure cut proposals from any other member of the Opposition's front bench?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have not seen Mr Howard's list of specific expenditure cutting proposals that he promised the ABC last week. That does not necessarily mean that the ABC has not received it but I would certainly be amazed if it has. If I were provided with such a list I would certainly be more than happy to do a personal assessment, and ask for a departmental assessment of it. I could not say for certain that I have not received any proposals for cutting expenditure from the Opposition-I have received a number of propositions for increasing it-because I have not checked through all of the files to see what tangible recent proposals might have been put up by, or on behalf of, Opposition members.

ANSWER.PARA: However, this morning, I found one tangible proposal which relates to Commonwealth payments to local government, a topic about which a number of Opposition senators have displayed interest in the last few days. I have a cutting from the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 August 1986-just over one year ago; immediately before last year's Budget, I think at the time when Senator Stone was a Sydney Morning Herald columnist. Senator Stone was developing an argument that there should be substantial cuts in government expenditure. He said this of local government:

Particularly since the Commonwealth Government has no good reason to be involved in local authority finances, those bodies also cannot be immune from the national cutback. Instead of the proposed 2 per cent real increase in Commonwealth payments to them this year, cutting those payments in half would save almost $300 million this year, spread widely across the country.

If Senator Stone would like to indicate that he still holds the view that the Government should cut $300m of local government funding, the Government would look at the proposal. We are willing to consider anything. I think Senator Reynolds would also be interested in the proposal and would probably seek comments from local government authorities, in particular local government authorities in Queensland, as to what they thought about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to reports following the stock market crash that the Treasurer has requested that the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) interpret its regulations with greater flexibility. Is the Minister concerned that such action by the NCSC could make it easier and cheaper for companies to succeed in takeovers which could reduce company tax revenue by billions of dollars? In particular, would the Government be happy for the NCSC to waive the provisions which prevent anyone making a takeover announcement, for example for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), from offering less for shares in the target company than he has paid in the last four months? Finally, is the Minister aware that a successful BHP takeover which uses the negative gearing loophole could deny the Treasury all, or part, of the $600m that BHP currently pays in company tax?

—I do not know anything about this matter. I have been told that there were some Press reports of it but I did not even see them much less get any official advice from the Treasurer. So I will have to refer that question to the Treasurer for a reply.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister get that answer to me as expeditiously as possible?
—I do not expect that I will be able to get an answer today but I will see whether I can get it for tomorrow.

—I ask the Minister for Justice: Are any prisoners in Australian gaols as a result of prosecutions carried out by Commonwealth authorities? If so, how many and of what sex are they and in which gaols and in which sections of those gaols are they imprisoned? Are any in gaols built by the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Cooney, who was kind enough to give me very short notice of this question, I have been able to put together some figures which may be of help to him in a preliminary way. He asked, firstly, whether there are any prisoners in Australian gaols as a result of prosecutions carried out by Commonwealth authorities. The answer is yes. As to the numbers and what sex the prisoners are, the answer is as follows: as at 1 September 1987 there were 452 Federal offenders. In New South Wales there were 201, of whom 181 were male and 20 female; in Victoria 84, of whom 74 were male and 10 female; in Queensland 54, of whom 48 were male and 6 female; in South Australia 37, and the 37 were male; in Western Australia 71, of home 63 were male and eight female; in Tasmania there was one male; in the Northern Territory there were three males; and in the Australian Capital Territory there was one male.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cooney will be interested to know that 62 Australian Capital Territory prisoners-59 males and 3 females-were detained in New South Wales institutions on 1 September 1987. No statistics are available on the numbers of joint offenders. Senator Cooney further asked how many were held in maximum security prisons on 3 November 1987. I regret that I have been unable, in the short time available, to obtain that information. I will do so as soon as possible, perhaps by the end of Question Time but certainly by Question Time tomorrow.

Senator Cooney asked whether any prisons were built by the Commonwealth, and the answer to that question is no. He further asked who is responsible for the classification of Federal offenders. Federal offenders are held in State prisons by virtue of section 120 of the Constitution. The State authorities are responsible for the classification of Federal offenders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Treasurer agree that rising prices on international commodity markets during the past six months or so have reflected expectations of rising inflation? Does he agree that the Australian dollar is widely regarded internationally as a commodity currency and that this has been a major factor underpinning the strengthening of the Australian dollar during that time? Does he also agree that in the light of recent financial market developments the outlook for international commodity markets is now towards deflation rather than inflation? If so, what conclusions does he draw from that as to the outlook for any currency widely regarded internationally as a commodity currency? What implications does he see for the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another step in the sustained campaign by the Opposition to try to talk down the dollar. It is the sort of economic sabotage that Andrew Peacock indulged in in February 1983. Of course the Opposition would love to see an economic collapse in Australia because it knows that unless it can get its act together much better than it has so far it will not have a snowball's chance in hell of winning government. So I can understand the political motive for trying to spread this doom and gloom, trying to talk down the value of the dollar, investment and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether I believed that recent improvements in commodity prices are due to rising inflationary expectations around the world. People can believe whatever they want to believe and indeed some people can then assert it as unchallengeable truth. I have a copy of a speech-I will not bother to quote from it now but I will at some other time-which contains a number of such assertions of unchallengeable truths. Frankly, I do not know what caused the recent improvements in commodity prices. One would have to pry inside the minds of the people who buy the commodities to find that out.

It is generally true for commodities that stocks have been running down, and in those circumstances it would not be all surprising if there were an increase in price. I noticed that in today's Australian Financial Review Michael Stutchbury's article refers to Andy Stoeckel, the former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, saying that one should not be surprised if commodity prices rise by 30 per cent before the end of 1988. I do not know why Dr Stoeckel said that or how sound his assessment is, any more than Senator Short could know what was in the mind of commodity buyers that persuaded them to pay higher prices in the last few months than they had paid in the previous year or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to media stories about increased revenue for Aussat Pty Ltd. These stories suggest a vastly increased revenue for the use of Aussat during this year, although the project still makes a loss. Can the Minister state what loss this year will come from Aussat and how that compares with the previous year? Also, what facilities does Aussat bring to particularly remote Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pre-tax loss for Aussat for 1986-87 was $34.9m. The net loss, taking into account for the first time a future income tax benefit, was $17.8m. The magnitude of those losses has caused some Press comment and generated some political interest. In response to that situation, a number of points should be made. The year 1986-87 was Aussat's first full year of commercial satellite operations. The use of transponder services increased by 40 per cent during the year, and at year end over 80 per cent of available in-orbit capacity had been sold, the majority under long term contracts, providing a sound base for continued growth of the satellite system. Revenue for the year was $73.7m, some 2 1/2 times the revenue of the previous year. Sales revenue was sufficient to fund all cash operating expenditures and interest payments, and that is an important step towards full commercial operation. In terms of its product life cycle, the company is still in its infancy. It is unreasonable to expect the company, in a highly capital intensive industry, as this one is, to generate profits at this stage, given that it has been operating for only two years. Aussat is broadly on target in its long term financial planning.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the kinds of things which Aussat is doing, and which we want it to go on doing, for people living in remote parts of Australia the list, as honourable senators should know, is pretty substantial. There is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation homestead and community broadcasting satellite service; the remote commercial television service, which is operational in Western Australia and imminent in central Australia and which is the subject of ongoing discussions for consideration of options for the north-east and south-east of Australia; Telecom Australia's Itevra service, which provides communications to customers in remote areas; and the State specific government communications network, Q-Net, in Queensland. There are also specialised networks in the provision of data and other communication links for remote mining and construction sites.

Other services that Aussat provides include the distribution by the Special Broadcasting Service of its television programs to reach most capital cities and a large number of provincial and regional areas; the national satellite based commercial radio news gathering and distribution network, Macsat, run by Macquarie Broadcasting Holdings Ltd; and the distribution of news agency, information and other data services run by Australian Associated Press. There is the establishment of a range of private video, voice and data services for a wide range of governmental and corporate sector users. There is the distribution to hotels and clubs of video entertainment and information services on a subscription basis, and there is the Starnet corporate data service. Therefore, I think it can be said that Aussat obviously is providing a range of communication services of a great deal of value covering the domestic, commercial and industrial needs of the Australian population.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate-wearing his Hawaiian suntan, I see-in that capacity as well as in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister will be aware of the concern expressed by the Steel Industry Authority about the doubling of time lost through industrial disputes last financial year and what the Authority has described as `the alarming downturn' in productivity. Does the Minister agree with Senator Walsh that, while both the company and the Government have met their obligations under the steel plan, the work force is, to quote Senator Walsh, `actually letting the agreement down'? Is it a fact, as reported in today's Australian Financial Review, that many of Australia's competitors have already achieved productivity rates of 500 tonnes per worker per year compared with the 245 tonnes achieved in Australia in the June quarter of 1986-87? What prospect is there of the Australian industry increasing its competitiveness if unions carry out their threats to resort to strike action in the event of further work force reductions following expiry of the steel plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deal first with the observation part of Senator Lewis's question, which came at the beginning-his reference to my Hawaiian suntan. I assure him that that is incorrect. The last place I visited on my overseas trip was London, and there was not much suntan to be had there. When I became Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, if I proposed an overseas trip it was always suggested to me that I spend four days in Tahiti on the way back. I asked my Department why it was always suggested that I should spend four days in Tahiti and I was told, `That is what Ministers in the Fraser Government always used to do'. That came out of the computer, I was told. I am grateful to Senator Lewis for mentioning that matter as a starting point.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the situation of the steel industry, I thought that Senator Lewis said all that he wanted to say on this issue yesterday. I substantially agree with Senator Walsh because what Senator Lewis was talking about yesterday and what Senator Walsh was talking about was the report of the Steel Industry Authority dealing essentially with the first quarter of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report.

—It was the annual report, but the industrial relations point made by the Steel Industry Authority related to the first quarter of this year. That was a very bad period in the history of the steel industry about which I made a number of comments at the time, and from which I do not retreat.
—And which I quoted.

—If Senator Lewis quoted me, I am grateful. He is starting to develop a sense of perspective at last. On that issue I agree with Senator Walsh. In confronting the issues of the steel industry now and in the future, let me say that the company anticipates a vastly improved level of production in the coming months, which is very welcome. Senator Lewis also drew attention to comparative figures with the Japanese steel industry, I suspect, although he did not mention the country, where a particularly high rate of tonnes per year of production has been obtained. As I recall the figures for Japan, they relate to Nippon Steel where there has been a 40 per cent reduction in the work force. Similar figures might well be quoted in respect of United States Steel, which has improved its productivity with a reduction in its work force from 100,000 to 20,000 in the last five years.

ANSWER.PARA: As to how these issues might be accommodated in the future, I would point out that the Steel Industry Authority, which is the appropriate body to do this in my view, met both unions and representatives of the companies last week and sought a resolution of a number of these issues for the future. From such reports as I have had it appears that there was a willingness to address those issues and try to reach a new form of agreement on industrial relations in the steel industry. The problems which occurred in the first half of this year were related not just to industrial relations but also to the introduction of new plant by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and some difficulties that were encountered with the introduction of that plant.

The important question for the future is whether agreement can be reached on the way in which reductions in the work force can be accommodated and the industrial relations situation improved. As I said, I believe that the Steel Industry Authority made substantial progress with discussions on that matter last week and I do not wish to prejudice any outcome of those discussions by making inflammatory or other comments which I might well be tempted to make. On this occasion I will resist the temptation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Special Minister of State seen comments by the shadow Attorney-General about the Government's planned display of the Australian Constitution? Does the Minister agree with the shadow Attorney-General's comments that the exhibition is nothing but `a travelling circus'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the comments by the shadow Attorney-General and I was surprised that he spoke about this very exciting, major event for the Bicentenary in such disparaging terms. To refer to it as `a travelling circus' is quite inappropriate. I will tell honourable senators some of the details of this travelling exhibition, but I point out that the reason why it is travelling is to enable people in regional and outback Australia to participate in the Bicentenary.
—And in Tasmania.

—Indeed, in Tasmania, as my colleague Senator Tate points out. I would have thought that a person who was in coalition with the Party that used to claim to represent country people would have been particularly enthusiastic about the fact that this exhibition will travel. In fact, it will be the greatest road show ever to tour Australia. It will visit 34 towns and cities across all States and Territories and the itinerary was chosen particularly to maximise the number of people in rural Australia who will have access to that exhibition.

ANSWER.PARA: The exhibition will be opened by the Prime Minister on 1 January 1988 in Wodonga and will close in Sydney in December 1988. It is planned as an exhibition about Australia for Australians. It is a unique show which will focus on our history, our heritage, our culture, our community, our achievements and our future. It will celebrate the contributions of all Australians-the Aborigines, those who arrived with the First Fleet and more recent arrivals. It is very well constructed in terms of service to rural and regional Australia because at each venue the local community will have an input to the exhibition, focusing on the history, arts, achievements and interests of that community. Therefore, it will not just be something that is being brought to the community; it is something which the rural communities can contribute to and participate in in a very creative fashion.

The exhibition is a model of government and private sector co-operation in planning bicentennial activities. The Commonwealth Government will contribute $19m and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has made the most generous sponsorship of $6m. Valuable assistance is also being provided by other Australian companies. Honourable senators can see that the shadow Attorney-General is very misguided indeed, very negligent of the interests of country people and badly informed about the scope and nature of what will be, for many Australians, particularly those living outside the metropolitan areas, the highlight of our 200th anniversary.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who will be aware of the much talked of need for the United States of America to significantly reduce its massive deficit, and quite properly so. However, inasmuch as a major part of Australia's export earnings depend very heavily upon world commodity prices, what does he believe would be the short or immediate effect upon the Australian economy of a contraction of the American economy due to the share market collapse, when compounded by a significant and serious attempt by the Americans to reduce that deficit which, in itself, must further contract the American economy in the short term leading to a slackening of Japanese exports to America, which will shunt into a reduced demand for Australia's commodities? Inasmuch as the Australian dollar has fallen by 10 per cent against the basket of currencies since September, does he believe that our level of inflation is likely to be greater than that previously predicted by the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne's question has a sense of deja vu about it because I happened to run into him in a London hotel on Friday of last week-not in the bar, I hasten to add-when he asked me much the same sorts of questions. At the time I did not apprehend that this was a rehearsal for Question Time in the Senate, but I must tell Senator Crichton-Browne that while he was absent the day before yesterday there was a quite savage attack on a member called Brown for his overseas trips. At first I thought honourable senators were talking about Senator Crichton-Browne, but it appears that it is some other member!

ANSWER.PARA: All I can say about the first part of the question is that a number of United States commentators have been drawing attention to the fact that a savage reduction in the size of the United States domestic deficit might compound the consequences of the share market fall in the United States which has, presumably, had a significant effect on small investors and so on. If the expenditure cuts associated with a large reduction in the deficit were not carefully targeted, they might have the effect of compounding adverse consequences for that section of the community. That is a matter which I have no doubt the United States Administration will be discussing with Congress presently as it tries to reach a resolution to the question of how the Budget deficit might best be reduced.

Senator Crichton-Browne also asked me about the reaction that these matters were likely to produce in the United States in terms of the United States trade deficit, particularly with Japan. There seem to be two schools of thought about that in the United States. There are those who argue for a reduction in the domestic deficit and a more rigorous economic policy. They see the share market fall as being a suitable vehicle to enhance their argument. Then there are those who support the current trade Bill before Congress and who say that the share market fall necessitates further action on the protective front to stop Japanese and other imports from coming into the United States market. It would be foolish for me to speculate as to how that argument will resolve itself in the American context. With regard to the last part of Senator Crichton-Browne's question, the answer at this stage of my awareness of the topic is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I again ask the latter part of the first part of my question. Does the Minister accept that the Americans are not given to concerning themselves with our economy when they are looking at their own? Therefore, with the compounding of the fall in the share market and the way in which it will contract the American economy, does he accept that if there is a significant reduction in the American deficit it will lead to a reduction in commodity prices which will affect Australia very significantly in the short term?

—I think that is an extremely difficult question to answer. Any answer would be highly speculative. In answer to an earlier question, I said that there will undoubtedly be some apprehension that world wide changes in share markets could lead to a downturn in commodity prices. That is certainly a view which has been expressed in some areas. I cannot take it beyond that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Is it a fact that the Norfolk Island population of boobook owls is represented by a sole surviving female and that there is an urgent need to re-establish owls on the island? Is the Minister in a position to report on efforts to persuade New Zealand boobook owls imported to Norfolk Island to enter into a procreative liaison-or to mate-with that island's sole surviving owl?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This important question should not be the subject of hilarity. I think all honourable senators will be aware that the National Parks and Wildlife Service, after extensive studies, discovered last year that the population of boobook owls on Norfolk Island is down to one and that this owl is a lone female. In order to rectify this problem and to make our lone female a little happier, it was determined to import two New Zealanders. One might wonder why the importation of New Zealanders would make anyone happy. Nonetheless, this was attempted and two New Zealand male owls were deposited on the island. Since that time it has become obvious to me that this has aroused the population of Norfolk Island. According to correspondence I have received, not only those with a professional interest but also interested volunteers are, in fact, crawling all over the bush of Norfolk Island trying to determine whether an event of substance has taken place. Our hope is that after a whirlwind courtship there might be unmistakable signs that a traditional happy event will take place. So far I have to report that it has been noticed that most of the activity appears to be oral. Lest I be accused of language unbecoming, might I say that most of it has been vocal. Very often, of course, New Zealanders are all talk and on this occasion there has been much calling. It is, of course, the answering that we are most interested in and, while we have no doubt that some of the calls are of a propositioning nature, we are not yet certain that these amorous intentions have been replied to.

ANSWER.PARA: As another comment on the character of New Zealanders, one of the birds has shown excessive signs of enthusiasm. It has been responding to the calls of a local rooster. It is to be hoped that this enthusiasm is not misdirected in the coming weeks. While I would always commend enthusiasm of this sort, I hope that it could in the end be directed to the female that is spending so much time alone. I know that with all of those people who are crawling all over the bush of Norfolk Island, searching for signs of this happy event, I will be able to report to the Senate further. So far all I can say is that the New Zealanders have contributed nothing but noise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind Senator Button that he has in the past offered the view that the Australian dollar was overvalued. In the light of the rapid fall in the Australian dollar to about 91 yen and of the trade weighted index to about 51, will the Minister now indicate whether he adheres to his earlier view that the Australian dollar is overvalued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A month or so ago I was quoted as having expressed some views about the Australian dollar, in particular views which were expressed by exporters both of primary products and of manufactured goods. Those views were all expressed publicly at the time. As a result of what I was supposed to have said, the Opposition raised a matter of public importance in the Senate and asked a series of questions. I thought the Opposition would have said all it had to say on that occasion.
—Was that when the Treasurer said, `Don't take any notice of him'?

—The honourable senator will learn in time. I am answering the question asked by Senator Peter Baume. I appreciate the giant size of Senator Stone's intellect, but I am sure that Senator Baume is capable of asking his own questions.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no view about the value of the Australian dollar which is expressed in the market-price of the Australian dollar. I have already been asked questions today about what I feel might have affected the market changes. I have declined to answer those questions, except to say that there have been a number of speculations about it to which I have pointed and I have nothing to add to those speculations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications to the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review, which claims that the Government is unduly protective of Qantas Airways Ltd and that this has caused a shortage of seats for international travellers to Australia. Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Knowing as I do the passions of people in this place whenever anything to do with the subject of overseas travel is raised, I wish to make a number of points in response to that editorial. I will go just to the general issues rather than to specific, alleged factual matters because it will take too long to deal with all the misconceptions and distortions which are contained in the editorial.

ANSWER.PARA: First, let me say something about the short term capacity situation. That situation is, as the editorial points out, quite unprecedented in terms of the level of demand for inwards travel and the sudden increase in recent months. As I have said previously, peaks are usually experienced at this time of year, but this year they are severely pronounced. This is not a problem that only Australia is facing. I think we all ought to appreciate that. The Asian region in general is experiencing the same level of increased demand as Australia. The Orient Airlines Association has just released figures which show that demand for travel from Europe into Asia-particularly Hong Kong, Singapore and Bangkok-is increasing at some 13 to 15 per cent over the previous year, the same rates of growth that Australia is experiencing.

As part of its response to the increase in demand, Qantas has been liaising, as I previously said, with Asian carriers on seat availability both between Europe and Asia and intra-Asia. The experience there is the same: full flights extending right through the onset of the European winter, extending beyond the normal peak into January. In terms of what we are doing about it, in addition to the 137 supplementary flights which have already been announced, Qantas will be leasing a 747 aircraft for six weeks from mid-December to early February with an option to extend to the end of April. Subject to the necessary technical clearances, I intend to approve that proposal as soon as I have received the formal application.

As a result of the extra aircraft, plus further schedule planning by Qantas, Qantas will be operating more than 20 extra flights in addition to the 137 that have already been announced over the holiday period. Many of these extra 20 will be to London but they will also be to Singapore, Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur and Manila. The Department has approved 55 supplementary flights by foreign carriers for the same period with a further 15 under consideration. We will give swift consideration to any further applications that might be received. In this context, I am sure that honourable senators will have read reports in the Press, which appear to be accurate, that a number of foreign carriers are interested in operating supplementaries-certainly, we would not stop them for a moment if they did-but they are prevented from doing so because of aircraft unavailability, or because they have made the commercial decision that higher returns can be made by deploying capacity elsewhere.

The other issue in the editorial about which I would like to say something, because it has been the subject of a great deal of misunderstanding, is the claim that the present situation can be blamed on the bilateral negotiating process. That sort of claim cannot be sustained and it demonstrates a lack of the most rudimentary knowledge about international aviation. International aviation is regulated through a system of bilateral air service agreements between governments. There are over 1,500 such agreements in place worldwide. They in turn cover something like 700,000 city pair combinations. No government can operate unilaterally in international aviation, or in a way which ignores the reality and significance of those agreements. It is not a matter of any regulatory ideology or protective ideology on the part of the Australian Government; it is simply the reality of international aviation relations.

Under most of these agreements, and certainly those to which Australia is a party, the designated airlines of both parties are afforded equality of opportunity to operate the agreed services, which opportunities may or may not be taken up. This does not mean that any carrier is guaranteed 50 per cent of the market as has been suggested in a number of quarters recently. `Quality of opportunity' is not the same thing as saying `guaranteed market share'. There is a fundamental difference. Aviation in this respect is no different from any other bilateral trading activity. Agreement is possible only when both sides are prepared to come to an arrangement that is satisfactory to their own interests. There is a great deal more that I would be happy to say on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say more.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLICY GUIDELINES FOR COMMONWEALTH STATUTORY AUTHORITIES AND GOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's policy information paper concerning policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises and seek leave to make a statement on the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The policy information paper entitled `Guidelines for Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises', which I now table, represents a further major step in the overhaul of Commonwealth public sector administration which was a commitment of the Hawke Labor Government in its 1983 statement `Labor and Quality of Government'. These reforms are consistent with and follow wide-ranging reforms to other parts of the machinery of Commonwealth administration, implementing streamlined, performance oriented management practices based on devolution of responsibility-`letting the managers manage'-with appropriate accountability for results. In particular, the guidelines for statutory authorities and government business enterprises establish processes for better defining and expressing the objectives which enterprises serve and against which their performance will be evaluated, as well as acknowledging the need to reduce the extent of Government controls over their operations.

SPEECH.PARA: The reforms indicate the Government's commitment to achieving the highest levels of operational and financial efficiency in Commonwealth business enterprises. This commitment flows from recognition that as a group these enterprises constitute an important business sector providing a significant proportion of the infrastructure on which the rest of the Australian economy depends. Efficiency in resource allocation and use by these enterprises is imperative, given that they employ about 3 per cent of the Australian work force, which is about 50 per cent of Commonwealth civilian employees, and their annual fixed investments constitute about 5 per cent of national gross fixed capital expenditure, which is more than three-quarters of the Commonwealth total.

Through the Government, all Australians have a significant investment in these enterprises. As at the end of June 1986, the book value of the Commonwealth's holdings of loan and equity capital in its 16 largest enterprises totalled an estimated $12.3 or some $2,500 for each Australian household. Given the scale of this investment and the central role of these enterprises, the degree to which their efficiency can be enhanced by objective measures will have a major bearing on the success of the Government's program to improve Australia's international competitiveness. This is one more way in which the Government is moving to protect average living standards after the reduction in national income which resulted from the decline in Australia's terms of trade. If Australia is to maximise its productive potential, the Government needs to ensure that public investment in business enterprises earns an adequate rate of return, if necessary after allowance on an objective basis for the cost of meeting any `community service obligations' or other non-commercial objectives required by the Government. Unless there is continuing attention to bottom line performance there will be pressure for misallocation of resources.

These guidelines cover measures to improve the efficiency and accountability of government organisations by administrative means. They do not address other measures which may advance the same goal in some cases, such as the issues of their ownership or competition in the areas in which they operate. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has announced that the Government will encourage broad-ranging debate on these matters. This is because as a Government we recognise that Australia needs now, as never before, to maximise the efficiency with which economic and social objectives are achieved. Unfortunately, objectivity in the public debate on achieving efficiency in these Commonwealth business enterprises has often been blurred by the intrusion of ideology. Assumptions that an enterprise will deliver services more efficiently if it is privately owned, or that private ownership is synonymous with competition, have no more validity than an assumption that because an enterprise is publicly owned its resources are necessarily being deployed in a manner which will maximise the public benefit.

In determining policy in relation to government business enterprises it is useful to clarify the issue by separating what might be called `natural monopolies' from the others. Telecom Australia is an obvious example of an enterprise which fits into this category. The scope of such a monopoly will always be blurred at the margin where it faces competition from substitute services and these substitute services may be available from public or private sector sources.

To the extent that public ownership has made it possible to conceal through uniform pricing the costs of delivering services, for example to isolated communities, there is an economically inefficient allocation of resources but greater equity. However, the economic inefficiency should not, as is often suggested during public debate on these issues, be attributed to the fact that Telecom is publicly owned. Telephone services cannot be produced economically in an isolated community nor can the cost of such services be fully recovered from the recipients. An attempt to recover the full cost of such services to isolated communities would necessarily result in prices higher than the market will bear. The consequences of that would be continuously increasing average costs and therefore prices in response to continuously falling demand, and continuously falling demand in response to continuously increasing average costs and therefore prices. Eventually all services would be terminated outside those major population centres where average costs are within a range which the market will bear. Losses on services to these areas are currently covered by cross subsidies at a cost to Telecom of some $500m per year.

The Opposition has suggested that the solution to this problem is to privatise Telecom. The fact is that a profit maximising private firm would provide virtually no services except those within and between the major cities. The rest of the business is innately unprofitable. Few Australians would accept a system which provided no telephones to about a third of the population and 95 per cent of the country. The Opposition's solution to that problem is to suggest that a private company or companies could be subsidised from the Budget to provide these innately unprofitable services. That is a possibility but it destroys any case for privatisation based on the assumption that the profit motive would induce a lower cost, more efficient service. Clearly, a privately-owned company with its costs underwritten from the Budget has no profit-related interest in efficiency or cost minimisation. If costs plus a margin are underwritten from the Budget there would in fact be an incentive not to seek efficiency.

The Government's approach to this problem is to retain organisations like Telecom in public ownership and to look at what might be done to improve their efficiency. In particular, the Government aims, through these guidelines, to impose financial discipline on its business enterprises, having regard to the need for enterprises like Telecom to accept what I would call community service obligations. With such obligations it is not reasonable to expect Telecom to meet a target rate of return equivalent to a market rate, but it should meet such a rate after the community service obligation has been netted out.

The Hawke Labor Government is committed, through these guidelines, to maximising the public benefit by efficient operation of Commonwealth business enterprises. They are the product of extensive consultation following the tabling of the policy discussion paper Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises on 10 June 1986. At that time I indicated that a period of three months would be allowed for public discussion and comment on the proposed guidelines outlined in the paper. The policy discussion paper was given wide public circulation and the period for submission of public comments was extended to the end of October 1986 to accommodate groups unable to meet the original deadline. Some 70 written submissions were made by Commonwealth departments, authorities, enterprises, unions, consumer and employer groups and other organisations. To assist discussion and comment on the paper in the Commonwealth public sector a round of consultations was held between my Department and interested authorities and enterprises and associated Commonwealth departments during September and October 1986. During this period my Department also held meetings with interested non-government organisations.

Reaction to the proposed basic guidelines for statutory authorities outlined in chapter 2 of the Green Paper was almost universally supportive. This was not unexpected given that they were essentially a codification of current practices. The general tenor of the comments received was that these guidelines would be both comprehensive and flexible enough to accommodate the wide variety of circumstances facing the many different Commonwealth statutory authorities. The Government believes that these guidelines provide a suitable policy framework for the establishment of new authorities and the review, as appropriate, of arrangements for existing authorities. The basic guidelines focus most closely on Budget dependent statutory authorities. A number of issues specific to government business enterprises are dealt with in separate guidelines but unless there is a statement to the contrary the basic guidelines have general application.

The proposed specific guidelines for government business enterprises, notwithstanding almost universal support for the underlying objectives, generated some public controversy. The key areas of concern were in the areas of strategic or corporate planning and financial targets. Most enterprises accepted the need for strategic planning and the submission of appropriate information about their forward plans to the responsible Minister. However, there was widespread opposition to the proposal that these plans be subject to ministerial approval. In relation to financial targets, there was general acceptance of the view that a satisfactory rate of return should be earned on assets employed in government business enterprises and that enterprise boards and managements should be accountable for performance in this regard. However, there was concern that the financial return on assets should not be the sole criterion of performance, and that there should be proper regard to the cost of meeting community service obligations or other non-commercial objectives required by the Government. There was strong support from enterprises for the relaxation of many of the direct controls over their activities, and it was observed that the proposed guidelines were not specific in terms of either the controls to be relaxed or the timetable for their removal.

It was clear from the comments received on the proposed guidelines for government business enterprises that the enterprises differ markedly from each other in their history, spheres of activity and operational objectives. As a consequence, determining common principles governing their activities is difficult. Nevertheless, the Government reaffirms its view that common principles, carefully drawn, will have a positive impact on the efficiency and accountability of the enterprises as a group, leading to significant gains for the public. The public are not only the consumers of the products and services of the enterprises but also their financiers through the provision of public debt and equity capital as well as retained earnings.

The guidelines, which have been substantially redrawn after consultation, will be implemented on an enterprise by enterprise basis, allowing for the different features present in each case. We are now convinced that this individually oriented approach will achieve better results than drawing up a detailed White Paper on the subject as had previously been envisaged. This follows a change of emphasis since the policy discussion paper was released. The Government has taken the view that, while the responsibility must be exercised within an appropriate framework of consultative arrangements with other Ministers, the onus for achieving improvements in the performance of government business enterprises rests primarily with the boards of individual enterprises and their responsible portfolio Ministers.

The aim of the Government's reforms is to provide incentive, enhance efficiency and improve public accountability. It is intended that these objectives be achieved through a package which combines removal of unnecessary central controls which detract from enterprise performance with greater emphasis on bottom-line per- formance. Government attention will be focused on strategic issues which are properly a matter for ministerial responsibility. For enterprises which have been established as companies the guidelines will be applied in a way which recognises constraints imposed by companies legislation and the enterprise's memorandum and articles of association. Under the guidelines each enterprise will be expected to provide its responsible Minister with a strategic corporate plan covering periods of around three to five years ahead. There will not be a requirement for ministerial approval of the plans, but the responsible Minister will be able, if necessary, to suggest to the enterprise board that a preferred strategy of the corporate plan be reconsidered to better reflect relevant government policies.

Adequate arrangements for the flow of relevant information to other Ministers with key co-ordinating responsibilities is also essential for well informed, sound decisions on public enterprise matters. For example, the Treasurer generally has responsibility for approving off-Budget borrowings by enterprises, which is necessary for control of the overall public sector borrowing requirement, while the Minister for Finance determines the terms and conditions of Budget advances along with the approval of financial leasing proposals, forward obligation limits-in some cases-and other transactions impacting on the Budget. Some key aspects of enterprise activities-such as the approval of major new investment programs or sales of assets, dividend payments, limits on borrowing programs and equity injections or repayments-in practice need the joint approval of several Ministers.

Appropriate financial targets for enterprises constitute the linchpin of the Government's reform package. The precise structure of the target will depend on the nature of the enterprise concerned but, unless there are compelling reasons to the contrary, will take the form of a specified rate of return on the enterprise's assets, funds employed or capital. For some enterprises the target may be set for periods of several years rather than annually, although annual reporting of performance will be required. Targets will be agreed with the responsible portfolio Minister having regard to the impact on profitability of any `community service obligations' or non- commercial objectives required by the Government as well as market circumstances. The introduction of financial targets will require the development of appropriate accounting and reporting practices. My Department will pursue these through further development of the Government's guidelines for the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings.

The Government will closely monitor the implementation of this new policy framework for the operation of its statutory authorities and business enterprises. While some fine tuning may be necessary, the Government believes that the guidelines provide a suitably coherent, consistent and flexible approach to the oversight of authorities and enterprises. This is intended to ensure that these bodies operate with maximum efficiency and effectiveness and reach higher standards of performance. The new arrangements will benefit the Australian community, complementing the other initiatives the Government has taken to improve the competitiveness of the Australian economy and the wide-ranging reforms to the machinery of Commonwealth public administration which have been instituted since coming to office in 1983. TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a copy of the statement made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) since about a quarter to one today. SPEECH.PARA: That all began, as I said, very shortly after the Government first came to office, about four years ago. I have to say, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to the Minister that quite frankly I find it difficult to determine what the paper is really attempting to achieve. If the Government is serious about privatisation, and I will come to that in a moment, as a means of achieving greater efficiency-after all, I think it would be acknowledged by the Minister at least as a theoretical possibility of achieving greater efficiency in the public authority sector, and certainly we were led to believe that by a whole series of comments from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), particularly since the last election-one would have to say that this paper is totally irrelevant. I was going to say `virtually', but I corrected myself. Paragraph 8 of the printed copy of the paper states that these guidelines:
do not address other measures which may advance the same goal-
that is, to improve the efficiency and account- ability of government organisations-
in some cases, such as the issues of their ownership or competition in the areas in which they operate.

The Government is putting on Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark or, in this case, without the two Princes of Denmark, if one can envisage such a circumstance. Neither privatisation nor increased competition is addressed in this paper as a means of improving the efficiency of operation of this large body of public authorities which, as the Minister in one of the somewhat pedestrian but, no doubt, still accurate statements in the paper, quite accurately, tells us comprise about 50 per cent of Commonwealth civilian employees and employ about 3 per cent of the Australian work force. Their annual fixed investments comprise about 5 per cent of national gross fixed capital expenditure; in other words, more than three-quarters of the Commonwealth's total of such capital expenditure.

I think one can deduce from that statement that, quite contrary to what the paper so blatantly seeks to mislead us by stating, in fact the paper is not about improving the efficiency of the public authority of the statutory corporation sector; it is simply about giving some kind of totally formal discharge of these expectations which the Government, and Senator Walsh in particular in his capacity as Minister for Finance-he has had the carriage of this matter throughout-has led us to believe would be brought about at long last by this great denouement in which he would be telling us how the Government was actually going to do something in this area.

Let us take the statement in the order in which the Minister himself took it. I have already cited some of the figures that the Minister referred to and some of the other figures in paragraph 5 of his statement, in which he mentions that through the Government all Australians have a significant investment in these enterprises. That is perfectly true; we do. But I think we would have to say that we do not see as much return on that investment as most of us would like to see. That is what the debate is or should be all about, if it were not for the fact that the Government today has run away from it and totally abdicated its responsibilities in this matter. In paragraph 5 of the paper the Minister says that at the end of June last year:
the book value of the Commonwealth's holdings of loan and equity capital in its sixteen largest enterprises totalled an estimated $12.3 billion.

He goes on in the following paragraph to make this palpably empty-I will not say palpably stupid as that is a phrase often on the Minister's lips-claim that the proposals which he is bringing before us today, which do not amount to the proverbial row of beans, represent `one more way in which the Government is moving to protect average living standards after the reduction in national income which resulted from the decline in Australia's terms of trade'. If Australia is to maximise its productive potential the Government needs to ensure that public investment in business enterprises earns an adequate rate of return-
the meaning of the word `adequate' is, I think, nowhere explained or drawn out-
if necessary after allowance on an objective basis for the cost of meeting any `community service obligations' . . .
