This characteristically straw-man argument on the part of the Minister is just that-a straw man. If the Minister is referring to arguments coming from this side of the chamber, I cannot ever recall any such arguments-quite the contrary. The Minister points out later in his remarks that losses on services to these isolated communities currently are covered by cross-subsidies at a cost to Telecom of some $500m a year. He then says-and this is the point I really wish to nail as one of the more outrageous misstatements of the Minister from whom outrageous misstatements are commonplace--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for outrageous statements.
—He is the Minister for outrageous statements, as Senator Newman very properly suggests. Paragraph 14 begins with this outrageous statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has suggested that the solution to this problem-
that is, the fact that losses on services to isolated communities currently are covered by cross-subsidies at a cost to Telecom of some $500m a year-
is to `privatise' Telecom.
Two sentences later, the Minister said:
Few Australians would accept a system which provided no telephones to about a third of the population and 95% of the country.

I would like the Minister, who has now left the chamber, or his substitute Minister, if he feels disposed to accept the challenge, to tell me or anybody else on this side of the chamber from where those statements are drawn. What justification is there for them? Are we to become accustomed not merely to misleading statements, but to outright lies appearing in government documents? Is that to be the standard of debate and governmental statements from now on? I should not say `from now on' because perhaps there was more of it in the past when I was not here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1983.
—Since 1983, as Senator Messner reminds me. To add to this misrepresentation, the Minister goes on to suggest:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's solution to that problem is to suggest that a private company or companies should be subsidised from the Budget to provide these innately unprofitable services. That is a possibility but it destroys any case for privatisation . . .

Perhaps I should desist from this line of argument in as much as there is no basis for the statement and it is, to some extent, a waste of the Senate's time to continue to rebut it. Therefore, I will return to something more productive than rebutting misrepresentations from the Minister for Finance. As I have said in this chamber on two separate occasions already in the short time I have been here, if one spent one's time in this place responding to misrepresentations from Senator Walsh, the time of the Senate would be occupied with nothing else.

I come to a most interesting comment, having left that peak of mendacity. In paragraph 19 of the paper, the game is given completely away. Having argued at various points in the statement that this document represents the culmination of four years of hard work by the Government to produce a solution to the problem of achieving greater efficiency in statutory corporations and government business enterprises, paragraph 19 says:
Reaction to the proposed basic guidelines-
that is, the ones originally proposed and of which these are a much watered-down version-
for statutory authorities outlined in Chapter 2 of the Green Paper was almost universally supportive. This was not unexpected given that they were essentially a codification of current practices.

That is to say, the Government was writing down, codifying, what was already being done. That was, even in the Green Paper, the basis on which the Government approached the matter and yet which it sought to portray to this chamber and the Australian people as a major reform of our public sector. What a total joke. What a pathetic attempt to hoodwink the public on what the Government really has been about. If it was a joke even in the case of the Green Paper, what we have today is merely a milk and water version of the original joke.
It is true that there was some opposition to one section of the Green Paper proposals. I point out that that was conceded by the Minister in his statement. In paragraph 21 he acknowledges:
. . . there was widespread opposition to the proposal that these plans-
that is, the strategic and corporate plans which it was proposed that statutory corporations would be required to provide to the Government-
be subject to Ministerial `approval'.
There was, indeed. In paragraph 25, the Minister acknowledges:
The guidelines, which have been substantially redrawn after consultation, will be implemented on an enterprise-by-enterprise basis . . .

That is bureaucratic language for saying, `We will continue the same process of ad hockery as in the past'. I do not necessarily want to suggest that that is a bad thing. As the paper quite properly points out, most business enterprises are different from each other. Therefore, it is inevitable that there will need to be a degree of individuality in the approach properly taken to them. The only thing is that this quite pragmatic and common sense conclusion has been obvious for the past four years during which time we have been told on many occasions that the Government would reform the system and produce an overall corset of some kind into which authorities would need to be compressed.
What has also happened has been acknowledged only obliquely in paragraph 25 of the paper, which states:
The guidelines, which have been substantially redrawn after consultation, will be implemented on an enterprise-by-enterprise basis.
Paragraph 26 states:
This follows a change of emphasis since the Policy Discussion Paper was released.
One of those changes of emphasis-it is a most significant change-is as stated in that paragraph:
. . . the onus for achieving improvements in the performance of government business enterprises rests primarily with the boards of individual enterprises and their responsible portfolio Ministers.

That is an oblique way of saying that Senator Walsh got rolled in the Cabinet room. Ministers who are responsible for bodies such as Telecom, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, Australian National and the Australian National Line simply refused to be told that in future Senator Walsh would run this segment of their portfolio. Therefore, the Minister has had to beat what might kindly be termed a strategic retreat. However, I have to say that both the nature and the pace of that retreat have been very much amended and accelerated by very recent events.

Let me take a few of the more interesting reports on this whole question which have come into the public domain in the last fortnight or so. These reports have been emerging in the context of the increasingly heated debate which has been occurring within the parliamentary Australian Labor Party, the Caucus and its back bench committees on the whole question of privatisation. The Times on Sunday of 18 October headlined an article by Mr Geoff Kitney, its chief political correspondent, `Cabinet ministers challenge Hawke on privatisation plans'. The article stated:
Two senior Federal Cabinet Ministers have put forward proposals aimed at heading off Government plans to sell or part-sell publicly owned enterprises such as Australian Airlines . . .

This as we all know has been very much on the mind of Senator Gareth Evans. Indeed, it underlay his recent decision to bring into this chamber a proposal to terminate the two airlines agreement. The article continued:
The move represents an unprecedented direct challenge from within the Cabinet-
not just within the back bench-
to the major policy objectives of Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Treasurer Paul Keating.

A great deal more is stated along the same lines. However, I will not address my remarks exclusively to that newspaper which is not always of record-the Times on Sunday. Let me take another newspaper, the Sydney Morning Herald, of 19 October which ran an article headed `Left to wage war on PM's sell-off' by Steve Burrell who, at one time I think, spent a brief time in the Treasury-he fleetingly passed through that organisation. He is now one of the Sydney Morning Herald's chief financial economic writers and certainly could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be said to be unfriendly to the Government, judging by the nature of his columns on most occasions. Mr Burrell stated:

A senior unionist yesterday threw down the gauntlet to the Prime Minister on privatisation, saying the union movement was prepared to take mass industrial action to block any sell-off of public enterprises.

In this country a senior union official is telling us that, however inadequate the elected government of the country may be, it will still not be in charge and the union movement will make sure that it is not, if it proposes to do anything it does not regard as appropriate. Ironically enough the man in question was Mr George Campbell, the assistant national secretary of the Amalgamated Metals Foundry and Shipwrights Union. Mr Campbell was the man who the Treasurer (Mr Keating) attacked at the Labor Party biennial conference in Hobart about 15 or 16 months ago for having, as the Treasurer elegantly put it in the sort of rather striking phrase which he sometimes manages to utter, in 1981-82 produced the smash in the metal trades industries and who, as a consequence, in Mr Keating's graphic words, had 100,000 dead men around his neck. This paragon of the trade union movement, according to a Minister of the Crown, is quoted on 19 October as having said:
. . . the wide cross-factional opposition in the Labor Party to privatisation would mean ``acrimonious defeat'' for Mr Hawke at the party's National Conference next year if he pushed the issue.

We all know the kind of push Mr Hawke is capable of when he decides that the numbers are against him. The push at that stage is in the opposite direction, and that is what we are seeing. This morning when the Whips gathered we were told out of the blue that the Minister would make a ministerial statement. I will not say it was a long awaited ministerial statement because although it has been long awaited nobody has been holding his breath to receive it. Why? It is because the Government has quite soundly, from a tactical point of view, taken the view that the sooner it cuts its losses in this area and gets out of it the better and that is what Senator Walsh has been busily doing this afternoon. He will be cutting the Government's losses on privatisation and in this whole area. Mr Campbell stated:
We are not going to allow in this country a situation where the decisions about our future are not made in Parliament House but in the boardrooms of the major corporations . . .

That is Mr Campbell's graphic way of putting it. What he means is that he will not allow this Government to sell off any government assets. That is what he is saying. In the Age newspaper of the same date is a report by Mr Russell Barton who reported similar events in much the same terms. On this occasion Mr Campbell was reported as saying;
He would not `telegraph' the Left's tactics but conceded that it had not ruled out-
and I use his words-
`some form of mass action both in the public and private sectors'.

Mr Campbell said that the deal with the government of the day, if it should be so recreant to its duties to the trade union bosses, was that it would actually make some decisions in the interests of the Australian people. A great deal more of those kinds of statements is in Press clippings of about that time and, indeed, more recently. More recently the battle has moved into the Caucus room. On 21 October the Australian newspaper carried an article by Mr Donald Greenlees who wrote:
The battle lines over privatisation of government-owned assets will be drawn next week-
that is, the week following 21 October-
in Federal Caucus with a move by Centre Left and Left MPs-
I take the opportunity of noting in passing that Senator Walsh is a member of the Centre Left faction in the Labor Party-
to isolate the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and senior ministers.

Centre Left faction leader, Senator Peter Cook, yesterday signalled an attempt by MPs to force ministers into drafting reports on how government assets such as Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank can be retained in full public ownership.

That is all very interesting but it has nothing very much to do with the major reform of our statutory corporations; it has nothing much to do with improving the efficiency with which these corporations operate; it has nothing much to do-in fact, quite the contrary, it has nothing at all to do-with improving the rate of return on the public assets of over $12 billion which these bodies represent. It has nothing to do with the objectives in the statement which the Minister has presented this afternoon and certainly has nothing to do with the original claims-I would almost say boast-which this Government, and this Minister in particular and his predecessor, Mr Dawkins, as Minister for Finance, set out over four years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the statement of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises which was introduced along with the statement. As Senator Stone noted, introduction of such a paper is somewhat overdue. The Green Paper from which this emanated has been, as the Australian Financial Review put it a few weeks ago, in the pipeline since 1983. It seems that this differs significantly in some areas from proposals that were floating around as recently as earlier this month. It was originally thought that this matter would go through Cabinet only after some trade-offs in the area of flexibility and so on had been included. I refer to flexibility in areas such as salaries, industrial relations, borrowings, capital purchases, land acquisitions, sales and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It would appear from a relatively cursory reading of this paper, as I have been able to spend even less time upon it than Senator Stone did, that the area of staffing, for example, has finished up being one in which statutory authorities will be required to staff under the Public Service Act, unless there are strong reasons for doing otherwise, rather than have, as I understand it, the more unfettered capacity to hire and fire which was originally proposed. It may well be that recent events on the stock exchanges around the world have cooled people off from this rather unfettered private sector mode of behaviour, and that it will not be imposed on statutory authorities and other government instrumentalities. The Government appears also to have come to terms with the fact that some services by statutory authorities carry a public good requirement, although some Opposition senators do not believe that they should. In other words, the Government has argued that it is a requirement that authorities take into account the fact that they are providing services to people at a cross-subsidised rate so that some people in the community can get services which they would not otherwise have.

I was a little disturbed in the debate on the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill to hear an Opposition senator dispute the need for people in isolated areas to be given cross-subsidisation. The Minister points out in the paper:
In determining policy in relation to government business enterprises it is useful to clarify the issue by separating the `natural monopolies' from the others.
Telecom Australia is given as an example of an enterprise which fits into the category of natural monopoly. The statement points out:

The scope of such a monopoly will always be blurred at the margin where it faces competition from substitute services and these substitute services may be available from public or private sector sources.

To the extent that public ownership has made it possible to conceal through uniform pricing the costs of delivering services, for example to isolated communities, there is an economically inefficient allocation of resources but greater equity . . .
Telephone services cannot be produced economically in an isolated community nor can the cost of such services be fully recovered from the recipients.
This is worth remembering, bearing in mind a comment made by Senator Alston during the debate on the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill. He said:
The blind notion that somehow everyone ought to have a telephone today will be translated into the equally blind notion that tomorrow everyone should have a television set.
He went on to say:

If people choose to live in country areas, it does not axiomatically follow that they should be entitled to all of the services that are perhaps taken for granted in some country areas. To the extent that they are necessary for the public good, there may well be a case for government subsidy. Otherwise, I-
that is, Senator Alston-
would have thought that the choice should be a private one, not a public one.

I do not know whether Senator Alston has ever lived in an isolated area in this country, but if he has he has not learned any lessons from it. Certainly he does not appear to have a great deal of sympathy for people who, having sacrificed a great deal to contribute an equally great deal to this country's economy, naturally feel that they should not be discriminated against when in receipt of services such as telephones, and other forms of communication such as television sets. Given the importance of electronic communications in this country at present, I would have thought that even Senator Alston would not regard the provision of decent television reception to isolated areas as a luxury, the cost of which should be borne by the recipient, the user, rather than by the community as a whole. I would like a few Opposition senators to rethink their attitude to this sort of cross-subsidisation.

The Government, as is apparent from this paper, has also not fallen for the Liberal Party of Australia equivalent of the Animal Farm catchcry, `Two legs bad, four legs good'-in other words, that it is bad if it is provided by the public sector, and automatically good if provided by the private sector. Again, the paper makes some reference to this in pointing out:

Assumptions that an enterprise will deliver services more efficiently if it is privately owned or that private ownership is synonymous with competition have no more validity than an assumption that because an enterprise is publicly owned its resources are necessarily being deployed in a manner which will maximise the public benefit.

It goes on to point out that the Opposition has suggested that the solution is to privatise, amongst other things, Telecom. The fact is that a profit maximising private firm would provide virtually no services, except those within and between the major cities. It is about time that the Opposition parties learned from the example in Britain. When British Telecom was sold off what occurred was simply an increase in cost to the consumer with no concomitant increase in the services that were provided. A monopoly is a monopoly, whether private or public, and there is no guarantee that service provision to the users will be any better if provided privately than publicly, nor that the costs necessarily will be kept down.

Although Senator Stone resiled from arguing with the proposition that was put in paragraph 15 of the paper, I think that it is incumbent on the Opposition parties to come up with some sort of conclusive proof that a private company or companies will provide a better service than public ones or, furthermore, to justify the argument that a private company or companies which cannot provide services to all at the same price could be subsidised from the Budget to provide these innately unprofitable services. This raises the question of how private private enterprise is, or even how enterprising private enterprise is, if it has to be bailed out of its unprofitable areas to provide the services. We cannot argue on the one hand that a company is private if it puts out its hand to the Government for some sort of subsidy or offset when the going gets tough. It is a little like the Opposition's attitude to regulation and deregulation. Opposition members want those regulations that help them make a vast amount of money, but want deregulation where it suits them as well. Businesses and private enterprises generally like governments to introduce regulations that protect them in some way, but they want to be left with a free rein in all other areas. The fact is that life is just not like that. One cannot pick and choose in that way and retain any sort of credibility.

I am pleased to note that the Government appears to have backed away from its deregulate and privatise mode that was evident during the time between the election and the stock market crash. I repeat that we welcome the Minister's statement. On the surface at least it seems to be a reasonable alternative to the privatisation mania of the New Right and the cost to the public purse of an inefficient, poorly structured, government protected Public Service. Earlier, Senator Stone asked: `Is this all there is?'. As far as I am concerned, it is enough at least for the time being. Instituting massive upheaval and total reform in an area such as this is hardly likely to result in the most efficient outcomes. I think it is probably better that the Government proceed slowly rather than willy-nilly in the way that might have emanated from the proposals in the earlier Green Paper.

Obviously, we will all have to look more closely at the contents of the guidelines and at the effects of the proposed changes on a case by case basis. To do anything else would be to resile from the responsibility that we have as members of parliament. We will need to check, for example, that the moves proposed in the guidelines do not result in price increases of essential services-for example, an unjustifiable or excessive increase in the price of telephone calls and stamps. We in the Australian Democrats will be keeping a fairly weather eye to ensure that these guidelines are not simply part of a softening up process for full scale privatisation.

This paper appears to have taken a fairly middle of the road course. It has given increased independence without removing public scrutiny and public accountability. I think this is fairly effectively summarised in paragraph 27, which was mentioned by Senator Stone, in that the Government is being careful to be moderate in what it is doing. Paragraph 27 argues that the Government's aims in these reforms are to provide incentives, to enhance efficiency and to improve public accountability. Its intention is to provide a package that:
combines removal of unnecessary central controls which detract from enterprise performance with greater emphasis on bottom-line performance.

I would have thought that, as far as the public sector is concerned, that is something that everybody would have wished. The `public good' element is retained-the capacity to provide services across the board, not a user pays basis but on a cross-subsidised basis-along with a commitment to increased efficiency and more extensive provision of the services that we have all come to expect and accept from the public sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this document, Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises, to be both deeply disappointing and highly tendentious in content. It purports to be a document that sets out policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. Indeed, after a labour of some 2 1/2 years-or perhaps 18 months since the last Green Paper-we have received very little for those efforts. If one looks at the justification for the nature of the guidelines, paragraph 8 states that they cover measures to improve the efficiency and accountability of government organisations by administrative means and they do not address other issues which may advance the same goal in some cases, such as the issues of their ownership or competition in the areas in which they operate. If ownership and competition are not issues that are crucial to the efficiency of the operation of government enterprises, I do not know what are.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot of nonsense in this debate and recent debates about there being no inherent advantage in private sector activities. Indeed, the document tries to run this canard once again-that somehow assumptions that an enterprise will deliver services more efficiently if it is privately owned have no more validity than an assumption that because an enterprise is publicly owned its resources are necessarily being employed in a manner which will maximise the public benefit. That whole line of debate has been blown out of the water in recent times by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-a very recent convert to the notion of efficiency by means of total or partial privatisation. But nonetheless he has put down two questions. In all his jumping backwards and forwards on this issue, his most recent statement is to the effect that there is a need to justify public ownership of activities to the extent that if they can be performed better in the private sector, they should be. If that is not a presumption in favour of the private sector, I do not know what is. That is not just in terms of the financial constraints that operate upon a lot of Public Service operations; one only needs to look at the whole gamut of bureaucratic controls that currently operate.

That is why I find this document so deeply disappointing-it does not come to grips with such current limitations as the requirement for the remuneration of board members and senior executives of many government business enterprises being determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. In fact, it continues the practice and almost boasts that industrial relations arrangements will remain subject to government oversight and co-ordination. It does not lift any of the restrictions on the ability of business enterprises to adopt commercial superannuation arrangements. It standardises audit and accounting requirements, but does not ease them to any extent. Again, it retains the ministerial oversight and the requirement for ministerial approval of borrowings. It does nothing to ease up the Loan Council limitations. It perpetuates controls over enterprises such as Australia Post by the Prices Surveillance Authority. It retains the requirement for the Department of Administrative Services to give approval for acquisition of land and for leasing of property. Again, it retains such administrative controls making enterprises subject to such Acts as the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the Ombudsman Act, the Freedom of Information Act and the whole range of ways in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has special jurisdiction over public trading enterprises that simply do not apply in the private sector.

Finally, the workers compensation arrangements are excessively generous. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is fighting a very strong battle at this moment to try to do away with common law rights to impose lump sum limitations on the excessively generous scheme that operates at present. It would even seem that he is contemplating going down the Victorian WorkCare road where there was a disastrously naive belief that somehow a greater emphasis on rehabilitation would ensure a reduction in the number of claims and a greater degree of efficiency. The end result is that within a period of some 18 months we have seen a blowout to $2.4 billion in the losses of that government operation. I would have thought it was quite clear that that was a classic example of how a government trading enterprise could be presumed to be more inefficient than having multi-insurer arrangements. I have no doubt that even Senator Walsh will come around to that way of thinking in the not too distant future.

But there are very many ways in which public trading enterprises suffer from crippling limitations that reduce their efficiency. While this paper starts out by saying that it will not deal with ownership or competition as issues, it then proceeds to an almost passionate defence of some of the anti-competitive and public arrangements that preclude any real opening up of the public sector to efficiency concepts. The notion, for instance, in paragraph 7, that one can treat Telecom Australia as a natural monopoly is a disgraceful distortion of economic reality. The idea of a natural monopoly is one where economies of scale are available to such an extent that if one other enterprise entered that arena, neither could operate as efficiently as one. That concept can apply to a very limited extent. It operates to a very limited extent, if at all, in the telecommunications area which has been overtaken by the technological revolution. Telecom may well have some vestiges of natural monopoly on the local network and perhaps even on the long distance network and it may well be that there is a very sensible justification for retaining the monopoly over the common carrier network, but that has absolutely nothing to do with opening up the first phone monopoly. It has nothing to do with the customer premise equipment and it has nothing to do with value added services. I find it extraordinary that the Government can put down such a superficial dismissal of the justification for exposing Telecom to some areas of competition.

I am not arguing that Telecom should be wholly privatised. I do not for a moment suggest that that is inevitably the way in which it should go. It is very interesting to note that the Prime Minister, in saying that Telecom and Australia Post would be sacrosanct when it came to privatisation, went on to say that he was not arguing that they should be immune to competition in various other sectors. It is perfectly clear that if the Walshes, the Dawkinses and the Keatings of this world get their way there will be substantial competition introduced into a whole range of public sector activities. I regard that as a very healthy development in the Australian community which will provide services to consumers at a much more efficient level.

It is tragic to try to misconstrue, as the Australian Democrats do, any sensible assessment of the realities of cost to rural and remote areas. It is one thing to make an explicit political decision and a commitment to the subsidisation of those services; it is another somehow not to want to know about the real cost of those activities. If it is costing on average something like $15,000 for remote telephone connections-and in some instances the marginal cost is up to $40,000-the public deserves to know about that. The cost should be transparent and a sensible, political judgment should be made about whether that is the most effective use of a government subsidy.

I find it deeply disappointing and verging on the dishonest that this paper should pretend that somehow the only way in which we can fund a subsidy is by a direct government grant. That is the notion that is put forward in paragraph 15. I well recall the Economic Planning Advisory Council discussion paper canvassing a range of possibilities, not the least of which was a levy that could be imposed across that sector. A whole range of competitors in the telecommunications industry could be levied and those funds could be used to contribute towards the cost of that subsidy. If we seriously want to maintain the level of first phone connections-and 91 per cent of the population already have them-or extend the number throughout Australia, as Telecom is currently committed to doing over the next four or five years, we could do so at government expense by adopting such an arrangement. We could do it in such a way that the burden would be borne by existing users of telephones and not by the whole of the community as is currently the case with the cost being paid for out of Consolidated Revenue.

I regard the idea that somehow the only alternative is to provide a subsidy from the Budget as a gross distortion of economic reality. It is an example of why this paper is so seriously and fundamentally flawed. It is deeply regrettable that the paper should be some sort of defence mechanism against the tide of privatisation, that it should be misleading the public to such an extent that it does not recognise the real virtues of competition and enterprise that should be very much at the top of the agenda.

The reality is that a huge war is going on in Caucus. Over the last few days Senator Cook has been trying to have debated a motion to put serious restraints on the sale of public assets. Consideration of that motion has been deferred, ostensibly because the Prime Minister is crook. We have seen the Victorian administrative committee of the Australian Labor Party back away from its original hard line. Yet only this morning we saw an abject cave-in by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who was previously a very enthusiastic advocate of privatisation. Of course, the blow torch has got to him and now he has told the committee to go away and rethink. He does not want to accept the tentative advice he has been given that there should be massive deregulation of the industry. That is not put forward on any ideological binge, as this paper would somehow suggest. Ideology is always what is said by one's opponents; the argument one uses for oneself is sweet reason. The Prime Minister and Senator Walsh are past masters at throwing that sort of dirt around.

I regard the use of the word `ideology' as no more than an abusive code word to disguise the fact that Senator Walsh and Co. are not winning the debate at present. It is a tragedy that the sensible discussion on these issues has to be confused in such a way. We do not subscribe to blind ideology; we believe in efficiency and competition. We believe that that will be in the best interests of Australians. Those who use the term `ideology' are intellectually bankrupt and are playing the man and not the ball. I would have thought that we should have gone long past that approach.

Given the time constraints, the last thing I want to say is that it is a fantasy land notion to suggest that somehow this paper provides one more way in which the Government is moving to protect average living standards. It is an amazing red herring. It has nothing to do with the price of fish. It is quite clear that it is just the ordinary genuflection towards some sort of motherhood statement about responding to the need for protecting average living standards. But that has nothing to do with the notion of efficiency. The fact that the stock market has fallen through the floor, that all the fundamental economic indicators are in the opposite direction, and that this Government is very much on the back foot, should not have to be the basis for introducing a paper of this sort which is now called an information paper. It should be an enduringly valid statement that is appropriate irrespective of the economic climate.

This paper should have been addressing efficiency and competition instead of somehow pretending to define them away in the first instance and then embarking upon this totally dishonest defence of Telecom and other agencies. It is not Telecom's fault; I think there are many enlightened senior executives in Telecom who very much appreciate the pressing need for real competition, who do see the virtues of at least partial privatisation as a means of enabling Australia to get into the international arena to take up many of those export advantages that are crying out to be taken advantage of. It is tragic that the Government, for sheer political motives, is caving in to pressure from the unions and others and is building these artificial walls around enterprises that themselves appreciate the need for competition. I am disappointed in the paper. I had hoped that there would have been a lot more in it about notions of efficiency. Sadly, that will have to wait for a change of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a policy information paper entitled Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. This paper very closely follows the framework which was actually set in June 1986 in a discussion paper entitled Statutory Authorities and Government Enterprises. One wonders about the rationale for introducing today a paper which contains such vague and often incoherent terms. I want to draw attention to four major deficiencies that I see in this paper. Firstly, the document represents little more than a restatement of current accounting and control practices. Earlier in this debate my colleague Senator Stone perhaps put it a little more succinctly when he said that it represented a codification of those sorts of practices. Secondly, the paper fails to acknowledge the work and the contribution of a number of important committees of this Parliament. I refer just to two that I believe have played a significant role in upgrading the accounting standards in this area. One is the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the other is the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The third deficiency in the report is that it is full of what I might term motherhood-type statements. I support that contention by quoting item 6 in section 1 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the scale of this investment and the central role of these enterprises, the degree to which their efficiency can be enhanced by objective measures will have a major bearing on the success of the Government's program to improve Australia's international competitiveness.
That is fine in that it talks about the Government's program, but that is just a motherhood statement. Item 7 reads:
If Australia is to maximise its productive potential the Government needs to ensure that public investment in business enterprises earns an adequate rate of return . . .

We have heard these sorts of statements so often that they are becoming rather bland. Unless they are supported by positive initiatives, they are not worth very much. In other words, they are just window-dressing to try to create in the public arena an image that the Government is trying to do the right thing.

Fourthly, although the Government points to the desirability of government authorities actually having to set targets, the Minister himself is guilty of not setting down a timetable for the implementation of targets. This whole document shows the hypocrisy of the Government. The document concludes by talking about the need to set targets and standards. Yet, the Minister walks away from his own responsibility, from his own recommendations. The document specifically states that the Government will monitor the situation over a period to see whether appropriate targets can be set. So, no specific timetable has been set. The Government is quite hypocritical in what it says in this document.

It is ironic that, although the Government in this paper makes the pretence of improving accountability, its actions suggest the reverse. I shall give the Senate three simple cases. Firstly, the Government, the Executive, is reducing the resources available to the Commonwealth Auditor-General; at the same time it is giving the Auditor-General extra responsibilities. So, the Auditor-General, who is responsible to this Parliament for reporting on efficiency, effectiveness, stewardship, et cetera-what I might refer to as control mechanisms, accountability mechanisms-is having his ability to report accurately diminished by the fact that the Government is reducing the resources of this important officer of the Parliament.

Secondly, I refer to the staff reduction that the Government has imposed on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. In fact, the Government has reduced the resources of that Committee to one-third of the staff placements that existed previously. If the Government were really interested in improving accountability, improving the reporting to the Parliament of significant features relating to departments and statutory authorities, it would reverse that decision. Earlier the Government recognised the importance of the Public Accounts Committee when it heaped additional responsibilities on it. At the same time it has sought to diminish the worth of that Committee by taking away its staff resources, to the extent that it now has only one-third of those which previously were available. Yet, that Committee is expected to perform the same work.

Thirdly, the Government is failing to maintain adequate internal audit resources within the various departments. The Government gives the impression that the recommendations and suggestions in this paper are quite new. I wish to quote from a Public Accounts Committee report of 21 October 1982. That report indicates the ongoing nature of that Committee's work and the fact that the previous Liberal Government has made many advances in this area for which the present Labor Government is now claiming credit. That report of the Public Accounts Committee reads;

The increased need for accountability of the public service is evident from such legislative innovations as the Freedom of Information Act, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, and other means of protecting the rights of the public and making the administration of government policy more accountable. Parliament has also recognised this new level of responsibility by calling for senior public servants to give an account of their management of public policy before committees of the Parliament.

By means of the document presented today the Government has put into writing its pretence of how much it is doing, when in fact its words are empty. In fact, the Government has plagiarised reports of other committees. A careful reading of this document reveals that lines or parts of lines have been lifted from other committee reports. Yet, no acknowledgment is made of the contribution that those committees have made in that regard.

I welcome the Government's commitment to move towards the setting of targets. For some time I have been engaged in a personal crusade to get the Government to do that. Few modern companies that are operating successfully in the private sector do not have specific performance targets that they must meet each year. The Government is very general in what it says. It says that investment return targets are desirable. It must be a little more specific than that. The Government is very good at setting out its objectives and in stating what is required, but it is very short on ensuring that specific performance targets are set each year by each of these bodies. Although it has indicated the desirability of moving and its intention to move in this area, it lacks the determination to set down a timetable for itself to ensure that each of these statutory authorities conforms with that recommendation.
