INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, two senators submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64, namely, Senator Powell proposing a matter of urgency and Senator Messner proposing a matter of public importance. To decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate, the President determined the matter by ballot. In accordance with the result of that ballot, I now read Senator Powell's letter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The necessity for Australians to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land and, because most approaches to the crucial issue of land degradation in the past have been limited and largely unsuccessful, the need for the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most valuable resources, the soil'.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The necessity for Australians to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land and, because most approaches to the crucial issue of land degradation in the past have been limited and largely unsuccessful, the need for the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most valuable resources, the soil.
If Dorothea Mackellar were to be writing her famous poem My Country now rather than earlier this century, she might have written:
I love a sunburnt country,
A land of sweeping plains,
Of rugged mountain ranges,
And erosion when it rains.

For once the Senate is debating an urgency motion which is indeed urgent. In March this year the Sydney Morning Herald carried a substantial article written by Bob Beale, its science reporter. He noted that scientists and environmentalists are sounding alarm bells at the many signs of physical stress and genetic depletion apparent in those sweeping plains and rugged mountain ranges so praised by Dorothea Mackellar in My Country.

The Australian Democrats have brought on this matter of urgency today confident of the support of the whole chamber. Land degradation in all its forms demands that governments give urgent attention to initiating comprehensive and long term strategies to remedy the massive problem facing Australia now and in the future. We want to place before the Australian people our belief in the necessity for all Australians to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land.

Shortly after the recent Federal election, two senior Federal parliamentarians from the majority parties, Senator Graham Richardson, Minister for the Environment and the Arts, and Senator Chris Puplick, shadow Minister for the Environment, both publicly stated their belief that soil degradation is the most important environmental issue facing Australia. When I read these statements in the Press I wrote to both honourable senators offering the support of the Australian Democrats for their views. I would like to quote extracts from their replies. The Minister, Senator Richardson, said:

I consider land degradation, including soil erosion, soil structure decline and dry land and irrigation salinity as a long term and serious environmental problem affecting a large proportion of the Australian continent. The problems are to a large extent the result of a variety of inappropriate land management practices, including overstocking, excessive vegetation clearing, overcultivation and unsuitable irrigation techniques. I will be seeking early discussions with Mr Kerin regarding the situation and possible means of collaboration between our portfolios to strengthen current activities and initiate new activities to address the problem.
I welcomed that response from the Minister. The shadow Minister, Senator Puplick, said:

Thank you for your note regarding my reported comments on soil land degradation and related matters such as water quality issues. I shall look forward to trying to develop a genuinely tripartisan or multipartisan approach to this vital question in the years ahead, although we have very little time left to get to grips with such a vital issue.

The Democrats agree with that. Hence this urgency motion. The sentiments in these letters were heartening. They reflect a long line of similar concerns expressed within the Parliament over many decades. I would like to quote from a few of the many statements by members of all parties. In 1937, Labor Prime Minister Scullin said:
It will be nothing short of a crime if we continue to permit the destruction of forests and the erosion of the soil.

Later, Robert Menzies, the then Attorney-General and later to be a long term Prime Minister of this country, agreed that soil conservation was `of great national importance and will not be overlooked'. More recently, in a debate on the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill in 1985, pertinent statements were made by members of all parties, many of whom are still sitting members. Mr Chynoweth, the honourable member for Dunkley in Victoria, said:

Since the arrival of the First Fleet the soils of Australia have been dramatically changed. We have removed vast numbers of trees. We have placed upon them animals which are not native to our country. This has altered the whole ecosystem. The share of rainfall that runs off the land swells the stream flow which in turn increases soil loss. It also decreases evaporation which alters the area's hydrological cycle. It can also lead to the desertification of areas which are on the fringes of deserts. This is happening now in Australia.
Mr Kerin, now the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in that same debate said:
Erosion, salinity and tree decline are afflicting over half of all agricultural land and poisoning waterways in this country.
Senator Brownhill, of the National Party of Australia, said:

A collaborative soil conservation study of 1975-77 showed that 52 per cent of the land in use in Australia needs some form of treatment for land or vegetation degradation. This area amounts to more than one-third of the entire land mass of Australia, a rather horrific figure to think of.
Senator Colin Mason, a recently retired Australian Democrat senator, said:

Dr Brian Roberts estimates that the top soil on the Darling Downs is disappearing at the rate of one centimetre a year. At this rate the Darling Downs will be useless for most sorts of crop production within 30 years.
Mr Hawker, the Liberal member for Wannon in Victoria, said:

The Standing Committee on Soil Conservation carried out a study in 1969 and 1970 which concluded that at the then current rates of soil conservation expenditure it would take about 100 years to achieve control of soil erosion in the non-arid areas of Australia even if no further soil erosion problems arose. The estimated cost of works at that time was $350m.
Mr Andrew, the Liberal member for Wakefield in South Australia, said:
Everyone agrees that soil conservation is essential, that it is, in fact, basic to society's survival.

While the problem of land degradation in all its manifestations is serious for Australia, we should also consider it in the world perspective. I have taken some figures from an excellent video called The State of the Planet which was filmed in Britain in the early 1980s and in which representatives from many countries placed before the governments of the world their concerns about continuing ecological degradation. The land surface of the planet covers some 135 million square kilometres but, of this total land area, not available for agricultural production is 6 per cent because it is frozen, 10 per cent because it is too wet, 22 per cent because there is hardly any soil, 23 per cent which is too salty and 28 per cent which is too dry. Therefore, there remains 11 per cent designated as prime agricultural land.

During the 1970s we exacerbated the problem. We have built and paved over 27,000 square miles of agricultural land-an area twice the size of Holland. By the year 2000 we will probably lose twice that area again. It is not only development and urbanisation which reduce the extent of the world's prime agricultural land. Erosion, desertification, salinity, the clearing of native vegetation, uncontrolled grazing and overgrazing of stock, damaging farming practices, to mention just a few, all contribute to the loss of soil-our prime agricultural resource. It takes 100 to 400 years to build 10 millimetres of top soil and 3,000 to 12,000 years to build enough soil to make the land productive. It is time that governments and the people recognised that soil is, in essence, a non-renewable resource.

Returning to the situation in Australia, let us consider the enormity of the problem, a problem which, as I said, has been recognised across party lines for decades. In Western Australia we are losing our soil at the rate of an area the size of Rottnest Island every four weeks from salinity alone. Wind erosion causes even greater losses. Again in Western Australia, it is reported in a joint Australian Government-United Nations environment program document entitled `Dry Lands Dilemma: A solution to the Problem' that losses in agricultural profits caused by land degradation amount to $94m a year. In the same report it is demonstrated that in South Australia salinity has been responsible for annual losses of $40m a year and, in Victoria, $15m. In July of this year a New South Wales Soil Conservation Service conference was told that farmers in the Murray-Darling Basin, an area that covers 80 per cent of the State, faced losses of $110m this year and huge future losses if land degradation continued. In the words of the Acting Commissioner, Mr Warren Watkins:
The present loss of soil to erosion borders on a national tragedy.

Soil conservation experts say that, if this problem is not countered by educating farmers, the food bowl could well become the dust bowl, with disastrous consequences for farms. In Victoria a report by Julian Cribb in May of this year stated:

In fewer than 40 years, if remedial measures are not taken, 400,000 hectares of Victoria's richest farmlands will be a blasted moonscape of salty desolation. The first farms in the fertile Goulburn Valley have already been rendered lifeless by rising saline ground water.

As one who has lived in that region for many years, I have seen the demoralisation that can occur when people are involved in an industry which suffers this kind of degradation. Just this week a report from the Upper Yarra Valley and Dandenong Ranges Authority and the Board of Works in Victoria stated that the banks of the Upper Yarra River are so seriously eroded in some sections that valuable farmlands could be washed away. The report states that adjacent land has been so seriously degraded that more than 90 per cent of the natural vegetation cover has been removed from privately owned areas of the catchment. The Upper Yarra Valley is an area of economic and environmental significance for Victoria, providing living space for 120,000 people and water for industrial, agricultural and human consumption for 2.5 million people who live in Melbourne.

There is a litany of statistics and warnings. A recent article in the Times on Sunday by Geoff Strong outlines a great many more of them. For every tonne of wheat produced the hidden price can be between three and 16 tonnes of topsoil. The Dean of Applied Science at the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education warns that if land degradation continues at its present rate Australia will face a diminishing agricultural yield leading to enormous socio-economic problems. The trend towards bigger, more mechanised farms has made the problem worse.

In the time I have today-which, of course, is 20 minutes maximum-I must point out that what I am saying is not even half of the story. The statistics, the studies and the reports are all too numerous to quote in that sort of time. So, in the face of all of the concern which has been expressed by the range of political parties and by experts in the field, the question is: What are we doing to remedy these problems? There are, of course, many projects-government projects, community projects and farm based projects. For example, there is the national soil conservation program, which is under the purview of the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy. There is the national tree program, Greening Australia, under the Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. There are various State government soil conservation projects and there are local community projects, and in particular there is the development at local level of soil conservation districts.

However, there are problems. The Federal Government's 1986-87 Budget allocation to the national soil conservation program was around $5.5m, roughly the same as it gave for landscaping the new Parliament House so near to here. In fact, looking at the figures for the funding of the national soil conservation program in the time that it has been operating since 1983, the average is just under $4m per annum. The former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, despite having named soil conservation as Australia's most pressing environmental problem just prior to the 1983 Federal election, had just a few months before axed funds for the national soil conservation program.

What can be done? What is needed? I alluded earlier to the Australian Democrats' belief that the Australian people need to be made more aware of the seriousness and urgency of the problem. We need a new land ethic, one based on care and respect for the land, one that encourages in people an enduring and strongly held ethical commitment to soil stewardship by doing the right thing for soil conservation. This was the message which was given in July of this year by the Assistant Secretary of Natural Resources and Environment of the United States Department of Agriculture, one that I think Australians should listen to. Such a land ethic must also be incorporated in appropriate legislation, and that is where government comes in. We must face the fact that some of our approaches to soil conservation have not been appropriate. I refer to a paper presented last year to the National Environmental Law Association of Australia by John Bradsen of the University of Adelaide's law school. In that paper he sets out what he believes to be inappropriate future approaches to soil conservation and suggests new approaches. He says that `United States and British experience shows that any legislation, State or Federal, which is not obligatory has not been effective. Reliance on common law-for example, where degradation on one property line damages another-has also led to ineffectiveness. There is no evidence to show that private agricultural land has suffered less degradation than leasehold land. Therefore the view that the owners of the land look after it better than any lessees is in fact a fallacy'. I am informed by Mr Bradsen that, as a result of his paper and further work, a report on soil conservation legislation is currently being studied by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy which it is anticipated, and it is hoped by the Australian Democrats, will be released shortly and become part of the future public debate on this matter. We welcome that.

Some of the other suggestions which we would like to make-which need to be addressed if governments and the community are to adopt the best approaches in dealing with this complex problem-include, firstly, the initiation as soon as possible of a comprehensive survey to determine the capability of all land in Australia and the extent to which that capability is currently being exceeded. I quote from the national soil conservation program paper tabled in November 1984 in which the writers of that report said:
Over much of Australia's farming areas land use has long exceeded long-term land capability.

We also need the involvement of the Commonwealth to a far greater extent than at present in co-ordinating and guiding research in the national interest from a position of leadership. I quote Mr Kerin when he said in the 1985 debate:
It has long been a belief of mine that the Commonwealth has an important role to play in actively encouraging and co-ordinating the conservation of our land resources.

I remind Mr Kerin of his comment then. We also need the development in this leadership role by the Commonwealth of uniform national standards to be used as a model for future State and Federal legislation. We urgently need the establishment by the Commonwealth of a national soil conservation databank to collect the land resource information which has already been procured within the States and through other sources so that it can be consolidated into a national land inventory. The Federal Government must give urgent consideration to investigating the feasibility of establishing conservation reserves, a scheme contained in the 1985 United States Food and Security Act, which is designed to assist farmers in implementing ecological farm management practices in order to reduce soil erosion.

The Australian Democrats take the view that governments, both State and Federal, must promote, encourage and support the transition to more sustainable agricultural practices which enhance this most important non-renewable agricultural resource, the soil. We would be very concerned if in this whole debate the view of the agricultural economists were to hold sway. We are conscious that that is a danger, particularly at this time when the economic rationalists seem to hold so much sway in so many of the public debates. The argument outlined in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation goes something like this: Soil conservation should be perceived as a possible means of achieving the underlying policy objective of maximising community welfare rather than an objective in its own right. The Australian Democrats reject that view. We believe that we must come to understand the soil as a non-renewable resource and we must make every possible effort to see that it is conserved and that, for all the best economic reasons, Australia continues to be a major agricultural producer as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish initially to offer an apology for Senator Richardson. Because of unexpected delays in the Senate business this afternoon he has been obliged to leave. He has presented me with some of his notes which I hope I can do justice to. The typed sections are okay; the parts in Senator Richardson's handwriting are a little more difficult. By way of opening remark, I wish to illustrate the importance that the Government places on this particular issue. We are aware of the awesome statistics that are available, particularly in respect of erosion by wind and water. Such erosion will remove during the next 12 months 20 billion tonnes of soil from fertile land throughout the world. We will also see 25 million hectares degraded through flooding, salinity or structural degradation worldwide. Again, one could gather some idea of the significance of this issue by realising that if we lose one millimetre of dirt over a one-hectare area that means losing 10 tonnes of topsoil. So it is a tremendously significant issue and one very close to the hearts of the rural producers of Australia. I believe it is also an issue that all parties in the Parliament can agree is vital to the future of this country. I think we can move some way towards achieving consensus on some of the measures that are required.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers land degradation to be the most serious environmental problem in Australia, as it is also in a number of developing countries. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has gone on the public record as citing soil degradation as Australia's most important environmental issue. Land degradation, including water and wind soil erosion and salting, has been identified as a long term and potentially most serious problem which, in 1977, affected an estimated 51 per cent of land currently in rural use. The problem, and the costs of controlling it, have increased since the 1977 Commonwealth-State collaborative soil conservation study. The problems are the result of a variety of inappropriate land management practices, including overstocking, excessive vegetation clearance, overcultivation and unsuitable irrigation techniques. At the government level, States and Territories are primarily responsible for implementing measures to achieve soil conservation. The Commonwealth contributes by tackling various aspects of the problem within its constitutional powers. As we are aware, these are somewhat controversial at times.

At the outset I need to make the point that solving our land degradation problems does not lie completely with governments. I fully endorse Senator Powell's call for the adoption of the land use ethic, as the main responsibility lies here with individual landholders. I understand that in recent years there has been a marked increase in farmer awareness and sensitivity to land degradation, and the farming community as a whole is now attempting to do a lot more to combat soil erosion within the constraints posed by their economic circumstances. The role for governments here is to provide support for the rural community through fostering new technology and soil conservation techniques, through research, advisory services and appropriate fiscal support. The Government also has an important role in fostering general public awareness of the problem and in fostering the adoption of a land use ethic.

As I have said, the Government agrees that land degradation is a most serious environmental problem and it has initiated a number of appropriate measures. I will deal briefly with these. Firstly, in 1984 the Government endorsed the national conservation strategy for Australia. The strategy identifies principles and priority national actions to be taken in addressing environmental problems, including soil degradation. It has provided an umbrella framework for the development of the national soil conservation strategy and the national forest strategy for Australia, prepared by the Australian Forestry Council. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his recent election policy statement, indicated that the Government would further develop environmental protection and understanding within the framework of this strategy.

In 1983 the Government also initiated the national soil conservation program. The Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 provides a statutory basis for Commonwealth co-operation with the States in the expansion of soil conservation activities. The objectives of the national soil conservation program are: that all lands in Australia are to be used within their capability; land use and management decisions must be based on a catchment-regional land planning concept; all land users and levels of government must meet their respective responsibilities in achieving soil conservation; effective co-operation and co-ordination must occur between all sectors of the community, disciplines and agencies involved in the use and management of land and water resources; and the whole community must accept a land conservation ethic. An amount of $6m has been allocated to the program in the 1987-88 Budget. This is a 9 per cent increase in the previous year's allocations, and brings the total funding since 1983 to $21m.

The aim of the national tree program, for which the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is responsible, is to conserve and establish trees and associated vegetation for the community and for private benefit throughout Australia. The key objectives are: to increase selectively tree cover in rural areas; to promote co-ordinated action by individuals, governments and the community generally to conserve, plant and regenerate trees; and to develop public awareness of the value of our trees. Under this program the Commonwealth provides funds for demonstration projects and a national information program. The national tree program plays an important role in combating land degradation.

I would like to cite a few examples of some of the more interesting projects now being done under the national tree planting program. We have a national information program in conjunction with the States and the Territories and many non-government organisations. We have established over 1,000 projects throughout Australia, which demonstrate the benefits and the uses of trees. The Government has established a national tree database, called Tredat, to monitor progress with tree projects throughout Australia. This has been done in collaboration with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Queensland Department of Forestry. The Government has provided support for the Greening Australia project, which is a non-government organisation providing a focus for the activities of the numerous community tree groups. A major focus of the national tree program is encouragement for local co-ordinated projects. Examples of such projects include Project Branchout in northern Victoria, where landholders and community groups have undertaken major tree planting on farms and public reserves in co-operation with State agencies and local government. Over the past few years several hundred thousand trees have been established using voluntary labour and the various employment creation programs. This type of co-ordinated project has been repeated in many regions, including the Yass River Valley, the Riverina and the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, Fassifern and Lockyer Valleys in Queensland, the midlands of Tasmania and Lake Toolibin in Western Australia. Other major project initiatives supported through the national tree program, and involving local communities, include the provision of shade, fruit and nut trees at Aboriginal outstations in central Australia, the rehabilitation of abandoned mining areas in north-east Tasmania and the establishment of green belts to suppress lead contaminated dust at Port Pirie.

In 1983 the Government removed full tax deductibility for land clearing costs. This provision had previously encouraged the removal of vegetation cover. Vegetation loss is an important factor in contributing to land degradation. The Government has also introduced important taxation provisions for the control of land degradation. Expenditures for the control of land degradation are subject to immediate tax write-off, and this applies to expenditure of a capital nature incurred in operations directed at combating land degradation. The Government is also working with the States in a number of significant areas. The Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments agreed in 1985 to establish the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council to enable those States to develop a co-operative approach to the better management of the basin. The goals of the Council include:
Control of existing land degradation, the prevention of further land degradation, and where possible the rehabilitation of land resources, to ensure the sustainable utilisation of these resources.

Land degradation has imposed considerable costs in the basin. The estimated value of the annual yield losses due to land degradation is about $215m. There are other costs. For example, about 45,000 hectares of agricultural land has been lost to dry land salinity in Victoria. To overcome the degradation of resources in the basin, the Council made an historic agreement to establish the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. In addition to the agreement to establish the Commission, the Council is now drawing up strategies for the management of the basin, which take into account environmental matters such as planning, water resources, agriculture, soil conservation, recreation and tourism. A major benchmark study, entitled `Murray-Darling Basin Environmental Resources Study' has been completed.

The Commonwealth works closely with the States and Territories through the Australian Soil Conservation Council. The Commonwealth is represented on the Council by the Minister for Resources, Mr Peter Morris. The Council and its supporting officials' committees have been involved in some important activities relative to this debate. The Council is now preparing a draft national soil conservation strategy. The purpose of the strategy is to provide nationally agreed policies and priority actions for the prevention and control of land degradation. The draft strategy is expected to be released soon for public comment. One of the priority actions is a promotional campaign on a land conservation ethic. Through the Council mechanism, a proposal is now being prepared for a survey of community awareness on soil conservation.

In 1985, the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment tabled its report on land use policy in Australia. One of the recommendations the Committee made was that the Australian Environment Council (AEC) establish a standing committee on land use to draft a national land use policy statement. In a decision earlier this year on the Senate Committee report, the Government decided that the relevant Ministers would seek to establish, through the AEC, the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) and the Planning Ministers Conference, a working group, to develop co-operative arrangements between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory Government with respect to rural and urban land use strategies and policies.

The Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) recently wrote to the Premiers and the Chief Minister on this matter. The Minister will be taking the matter forward at meetings of the AEC and CONCOM next week. The Government looks forward to the co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory on this most important matter. While I hope we now have some degree of bipartisan support in this place on the importance of soil degradation and measures required, I should contrast the activity of the Hawke Labor Government on land degradation with that of the previous Fraser Government. We are approaching land degradation on a range of fronts. In contrast, the Lynch razor gang, under the Fraser Government, abolished the existing soil conservation program. However, I am glad that all parties now recognise the importance of this issue.

The Government will be progressing on a number of fronts. However, there can be no doubt that governments can do more, specifically in a number of areas; firstly, in terms of public awareness in fostering a land ethic; secondly, in terms of advisory services and research; thirdly, possible fiscal measures; and, fourthly, targeting particular high priority areas such as the Murray-Darling basin. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the Minister will be holding discussions in the near future with his colleagues to see what further initiatives the Government can take in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to participate in this most important urgency debate that calls on the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most precious resources, the soil. I venture, however, to suggest that the soil is not one of Australia's most valuable resources; it is the most valuable resource. It may be trite to point out that without soil we would not have our crops or livestock industries, we could not provide food for the Australian population and, increasingly, people throughout the world, we would not enjoy the standard of living we have today and we would have little to sell the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a unique continent in that we are regarded as an agricultural nation when our soils generally are shallow, unstable and of low fertility. Only 10 per cent of our land could be regarded as deep, arable soil. Yet, agriculture extends over two thirds of our total land mass. Obviously, this is the nub of the problem. By necessity, over 200 years successive generations have ploughed, cropped, grazed and generally gambled with much of our country to produce food for our population and the population of the world. On the eve of 200 years of settlement, we are faced with a massive problem. Whole regions of land which were once able to support cropping and grazing and were productive are no longer available for us or future generations to use. They are gone. The soil structure has either broken down so irretrievably that there is a desert, or it has become so saline that nothing will grow. This has happened over 200 years- and it is still happening. If this continues, we will have nothing to leave our children and grandchildren.

Sadly, the problem is not just restricted to Australia. Across the world, by the end of the century, a massive 35 per cent of once-productive farm land will have been turned into dessert. This is not a natural phenomenon. It is man made and we all stand condemned for it. The problem is not one of which we are unaware. An assessment of soil conservation needs was undertaken some 10 years ago between 1975 and 1977 in a collaborative study between the States and the Commonwealth. I know that Senator Powell referred to this in her speech. That assessment showed that 52 per cent of the land in rural use in Australia needs some form of treatment for land or vegetation degradation. This degraded area amounts to more than one-third of the entire land mass. Over 5 million square kilometres are used for agricultural and pastoral purposes. Of this total area in use, over 23 per cent, or 1.8 million square kilometres, needs treatment with land management practices only, while 29 per cent, or 1.48 million square kilometres, needs conservation work of various kinds, almost invariably in conjunction with appropriate management practices.

Arid zones, where rainfall is too low or two unreliable to support regular dryland cropping, exist over 70 per cent of Australia and the majority of that Land is used for grazing. Sadly, degradation has occurred on 55 per cent of that arid zone. Degradation covers an area some 27 times the size of Tasmania-and I know we all laugh occasionally at Tasmania. While most of the degradation is loss of vegetation, increasingly it also involves soil erosion and salinity. The same thing is occurring in the non-arid and extensive cropping zones. In the non-arid zone, where grazing is undertaken, a third of the land needs attention to prevent further degradation.

To highlight how this problem also affects the city dweller, it is important to point out that the non-arid grazing land category includes the catchment areas and water supplies of many eastern cities and towns. It also includes land that was once sown with crops, but is now so badly affected by salinity that only limited grazing can occur. The story is repeated in the cropping areas, of which one-third need attention. The problem, of course, is not just soil erosion but also salinity. Salinity problems are occurring in south-western Western Australia. I am quite sure that the problems in this most productive area will be raised later in this debate. Salinity problems are also occurring in some of the irrigation areas in South Australia, Victoria and southern New South Wales. We are also faced with dry land salting problems.

We are faced with a problem of massive proportions-a problem that has been known about for some time. Yet, successive governments, State and Federal, have done little to acknowledge the seriousness of it. As a recent article in the National Farmer, written by Bruce Mills, stated:

Vast areas of Australia's pastoral lands are fast being engulfed by desert, huge areas in the Murray-Darling River basin are turning to salted wastelands while millions upon millions of tonnes of topsoil are being eroded off our best farmlands each year.

It's all been said before in various forms; scientists have trotted out statistics and warnings; politicians have nodded and agreed that something must be done and plenty of inter-governmental committees and task forces have been set up to look into possible solutions.

One such committee set up by the previous coalition Government was the national conservation strategy task force, which held a national seminar in 1981 to look at land degradation and other conservation matters. That was a Liberal-National Party initiative on soil conservation. That body has since published a national conservation strategy for Australia. The paper included, among other recommendations, the need to increase awareness of the problem and to provide incentives-that this Government does not give-to land users, including encouragement of tree planting, soil conservation measures and strengthening of farm advisory services and extension services.

One would expect that over the past four years, and particularly now that such an environmental zealot as Senator Richardson is at the helm-unfortunately he could not be here this afternoon-this Government would really have gone to town on the problems of soil conservation. But this is not the case. If we turn to this year's Budget Papers we see that a mere three lines on such an important issue are devoted to soil conservation-three lines out of literally hundreds of lines. The three lines read:

$6.0m (up $0.6m) is provided for the National Soil Conservation program which provides financial assistance primarily to the States for soil conservation and related research and extension activities.

How pathetic that is. So to combat this national crisis the Federal Government has provided a pathetic $6m. To put that in perspective, it is only $1m more than the $5m being spent on landscaping the new Parliament House. In other words, beautifying a few hectares on top of the hill will cost almost as much as the entire soil conservation budget for Australia. As I said, how pathetic and completely out of balance that is. Where are this Government's priorities on soil conservation? As the National Farmer summed it up, it really is a joke. If the matter were not so serious I presume that it would be a joke.

The previous year's budget was no better. In 1985-86 the Federal Labor Government gave $5.5m; the previous year the Government started the national soil conservation program with $4.5m but that same year the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown-Senator Richardson's boss in the other place-gave away $7.5m of taxpayers' money to Sydney's Parramatta sports club for a new rugby league stadium. In the same year the Government gave Sydney's new Maritime Museum $18m, three times more than was allocated to soil conservation.

The various States are doing little better. It is unlikely that the combined State contribution would be more than $100m. Yet the Australian Agricultural Council has estimated the cost of carrying out what it calls essential soil degradation control at $2.5 billion. So, in round figures, the Federal Government's allocation was approximately 1/450th of that required for essential works, to say nothing of the less critical works.

Dr Geoffrey Beckmann, recently retired from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation after many years spent studying the engineering structure of landscapes, says that the attitude of the Federal Government to soil conservation is a disgrace, and how correct he is. He has predicted serious consequences for the nation unless there is a complete revamping of policies and a massive injection of funds for conservation works. He stated:
We are sitting on the edge of a disaster.

If we do not watch what is happening, the life blood of the soil will be washed away to the sea as a result of the inaction of this Government. In 1975 the total cost of essential works was estimated at $675m or 1.1 per cent of our gross domestic product. Estimates then suggested that half of Australia's land was in need of work to halt water and wind erosion if it were to remain productive. Since then literally millions of tonnes of soil have been blown away or washed out to sea to be lost forever by this country.

The coalition Government acknowledged the importance of encouraging farmers to care for their soil and it allowed full write-off in the year of expenditure for on-farm water and soil conservation measures. We introduced a $640m bicentennial water resources program which has since been abolished to the discredit of this Government. However, as I said earlier, I do not believe that any government has done enough. I am very interested, and have been vitally interested for a long time having started competitions in different places, on the subject of soil conservation.

Before I wind up my remarks, I compliment the Soil Conservation Service of New South Wales and the job it is doing with the meagre funds that it receives. In particular I refer to Mr Bob Juno, the new Commissioner of the Soil Conservation Service of New South Wales. I have raised the issue of soil conservation numerous times in this place. Earlier this session I raised it in a notice of motion; I raised it again in an Estimates committee hearing and an officer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy suggested that both Federal and State governments were not spending sufficient funds on it. Of even greater concern was advice that there had been no update on the 1977 studies to which I referred earlier in my speech. In other words. there has been no update on that work and with only three lines devoted to the matter in the Budget, I guess we will not get much more from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or this Government.

This Government can wax lyrical about rainforests; the Minister can make numerous trips to rainforest areas in Queensland; he can talk warmly of his conversion to greenieism but on the subject of soil conservation he is pathetically silent. I do not say that rainforests are not important; they are. However, soil is being neglected; it is being ignored by this Government. A video entitled Wheat Today: What Tomorrow? has just been released and I recommend to Senator Richardson that he view it soon so that he can do something about the problem.

The Australian Bicentennial Authority was not going to recognise soil conservation in our bicentennial year but I am happy to say that it will now do something in conjunction with the New South Wales Farmers Association, the Soil Conservation Service of New South Wales and the State Department of Agriculture. I am pleased that this matter has been brought to the attention of the Senate but I must confess that it seems a little ironic, perhaps even hypocritical, for the Australian Democrats to be expressing concern at the loss of productive land. For it is the Australian Democrats who, if they had their way, would have all farmers arrested and all their land taken from them and locked away as a museum. It is the same Australian Democrats who oppose intensive animal production but can provide no alternatives for feeding, at an affordable price, our population. It is the same Australian Democrats who want an extension of World Heritage listing areas to other parts of Australia which, no doubt, will threaten present agricultural production. However, their spokesperson on primary industry matters, Senator Powell, does have an interest in, and knowledge of, agriculture. I believe that she is genuinely concerned, as I am, at the inaction of this Government on issues such as soil conservation, erosion, salinity and desertification. The Labor Government stands condemned for its inertia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to support Senator Powell's urgency motion. From previous remarks from both sides of the chamber it appears that we agree on this matter of urgency, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for Australians to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land and, because most approaches to the crucial issue of land degradation in the past have been limited and largely unsuccessful, the need for the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most valuable resources, the soil.

I intend primarily to address the situation in my State of Western Australia, and I do this for two reasons: firstly, because Western Australia, because of its size, contains almost half of the land area and therefore almost half of the soil of Australia and, secondly, as a State which stretches from the tropical north of the continent down to the temperate south, Western Australia illustrates the full range of climatic and soil types found in Australia and also the full range of soil problems and degradations of the soil which Senator Powell's motion addresses.

I must say in answer to Senator Brownhill that this motion is in full accord with the policy of the Australian Democrats. I draw to the attention of the Senate a report entitled Western Australian Environmental Review 1986 which was published in September 1987. This report was written by two people-R. G. Chittleborough and F. M. Keating. The explanation of the publishing date being one year after the date of the completion of the report is in the notes on the unauthorised publication. It states:

The following review was originally written for the Department of Conservation and Environment, in December 1986. It was, however, never published for general public consumption-due in part perhaps to the sensitivity of some of the observations made. This situation played a substantial part in the subsequent resignation from the department of the principal author, Dr Grahame Chittleborough.

The review has great value in providing an understanding of the current West Australian natural environment, and the nature and magnitude of the problems facing it. The review should be public property.
Consequently, a group of concerned citizens has decided to reproduce the report, on behalf of the authors, as a public service.

A number of people were stunned when the Western Australian Government put out a very glossy, short report which did not go into the details that are in this report. The authors of this report were very pleased to have access to the full report as published. I recommend the report to the Senate because, although it deals with the situation in Western Australia, everything listed is pertinent to the whole of Australia.

In considering soil we have to be aware that we are dealing with one of the essential life support elements of human life. If we do not preserve and protect our soils, we will certainly starve. If we in this generation are not to starve, then our children or grandchildren will be placed in extreme jeopardy because large areas of the world are in danger of losing the capacity to be self-sufficient in food production. In Australia we already export an enormous amount of food to other countries, and it is likely that in future with the burgeoning of world population we will be called upon to export even more to feed people across the seas. But we will not be able to respond to this call if we do not preserve our own soils.

We also have to be aware in this debate that, as with most forms of environmental damage, soil degradation, once it has occurred, can be either impossible or extremely difficult to remedy and can cause enormous problems lasting for generations, if not for centuries. It is one of the many areas in which prevention is enormously preferable to cure after the damage has been done. That is the state in which we now find ourselves to a great extent-we must now attempt to start to cure the damage that has already been done. We have to be aware, and we in Western Australia must be particularly aware, that we live in a desert. The climate over much of our State is essentially a desert type climate. In deserts, soils and vegetation are extraordinarily vulnerable. Part of our problem is that most of the European peoples who came here were used to European type climates and agricultures and were unaware of the fragility of the soil in this desert environment. So they treated the environment and the soil here as they had that in Europe. They also introduced alien agricultural forms to this continent.

We also need to be aware that agriculture and our trading patterns involve us in progressively removing the fertility of our soils. In small, subsistence based sustainable agricultural communities just about everything comes from the soil and everything is returned to the soil in one way or another. So, as has been mentioned by other speakers, agriculture is a cyclical activity. But large scale Western agriculture robs the soil of its fertility and leads to steady degradation. Every shipload of wheat and beef that leaves Australia is a shipload of Australian soil fertility which is leaving this country for ever and is lost to future generations. It is true that some of this fertility can be restored by the use of fertilisers imported from overseas, but fertilisers themselves have their own problems. The danger is that greater and greater amounts of them are needed to sustain the yields that we have from our agriculture.

It is already apparent in Western Australia that considerable areas of land which have been cleared for agricultural use for cereal crops will be going out of production because crops are no longer economic. The ultimate possible disaster is full scale desertification. We know from history that the northern part of the continent of Africa and other areas around the Mediterranean until relatively recent times were fertile areas. We have all read in the Bible about the cedars of Lebanon. Those wooded areas are no longer there; those trees were cut down. I was surprised to discover that a lot of those wooded areas were cut down comparatively recently, in fact after the steam engine was invented, to feed those machines. When people let loose their goats to feed on the vegetation that was left after the trees had been cut down the final degradation and desertification in those areas occurred.

We know that the Sahara Desert is creeping inexorably southwards and that one of the factors contributing to that situation is the impact of human activity. We have all seen on our television screens the awful pictures of what is happening in areas of Africa such as Ethiopia because the land there has been degraded to such an extent. We all have some understanding of what the possibilities of desertification can mean to us here in Australia.

In attempts to maintain profitability, farmers in Western Australia have been advised to consolidate their holdings and to adopt more mechanised techniques, but this is not saving the farmers in Western Australia. A number of them have already gone bankrupt or are on the brink of bankruptcy, rural populations are declining and small businesses in country towns are being affected. It appears that the only solution to aid the situation is that advocated by Barrie Oldfield. Many of us were able to see Barrie Oldfield's video Wheat Today: What Tomorrow?. In that video Barrie Oldfield described what can be done to save the situation. It is supreme irony that the Aboriginal people who occupied Australia for 40,000 years before European people came here had a much deeper wisdom about the land and its soils. It is an irony that we are about to celebrate 200 years of the impact of a new society on Australia and the Australian environment. The Aboriginal people have been here at least 200 times the number of years that our society has been here, yet we have probably done at least 2,000 times the amount of damage to the soil in Australia.

In Western Australia wind erosion is one of the major threats to our soils. It is strongly associated with introduced methods of practising agriculture which involves the clearing of vast areas of native vegetation and the cultivation of alien and purely seasonal species, which then leave the soil exposed to the wind. This was described very well in Barrie Oldfield's video. He also described very well how water erosion is a major threat to our soils. This is a particular danger in the northern, summer rainfall region, but it is also true that where one gets sudden downpours-and this was illustrated very well on the video-soil that has been cleared cannot absorb the rainfall, and so the rain simply runs off, taking a lot of the soil with it. Another problem is the compaction of soils caused by the continual use of very heavy agricultural machinery. The result of this is that most of the rain that does fall runs over the surface instead of penetrating it.

There is also the salinity problem, salt in the soil, which means that it is extremely difficult if not impossible to grow crops in the soil. I would like to give some of the costs involved because costs are significant. The annual loss to wind erosion is estimated at $38m; water erosion, $19m; and salinity, $26m. Only about 30 per cent of 17 million hectares of land in Western Australia cleared for agriculture can now be regarded as stable. The remaining 70 per cent is affected by some form of soil degradation. I quote from page 3 of the report Western Australian Environmental Review 1986:

Overall, Western Australia has accumulated an environmental debt which will have to be met by the community if we are to restore sustainability. Those involved in using or managing the environment, whether public or private, are generally aware of the causes of the problems. However, until community awareness recognises the need for further remedial action only the symptoms can be addressed.

There is much scope for increased involvement of the community in planning a sustainable future, and for strengthening an environmental ethic by which individuals recognise their responsibility for stewardship of our environment; an ethic which sees conservation and development as mutually dependent activities within the system of which we are a part.
I commend Senator Powell's urgency motion to the Senate and I hope that on this occasion all parties here will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of urgency that has been brought on by the Australian Democrats. Clearly, they have a great concern for the preservation of our soil. They are to be praised for that. Indeed, it is good to see that they are following a trend started by this Government. I shall give some evidence of that. First of all, I refer to the evidence in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment which, when the report was prepared, was chaired by Senator Gerry Jones, a very eminent senator from Queensland. In that report he discussed the need for soil preservation and, with other members of the Committee, he commented on the need to pay attention to that area. The Government has done just that. In 1985 the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act was passed. The second reading speech was given in the House of Representatives by Mr Kerin, the then Minister for Primary Industry, who is now the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He is a man who has devoted much time and attention to the question of soil conservation. SPEECH.PARA: Before concluding this speech, I would like to emphasise the Commonwealth's commitment to soil conservation and the place of this Bill within that overall commitment. Historically, the Commonwealth Government's involvement in soil conservation has been on an in and out basis. The previous Government-
I am sure that Mr Kerin said this with some sadness-
opted out of soil conservation completely so that at the time the present Government took office there was no involvement at all.

The Minister, when he introduced that Bill, was able to illustrate this Government's commitment to soil conservation. He was able to say that when the Hawke Labor Government came in it faced a situation in which the previous coalition Government had opted out of soil conservation completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why more and more people in the country are voting for us.
—That is right. Mr Kerin went on:

SPEECH.PARA: This Government turned around that disastrous decision and established the national soil conservation program. The national soil conservation program, as I have explained, has the overall aim of ensuring that the use of our land resources takes place on a sustainable basis.
A little later he said-again no doubt with some regret:

The previous Government justified its dilatory attitude to soil conservation on the grounds that because the direct constitutional responsibility for land use rests with the States, the Commonwealth need not become involved. However, it is now obvious that the magnitude of the land degradation problem is such that a national perspective must be obtained with the Federal Government providing a means of co-ordinating this perspective, as well as making its own direct contribution to soil conservation.

So the Government welcomes the Democrats following the trend that it has started. We do not doubt they will support the Government in its determined efforts in the future. We thank Senator Powell for her urgency motion. By way of illustration of what the Government is doing in this whole area of soil conservation and water conservation, in the House of Representatives on this very day a Bill has been introduced-the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987-which deals with the question of the waters of the River Murray basin. Item 4 of the explanatory memorandum to that Bill states:
The new Commission-
which is to be established under the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987-

is to encompass the statutory responsibility provided for under the River Murray Waters Agreement 1982 and to undertake an advisory role to the Council on water, land and environment matters in the Basin not covered in that Agreement. The Commission will replace the River Murray Commission and will comprise two Commissioners from each Government who, between them, will represent water, land and environmental interests.

That is an illustration that has inspired Senator Powell to bring this motion on today. We thank her for it. No doubt she will be supporting the initiative that the Government has taken in this area, illustrated by the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act of 1985 and further by the legislation which is presently before the Parliament-the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987.

I turn now to the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985. A section of that Act talks about the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, which was set up under the Act and which had to make an annual report. It has done so. I have a copy of that report before me now which is dated 1985-1986. The report was prepared by people other than politicians, including people of very great eminence in this field such as Professor John Burton, the Foundation Professor of National Resources, University of New England; Dr Brian Roberts, the Dean of the School of Applied Science, Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education; and others. That report makes it quite clear that the initiatives taken by this Government have started to bite and have started to achieve the sorts of things that Senator Powell and the Democrats talked about here today. Page 3 of that report states:
The broad aim of the National Soil Conservation Program is to develop and implement national policies for the rehabilitation and sustainable utilisation of the nation's soil and land resources.
The program has five major goals:
that all lands in Australia be used within their capability;
that soil conservation activity and land use decisions be based on whole catchment/regional land management planning concepts;
that all land users and levels of government meet their respective responsibilities in achieving soil conservation;
that effective co-operation and co-ordination occur between all sectors of the community, disciplines and agencies involved in the use and management of land and water resources; and
that the whole community adopt a land conservation ethic.

That is what is set out in the report of the Committee which was set up by this Government. From page 14 onwards is a list of the grants made through this Commonwealth Government to various bodies interested in and dedicated to soil conservation. The expenditure set out on page 15, for example, shows the amount spent in each State, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. When I look at this Government's record over the years I note with some pride that it can hold up its head in the light of the achievements it has made in the soil conservation area. The motion before the Senate states:

The necessity for Australia to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land, because most approaches to the crucial issue of land degradation in the past have been limited and largely unsuccessful, the need for the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most valuable resources, the soil.

We have done what this motion urges should be done. We have set up procedures, in contrast to what was done by the last Government. We have set up structures and we have set up approaches to help soil conservation. More importantly, in terms of this motion, we have established a new land use ethic based on care and respect for the land. Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, set out in his second reading speech to the vital Bill I have already referred to, the five matters that appeared in the report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, thus establishing an attitude which should be pursued by all those interested in conservation and soil preservation.

Senator Brownhill implied that this Government is concerned about rainforests but not about soil. The concept must be seen as a whole. Not only is the soil important but also are the rainforests. We have to, as it were, love this country and have respect for it not only in terms of the soil but also in terms of its forests, rivers and mountains-in terms of the whole situation in which we find ourselves. The ecology of the country cannot be isolated as has been attempted. The whole issue has to be looked at as a unit. That is what this Government has done. Again and again we have mentioned in this chamber the Franklin Dam which this Government preserved, the forests which we are attempting to preserve at present and our efforts in protecting the environment. That helps to establish this ethic; it helps to make people conscious of the need to preserve a very fragile environment. I can only agree with that and point out what the Government has done.

In conclusion, I might list again some of the things this Government has done since it has come to power. It has established the national soil conservation program, the aim of which was to halt and repair the land degradation which, unfortunately, the previous Government left to the States to do. It is a national problem and we have to think nationally. It is no good thinking in terms of what the States can or should do. It is a national responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —They claim to represent the farmers.
—Yes, the Opposition claims to represent the farmers. Unfortunately, it does not do anything towards soil conservation. I hope that by the end of this debate it will be more nationally minded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has provided $15m for land rehabilitation since it was elected in 1983. It has removed taxation incentives for land clearing, and that is important. Taxation incentives used to be given to encourage farmers to clear the land. But that is not the way to preserve the soil. The Government has created the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council to address the broad issues of the basin. As I said before, legislation which relates to this area is being introduced into the House of Representatives today. The Government has also established national reafforestation programs for which it will be providing initially $15m over three years. Over all, the Government has a philosophy of conservation, and of preserving the land, the forests and the waterways. In light of this motion and in light of the debate today, the Government can be very proud of its achievements since coming to office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I want to make concerns Australia's most valuable resource, the soil. There is probably no one in this chamber who understands better this aspect than I do. For the last 20 years I was in charge of one of the top three wheat growing organisations in Western Australia, a position I valued very much because it has been in the family for at least 60 years. I hope it will be in the family for another 100 years. The Australian Democrats have brought on this matter of urgency as though soil conservation is something new. Part of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for Australians to adopt a new land use ethic based on care and respect . . .

Later in my speech I will tell the Senate what is going on in Western Australia to bring the land that has been degraded back to its original condition. Senator Jenkins told us about the problems in Western Australia. It is a pity that she did not remain in the Senate to hear my comments about what is going on in Western Australia. It is ironic that the Democrats have brought on this motion because most of them have stuck to the cities. This is the case in Western Australia, anyhow. The only time they have ever gone into the south-west of that State was to stand in front of bulldozers in the forest country. I spent quite a bit of time in the 1950s developing our properties with bulldozers. When I see the Democrats come along with such a motion, I am very sorry-and I say this tongue in cheek-that my bulldozer driving days are over.

Do the Democrats discount programs that are already in place? Do they want everything that is in place thrown out of the window to make room for their new-found scheme? I know that there are problems with the soil in Western Australia that stem from the indiscriminate clearing of some land that was not suitable for agriculture. The post-War one million acre a year clearing program in the 1950s has helped to feed starving people in many countries and has contributed to the standard of living that we enjoy today. Having cleared the land and having realised that our soil was degraded, programs to improve the soil have been put into action. Capital works have been put in place to repair the past damage. Of the 72 proposed soil conservation districts, more than half are operational. Advisory committees have been established. W. I. Salt has showed Australia how to control water run-offs. These committees are working in conjunction with the Western Australian Department of Agriculture and the Department of Conservation and Land Management which encourage and co-ordinate landholders to adopt proven farm practices which have already reversed the degradation process.

The first modern district advisory committee was appointed in 1983 under a land and soil conservation Act introduced by a conservative government in Western Australia in 1945 and amended by a Western Australian Liberal government. I am not going to start a slanging match with Senator Cooney who was scoring points in respect of what the Government has and has not done. It is a pity that he did not remain in the chamber to hear what other speakers have to say.

The major emphasis in Western Australia has been on the control of new clearing. A total ban was introduced on clearing for about 12 months. After 12 months, clearing can be done only by submitting plans, by having an inspection carried out and then, by gaining permission with attached conditions.

Levy banks have been constructed to control water run-off. As I have already said, an extensive system of levy banks has been in existence for many years. Farmers have also been assiduous in their use of ploughing equipment and the time at which they plough. Not too many years ago farmers were advised to use the direct drill method. The use of that method almost caused some farmers to go out of business because of the resultant downturn in production. So now farmers assiduously use modern day chemicals that do not build up in the soil. By that means soil degradation that may otherwise have resulted from ploughing has been kept under control. I do not agree one iota with the comments of Senator Jenkins about the use of heavy machines. The heavier the machine, the wider the cutting implement, and as a result the machine travels over the ground less often. The Wellington Weir area in the south-west land division is facing salinity problems. Those problems are being overcome by the work carried out by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture under the present State Government and past governments.

With the upsurge in gold mining in the past few years, mining activity has probably been the biggest cause of land degradation. At one time a person wishing to work a mine did not have to submit plans as such mines came under the old system of control. A miner with an ongoing lease-some of the leases were granted back in the 1890s and thereafter-had his lease renewed. In the areas in which the new laws applied, miners had to submit an application to renew their leases. My experience in local government tells me that we cannot now expect those miners to submit plans and work to them. When I was in local government we were able to make the miners do what we wanted because if they did not we could be unco-operative when they wanted roads extended and that sort of thing. I am happy to report that the mines that come under the control of the old system are now working well.

Anyone who wants to establish a new mine must first submit plans, and he must work to those plans under supervision, otherwise he will lose his lease. We have the backing of the Western Australian Government and its soil conservation authority in taking that action. I am happy to report that that system is working well as it has resulted in such problems as blowing dust being overcome. Probably the biggest bugbear of the modern day prospector over the past four or five years has been the advent of prospecting with a D9. The old-time prospectors simply used to sample the top of the soil. Now a big D9 is used and drilling occurs. Under the new system that activity is being controlled.

Much has been said about Alcoa's alumina exploration in the south-west of the State. However, Alcoa has probably led Australia in the area of revegetation. In fact, about three or four years ago it put in charge of that program Dr Barry Carbon, a top scientist with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). As well as establishing Alcoa's revegetation program, he established a program under which Alcoa sells trees to the rest of the State. In fact, that company probably gives away a heap of trees. Those trees have been planted and are doing very well. Incidentally, in case honourable senators do not consider Dr Barry Carbon to be a top authority in this field, the Western Australian Labor Government has appointed him head of its environmental authority.

The Australian Democrats said that a tree planting program is operating successfully in each State. Alcoa is leading a group of companies and academic research groups in developing a tree propagation program which could attract $40m a year in export markets. They are in the process of developing a fast growing tree to put on the export market. Six thousand of these trees have already been distributed in Western Australia. This joint venture comprising the CSIRO, Murdoch University and Alcoa is co-operating with departments of soil conservation in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. I have here the full details of the current soil conservation program. New programs are being initiated all over Western Australia. I do not know whether Senator Jenkins has crossed the Darling Ranges, but that task should not be embarked upon by the faint-hearted. The documentation shows that programs are being undertaken from Derby in the north-west of the State to Esperance and Hopetoun in the south-west.

On those farms that have been overcleared, the farmers are allowing strips of natural bush to grow and act as windbreaks in order to halt soil degradation by wind. That process has been very successful. I have tried it on my own property, and it certainly works. Whether honourable senators believe it or not, land will regenerate. Anyone who wishes to argue that point should examine the strip of land on which the old narrow gauge line ran between Perth and Kalgoorlie. The last train ran on that line in 1968 or 1970. Today it would not be possible to tell that there had been a railway line there except for some of the old tracks and sleepers that have been left there. That shows that if we want an area of land to regenerate, it will do so.

Agricultural activity can be maintained with the assiduous use of chemicals and proper ploughing. In the short time that I have been a member of this chamber, I have heard the Australian Democrats say that farmers should use no chemicals. Certain chemicals have been approved by departments of agriculture throughout Australia, and no doubt they are monitoring their use.
