SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be tempting to say, in the light of many other motions of this nature, that opposing this motion would be like opposing motherhood, but there is a clear philosophical difference between the views of honourable senators on this side of the chamber and the views of honourable senators on the other side on this matter. The key point of the motion is a plea to the Commonwealth Government to look after the soil of this country. I will touch on that later. Like other speakers before me, I am very pleased that this motion has been brought on. The record of this Government since it was elected in 1983 is impressive by any measure and in stark contrast to the record of our predecessors which was a record of no involvement whatsoever in this area. Theirs was a deliberate policy. Our predecessors' view of the constitutional arrangements of this country was that the Commonwealth had absolutely no responsibility in this area and the States were left to play the role.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate highlights what I believe is the middle course that should be adopted by any sensible government running this country, that is, a recognition in this day and age that Australia is a nation and that, while respecting the constitutional position of the States, there are clear areas of national interest which override parochial State interests. Soil conservation is one of the classic areas where State parochial control is likely to achieve a much worse result for the nation as a whole because of local, community, political and, in particular, financial pressures by developers on State governments. To some extent these pressures can be overriden by Commonwealth governments which can take a broader view of the matter.

The problem is certainly serious. In one year half a tonne of soil for every human being on this earth is lost forever. Senator Panizza invited someone to take issue with the fact, according to him, that soil can regenerate. Soil can regenerate in the same way that oil can be replaced-over hundreds of millions of years. The kind of regeneration Senator Panizza is talking about is not regeneration at all. It is the restoration of degraded land which simply removes a moonscape eyesore. Soil does not regenerate. It is like brain tissue, unfortunately. It does not have the capacity to regenerate. All one can do is to convert gravel pits into parking lots, as they have done in Kakadu National Park, for example, or into water storage areas or swimming dams. One can grade them over and grass them, but it is nonsense even to suggest that one can replace soil which has been taken away from the surface and washed out to sea. It cannot be done, except, as I have said, over hundreds of millions of years.

As I have said, every year half a tonne of soil is lost forever for every person upon this earth. This year alone, wind and water will remove 20 billion tonnes of soil from fertile land worldwide. Twenty-five hectares will be degraded through flooding, salinity or structural degradation worldwide. For Senator Panizza's information, each centimetre lost from farming soil in this country-I have the same farming background as Senator Panizza and Senator Walsh-reduces crop yields by up to 20 per cent. Losing just one millimetre of soil over a one-hectare area means losing 10 tonnes of topsoil. That soil does not regenerate, except over a very long period, as I have said. All one can do is try to make it look better.

In the part of the country I come from actions have been carried out in the past by developers that are nothing short of criminal. Tipperary is a classic example. I was involved in that. I was working for the Soil Conservation Service of the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry. It is a bit hard when one is tootling along with a D6 bulldozer trying to put up levee banks and also following half a dozen D9s with a chain in between them, fell clearing 12,000 acres of land a year, going straight across the country, over watercourses, rivers-the whole lot. Tipperary was an environmental disaster. Twelve thousand acres of land were cleared in the first year of sorghum production at Tipperary. This occurred in the Top End of the Northern Territory. The soil erosion that occurred in the first wet season was enough to break one's heart. All we have been able to do since then has been to try to repair the damage. But I am afraid that in my lifetime and in the lifetime of Senator Panizza we will not be able to regenerate that soil. It is a real problem.

The challenge is to find land use systems, if it is at all possible, that are more economic than the present systems and that do not lead to the same degradation. In many areas of Australia-Senator Panizza will acknowledge this-that is very difficult, if not impossible. In the Northern Territory one of our most serious erosion problems is the overgrazing of pastoral land, particularly in drought times. Most of the land, certainly from where I sit, is not able to be used for any other economic purpose. The only thing one can do is to shut it down, which has happened in some areas, and not use it.

One of the problems in this area, as I said before, is that the States are constitutionally responsible, in the main, for land use. It is a constitutional responsibility they jealously guard. In terms of the leadership given by the Federal Government, the response we have had from the States has been very heartening. It is not due simply to the fact that we happen to have four State Labor governments. The response from the conservative States has been just as encouraging because of the leadership and the injections of substantial sums of Federal money into the operations of the national soil conservation program. Some $15m has been expended under that program in co-operation with the States since it was established in 1983. It was established in an absolute vacuum. It was the deliberate, calculated and stated policy of the previous administration that soil conservation was not a role for the Federal Government to play and was entirely the constitutional responsibility of the States. Considerable money has been spent in this area. Something like $60m is currently spent by the States and the Federal Government because of the leadership role this Federal Government has adopted.

Just as is the case with cigarette smoking, the community, because of the attention that has now been paid to this problem, is becoming more and more aware that the problem exists and is becoming more and more sensitive to it. One needs only to pick up a handful of rural publications-I subscribe to a great many of them-or listen to rural news broadcasts. In almost every publication in the rural media one will find articles, letters from farmers, people on the land and scientists about the problems of land degradation and the necessity for people to give some cognisance to it. That is a very recent nationwide phenomenon. There has been a dramatic increase in community concern about this matter.

In the Northern Territory we suffer from an extremely harsh and unforgiving climate. I mentioned an outstanding example of the criminal degradation of land-Tipperary. In the Northern Territory we have a small cropping industry and a very large pastoral industry. We suffer from the Australian syndrome of floods and droughts. We also tend to suffer from the very serious problem of overgrazing. As a result of overgrazing we get a complete decline in vegetation, particularly around stock watering points. Over the last couple of years, greatly improved management, due to scientific input into the siting of stock watering points and stocking rates, has resulted in a very welcome lessening of land degradation in the Northern Territory due to overstocking and drought.

A study conducted by the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry in 1980 showed that, under previous stock management, an overgrazed and hence non-vegetated area yielded 1.9 tonnes per hectare of suspended sediments over 11 storm events, whereas a vegetated catchment yielded 9 kilos of soil per hectare in suspended sediments over the same number of storms. They are fairly dramatic and convincing figures. It is pretty hard to regenerate that extent of soil loss which occurred through just 11 storms. Of course, everyone knows the extent of rainfall-60 inches per annum-in the Top End of the Northern Territory. An unpublished report prepared by the Northern Territory Conservation Commission indicated that 50 per cent of all crop lands in the Northern Territory experienced soil loss in excess of 5 tonnes per hectare per year-non-recoverable-with losses as high as 102 tonnes per hectare per year in small areas where the problem was particularly bad.

As I said before, the Federal Government responded to this national problem in 1983 by establishing the national soil conservation program. In respect of addressing the very wording of the motion we are debating, it would be useful to point out what the aims of that program are. I quote from the aims as laid out by the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee that administers that program:
that all lands in Australia be used within their capability:
that land use decisions be based on a whole catchment/regional land management planning concepts;
that all lands users and levels of government meet their respective responsibilities in achieving soil conservation;
that effective co-operation and co-ordination occur between all sectors of the community, disciplines and agencies involved in the use and management of land and water resources;
I stress the final aim, which is:
that the whole community adopt a land conservation ethic.

Indeed that is what this motion calls upon the Commonwealth Government to do. I just point out to the people who have moved the motion-I am sure they are aware of it-that this Government has been doing precisely that from the very first day it was elected, in stark contrast to the complete lack of any initiative at all on the part of our predecessors who have, of course, participated in this debate this afternoon. In a relatively short period of time-indeed, it is only 1987-there has in fact been, because of that injection of considerable sums of Federal money and the attention given to that problem, reciprocal--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only peanuts compared to the money that has been spent on other things that aren't anywhere near as important.

—I would say that the honourable senator's credentials for even participating in this debate, in terms of the Party to which he belongs, are very thin indeed. As I said before, the record of the honourable senator's Party is disgraceful. The reason it is disgraceful, of course, is that under the seven years of Fraser government there was an enunciated policy of federalism. This policy held that land use was the sole responsibility of the States. I would like to get some arguments on this point because it would be difficult to find an area more jealously guarded by the States than that of land use. I would point out that the example I have just given of Tipperary occurred before there was self-government in the Northern Territory and before soil conservation legislation, which provided for orders that could stop that kind of development, was even in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that the Northern Territory Government's record of imposing stop orders has in fact been fairly satisfactory, because orders such as that have been imposed over the years to prevent that kind of foolish development. But the record of this Government is that it established that soil conservation program when first elected; continuing commitments were given to that program during the last election campaign; and continuing funding can be found for it in the current Budget. As I have said, $15m has been provided since 1983. This Government has removed taxation incentives for land clearing. It has broadened taxation provisions to give a 100 per cent write-off for expenditure on land degradation in the year of expenditure. It has created the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council to address the broad issues of the Murray-Darling basin problems. It has established the National Drought Consultative Committee for comprehensively reviewing drought policy, recognising that much land degradation, as I have said before, takes place during droughts.

I do not think that any honourable senator should oppose this motion. But I would just like to point out that, as I said before, if the senators of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia join with us in supporting this motion, I will be particularly pleased, because that will indicate a significant and welcome shift in policy from the previous attitude of both those parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the incorrect grammar of this urgency motion moved by the Australian Democrats, its central point certainly warrants the strong support of this chamber. That central point refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the need for the Government to give the highest priority to efforts aimed at conserving one of Australia's most valuable resources, the soil.

I welcome the belated interest of the Democrats in the issue of soil conservation. However, one may question a peripheral point of this motion which demands a new land use ethic. The Democrats, in this attitude, and also in their belated interest, are paralleling the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF). In speaking for the Democrats earlier today Senator Jenkins claimed that every tonne of wheat which is exported from Australia exports soil fertility. Her venom with regard to the issue of soil conservation should have been directed at the Government, not at hapless farmers. By good farming practice, soil fertility is regenerated. It is not exported, as Senator Jenkins would have us believe.

The fact is that most modern day farmers are environmentally responsible. If they are not the soil becomes further degraded and farm profitability will collapse. That is why good farmers are good environmentalists. Dr Charlie Carter, the head of the University of New South Wales Fowlers Gap Arid Zone Research Station, confirms this. Present day land management can still be improved, but this is not the main problem with regard to soil conservation. The real damage was done by past generations which were ignorant of the fragility of Australian soil compared with European soils and did not know how to deal with it. Not enough is being done currently to restore land which has suffered erosion caused in the past by grazing too large flocks over big areas with only a few main waterholes. Today smaller flocks graze over comparatively small paddocks with their own waterholes.

It should be understood that about 50 per cent of current problems come from feral and native animals, including rabbits, kangaroos, goats, donkeys and camels, which are flourishing in arid zones under present land management that provides permanent waterholes. Farmers have a vested interested in conserving the land and perpetual leases give them more incentive to do so than fixed term leases. Most farmers regard their land as a heritage and want to pass it on in a better condition to their children.

This is confirmed by a farm poll undertaken by the National Farmer magazine in 1985. This poll set out to find what forms of degradation landholders thought were most apparent on their land and also land of their district. It also set out to find what soil damage was costing farmers, what farmers were doing about the problem and what obstacles existed at that time. Water erosion turned out to be the main form of degradation in the eastern parts of Australia, while wind damage was more significant further west. Tree decline topped the list in the temperate south. Farmers who noted degradation in their districts also generally acknowledged its presence on their own property. More than three-quarters of the farmers who noted water erosion in their districts also acknowledged it on their own land. For wind erosion and tree decline comparative proportions were around two-thirds. Of farmers who acknowledge water erosion on their properties, 53 per cent said they were suffering production losses of less than $5 per hectare as a result. But around 20 per cent put the figure at between $5 and $20 a hectare, and a small but significant 4 per cent said that production was being slashed by more than $100 per hectare. A surprisingly high 31 per cent said that they were willing to spend between $5 and $20 per hectare to fight water erosion and 11 per cent said that they would be willing to spend between $20 and $50 per hectare.

So some farmers, contrary to what some might have us believe, are indeed willing to spend even more than they reckon they are losing to repair the soil. Half of the farmers suffering the effects of wind erosion estimated their production losses at less than $5 per hectare, with around 20 per cent putting it at between $5 and $20 a hectare. Of those affected, again, 29 per cent said they would spend up to $5 a hectare to prevent the soil blowing, and 21 per cent said they would spend between $5 and $20 a hectare. So let that also lay to rest the notion that some would have us believe that there exists on the part of farmers a lack of concern with regard to soil erosion.

However, there were stumbling blocks to farmers being able to tackle this problem. The main stumbling block was a lack of finance. Farmers who had acknowledged water erosion on their properties, provided a typical sample. Twenty one per cent said that the available control measures were too costly; 30 per cent said there was inadequate finance available; and 13 per cent said they were not in a position to borrow money to do the work. More than 60 per cent overall signified financial constraints as the main problem in their being able to devote attention to soil conservation.

In the midst of the current rural crisis it is understandable that many farmers are unable to find money to plough back into soil reclamation. However, farmers in my own State of South Australia are co-operating in the restoration and conservation of the land. They are voluntarily undertaking repair work and transforming former wasteland into a productive asset. South Australian farmers have embraced the Greening Australia concept better than those in any other State. Indeed, Greening Australia has commended South Australian rural people for providing more co-operation than any other group in any other State. This is further evidence of the success of modern South Australian farmers in soil conservation. That is acknowledged by their expertise in dry land farming. South Australian farmers are exporting their soil technology and dry land farming techniques to the Middle East and, more recently, to China.

As I said earlier, the belated interest of the Democrats to this most important issue of soil conservation is very much welcomed, and it is very much distinct from their earlier interests in more trendy conservation issues akin to the approach of the Australian Conservation Foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously haven't read our policy. We had it in 10 years ago.

—We have not heard much about it, Senator Macklin. The Australian Conservation Foundation was also conspicuous by its absence during the long haul to get soil conservation on the national agenda. Only when high profile national campaigns seemed about to begin, and some money began to flow, did the ACF start to show more than a nominal interest. The ACF recorded its priorities and long term goals for the next 20 years in its annual report for 1983-84, when its former Director, Geoff Mosley, officially stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Undoubtedly the main issue to attract the Foundation's attention-
was-
. . . peace and disarmament and the related topic of opposition to uranium mining and export.
That sounds a bit like the Democrats to me. In a test of our credulity, Mosley further claimed:
Any solution-
to soil erosion-
will require a global anti-nuclear movement . . .

Needless to say practical soil conservationists argue that there are more direct ways of tackling soil erosion in Australia than by first building a global anti-nuclear movement. The Australian Conservation Foundation's dishonest approach to the issue of soil conservation reached its peak when it mounted a campaign based on the removal of the mountain cattlemen's so-called dirty horses, cattle and dogs from the high plains in Victoria and their replacement with alpine National Park Service walking tracks. This issue is too serious to be a plaything of left wing propagandists. The two greatest environmental crises facing Australia today are soil degradation and water resources. Yet we find these issues barely mentioned in the media and barely mentioned by the most vociferous and media conscious of our environmental lobby groups. So these issues remain unknown to most Australians. They have, as I said, a low priority on the militant environmentalists' list of issues. That is well exemplified by to the leadership of the Australian Conservation Foundation.

Australia is the world's driest inhabited continent. Figures vary as to the cost of soil degradation and salinity in lost agricultural production each year. Earlier studies suggest that this loss was about $600m per annum, but the most recent long term study, by the Soil Conservation Service of New South Wales, suggests an annual loss of production of $2 billion, and that is the equivalent of our annual wheat exports. Of the five million square kilometres of Australia, which are used for agricultural and pastoral purposes, it has been estimated that about 1.2 million square kilometres require remedial measures. The costs of this vital activity could well be in excess of $2,500m, but the Government appears to have done little to address this issue.

A few specific examples indicate the costs in my own State of South Australia of land degradation. Victoria's salinity costs South Australia between $5m and $10m a year. The costs of lost production of butterfat and lucerne in the lower Murray are about $4m a year. Indeed the total cost to South Australia of salinity is $40m per annum. This highlights the special problems caused to soils in South Australia by the inadequate management of the Murray-Darling basin. The Murray-Darling Basin Commission is decades overdue, but it must prove itself effective when in operation. In large measure the salinity problem of the Murray River is caused in its upper reaches. By the time the water reaches the South Australian border, it is little more than a cesspool as a result of unrestricted and unsupervised use in the river's upper reaches. Of course this is exacerbated by some leaching effects in South Australia, due to the absence of trees, which allows surface water to mix with subterranean water, making it all salty and causing that leaching effect.

This is but one example reinforcing the need for a national tree planting program. Across Australia as a whole 81.6 per cent of arid zone grazing land requires soil conservation treatment, and in the non-arid zone, 13 per cent of grazing land, 31.5 per cent of extensive cropping land and 15 per cent of intensive cropping land requires treatment. It is to the great credit of the Fraser Government that it recognised this problem and commenced remedial action. But the sad fact is that the present Labor Government has not built on the national strategy for soil conservation established by the Fraser Government. It has preferred to devote attention and financial resources to trendy boutique environmental issues, to win electoral support from small vocal groups, rather than devote attention and adequate resources to the important national issue of soil conservation. There is plenty of evidence of the low priority that the Australian Labor Party gives to soil conservation. In the current Budget the Government has allocated a meagre $6m to the national soil conservation program, and further only $814,000 to the national tree program. This compares with the $200m it allocated to Tasmania to halt the building of the proposed Franklin Dam, the proposed $50m in compensation for World Heritage listing of the Queensland rainforests, $8m this year for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and $17m for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Of course, all of these are important areas of conservation, but they do not match the significance of soil conservation as a national issue. The $6m allocated to soil conservation this year matches only the funding of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, that blatant and frivolous waste of taxpayer's money identified earlier this year by the coalition Waste Watch Committee. This Office is supposed to monitor the Alligator Rivers Region as to the effects of uranium mining, but it has become a bureaucracy engorging taxpayers' funds, maintaining expensive offices in Sydney, researching obscure projects beyond its charter, and providing junkets to exotic locations around the world for its staff, as well as duplicating work already done by a host of other agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, you had called the next paper, which would be the resolutions of the 126th special meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. I wish to address my remarks to that paper on the assumption that you will subsequently call the 127th meeting paper to which I will also address some remarks.
—The two papers are being taken together by leave.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think it is a shame that a representative of the National Party of Australia should have taken the action which now restricts comments on two particularly important papers to half the time that might otherwise have been available. It is a matter for positive comment that the Australian Agricultural Council held an urgent meeting at the time of the chemical residue crisis. I note from the report that the residue levels for DDT, dieldrin and cryomazine had been found to be above both United States and Australian tolerance levels. I also note from the report that the Council agreed to accelerate and to co-ordinate the implementation of a national ban on the sale and remaining uses of DDT. Lest I again be accused this afternoon of being a Johnny-come-lately on this matter, I make it clear that as far as DDT, dieldrin and a number of other chemicals are concerned, the Australian Democrats have for many years been calling for Australia to step in line with other enlightened countries and to institute these bans.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council also agreed to establish an extension task force to develop and to implement as quickly as possible a program aimed at the proper usage of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Of course this is an advance but the Australian Democrats believe that this issue needs to be taken further. If extension services can provide that service, we believe that they must provide information on alternatives within agriculture. The record shows that today's new chemical becomes tomorrow's problem all too often, but certainly not in every case. While we may want to eliminate some chemicals for particular reasons at a particular time, I and the Australian Democrats have no confidence that the total banning of chemicals is the answer.

We believe that governments have been lax in seeking out information on alternatives, and there is a wealth of information overseas. The Australian Democrats have put to the responsible Minister that what Australia needs is an integrated pest management unit. Such a unit would be based on a sound understanding of the crop, its pests and their natural enemies, competitors in the environment and alternative hosts and includes biological control and balanced crop rotations. In the United States such a unit was established within the office of pesticides programs. In a number of European countries there are publicly funded organic biological farming activities which have trained field officers assisting farmers as well as a number of research farms, institutes and universities which are devoted to organic and biological agriculture.

The Australian Democrats believe that the establishment of such a unit ought to be a priority issue and would include the following in its tasks. It would gather together information already existing in Australia and overseas on alternative methods of pest and disease control. Following the establishment of such a database appropriate information and alternatives would be prepared and distributed to farmers via the State departments of agriculture and other farming bodies upon which they rely so much for their information on how to improve their productivity. In co-operation with State departments of agriculture and farming bodies, a unit such as this should initiate and encourage practical measures for farmers who are using, or wish to use, alternative measures-for example, sponsoring field days on properties where alternatives are used economically and effectively.

Apart from the environmental and health problems associated with chemical abuse and overuse, the costs and increasing resistance of insects to chemicals are an additional burden facing farmers and one which we believe government has a responsibility to alleviate through giving advice on a range of alternatives. It is this sort of suggestion that we have put to the Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also speak on the Australian Agricultural Council resolutions of the 126th and 127th meetings. In the limited time available to me I would like to speak on two issues of a minor nature. Page 45 of the report of the 127th meeting states that an organisation is being set up under ministerial direction and will comprise key industry people involved in the production, packaging and export of horticultural products, plus appropriate government representatives. The Council would provide a forum to represent the interests of the State councils, industries and governments in the development of horticultural export growth. I am not speaking about the Horticultural Growers Council but a body called the Australian Horticultural Export Council. The resolution says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian Horticultural Export Council would be complementary to the proposed Australian Horticultural Research and Development Corporation, the Horticultural Marketing Corporation and the Horticultural Policy Council.

It sounds to me as if it is all very much the same thing. I wish that this could be sorted before we go further down the track of providing three more bodies as proposed. I have not heard about this matter previously. I do not know whether other honourable senators are aware of it, but I draw attention to this matter before a whole group of parallel bodies is formed.

In regard to resolution 57 one finds that as at the date of the meeting on the question of plant variety rights-an issue that is vital to Australia's progress if we are to build up a better export market and get into better products-the appointment of the PVR Registrar was to be `finalised shortly'. One also sees that the `appointments to the PVR Advisory Committee were also expected to be made soon'. That was on 14 August this year when the legislation was passed on 25 February-that is six months. In the last half hour I have been trying to ascertain whether anything happened in the next two months, but at this stage I have not been able to confirm that what was to happen `soon' or `shortly' has yet taken place.

I wish to comment on the two big issues in those meetings, the subject of milk and that of chemical residues. The matter relating to milk is extremely serious because milk is a product of every State and a reasonable amount of goodwill and common sense is essential if we are to make a transition from the traditional method of milk management and milk marketing to what will come about. It does not help at all to have an odd individual here or there racing off and trying to produce a revolution. We will not achieve the best results in that way.

In regard to the subject of chemical residues, having read of the actions that have been taken and the program that has been set, I believe that everybody in Australia can be satisfied that an excellent program was laid down and was carried out intelligently. I trust that we will be able to induce as much urgency as possible and can see how to lift the barriers between Australia and other countries-and most of all that we get on with a system involving simplicity of testing. Clearly the present testing program cannot be continued in view of the cost, the time involved, the question of remoteness, and the storage of carcasses in the meantime, which are all problems that must be overcome. I trust that this body is working on these issues.

Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Hawke Labor Government was elected in 1983 with a firm commitment to the availability of adequate and affordable housing for all Australians.

In 1984 we introduced the New Housing Assistance Bill which honoured our commitment to revamp public housing policy and assistance in Australia. This was an important piece of social legislation. Affordable and secure housing is essential for the well-being of all Australians.

The 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, authorised by the Housing Assistance Act, was negotiated by Federal and State governments in 1983-84 to operate for 10 years from 1 July 1984. It included a number of initiatives, one of which was that the agreement be evaluated triennially.

At the Housing Ministers Conference in April 1986 Federal and State housing Ministers agreed to a timetable and a procedure for the first triennial evaluation of the agreement. At that meeting Ministers agreed that a steering committee of Commonwealth and State officials would be established to oversee the evaluation in accordance with the agreed terms of reference.

The terms of reference stated that the first triennial evaluation would examine the effectiveness and efficiency of rental and home purchase assistance programs, against the principles set out in the agreement. Ministers also agreed that non-government organisations be invited to provide submissions on the operation of the agreement.

The triennial evaluation concluded that public housing programs under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement are generally efficient, effective and well targeted. The evaluation also concluded that the objectives and principles introduced in the 1984 agreement remain valid, but that in particular areas of the provision of home purchase and rental assistance, minor amendments could further improve effectiveness and efficiency.

Two changes are to be made to the Housing Assistance Act through this Bill. The first is to provide for the continuation of the Government's commitment to provide a guarantee of a high level of base funding for the next triennium. Funding to the States and the Northern Territory for housing will be guaranteed at a base level of $700m for 1988-89 and 1989-90. This is $200m more than the record base funding provided in the first triennium and 3 1/2 times the base level provided for in the previous Government's 1981 agreement. The current year's funding is to be made available through Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1987-88.
The financial impact of this Bill is therefore a cost to the Commonwealth of $700m in 1988-89 and 1989-90.
As part of the $700m guaranteed for 1988-89 and 1989-90 the local government and community housing program will receive $11m and the crisis accommodation program will receive $14m.

The Government will also allow all States to nominate up to 100 per cent of the loan component of their State government borrowing program for public housing in 1987-88. These funds are available at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent repayable over 53 years.
This funding, which is provided in a year of very considerable Budget restraint, reflects the high priority accorded by the Federal Government to the alleviation of housing related poverty.

The second change to the Housing Assistance Act arising out of the evaluation of the agreement relates to section 11 of that Act, which deals with the Minister's authority to reallocate specific housing assistance grants from one State to another. This section is to be amended to allow the Federal Minister responsible for administering the agreement to redirect funds to other States or for the funds to be retained by the Commonwealth. This could occur in the event of a State failing to comply with the provisions of the agreement relating to specific purpose programs or the guidelines for those programs. This change is being introduced to ensure that States adhere to the agreed procedures for consultation in respect of Aboriginal housing and other special purpose programs and that in these programs, which are fully funded by the Federal Government, Federal priorities are implemented.

Following the outcome of the triennial evaluation, amendments were also made to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and I propose to outline briefly these changes for the information of honourable senators. I seek to table the amended agreement. The amendments in this agreement have been negotiated and agreed with the State and Northern Territory Housing Ministers.
The agreement has been tightened up in the area of State matching contributions to ensure that States meet their financial responsibilities for public housing.

The agreement will also be amended to ensure that all State matching contributions for home purchase assistance, and Loan Council nominated funds used for home purchase assistance, will be channelled through the home purchase assistance account. This will ensure that all funds provided to the States under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and Loan Council arrangements continue to be used for the purposes of the agreement.

The agreement will permit surpluses generated from home purchase assistance operations to be used for general rental assistance. It will also specify that not less than 50 per cent of total funds are to be directed to public rental assistance in recognition of the need to increase the supply of affordable rental housing.

The approved use of funds will also be widened. This amendment will permit funds provided under the agreement to be used for more innovative purposes such as joint ventures, secondary mortgage market trusts and rental housing trusts. This move will encourage States to enter into innovative financial arrangements and attract private sector finance into public housing provision.

Home purchase assistance provisions will also be amended to require that reviews of income of recipients be conducted annually or at intervals agreed to by the Minister. This will ensure that subsidies are not provided to those who are not in need and will maximise the amount of funds available for further loans. If income is not reviewed annually then loan repayments are to be adjusted annually in accordance with the consumer price index or other agreed index.

The sales policy for public rental housing will be refined to ensure that rental stock is not depleted and that sales will cover the costs of providing replacement dwellings. This policy will provide that public rental housing constructed or purchased within the previous five years cannot be sold to an individual purchaser at less than replacement cost.
This Government will also ensure that young single people are not excluded by a particular State from access to public housing.

These changes to public housing arrangements will ensure that the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement remains effective in assisting many thousands of Australian households each year to obtain adequate housing at a price they can afford.

In addition to our public housing efforts this Government has made significant achievement in other areas of housing assistance. The first home owners scheme has been widely heralded as the most effective scheme ever to assist home buyers obtain their first home. The eligibility limits were increased in March this year, with extra assistance going to families. Since its inception, this scheme has helped over 255,000 first home buyers into their own home. It continues to be the most effective home purchase assistance program ever introduced by a Federal Government.

This Government has not ignored the private rental market. The recent decision on negative gearing will flow through into increased rental supply and put a brake on rent increases. We will also provide direct assistance through the new family allowance package. Low income families renting privately who are receiving the family allowance supplement, parents on unemployment benefit, and pensioners will now receive up to $15 a week rent assistance.
It is the first time that any Federal Government has provided rent assistance to working families on low incomes. This is a significant breakthrough.

This Government's sound economic policies will continue to place downward pressure on home loan interest rates. The Budget has been followed by an immediate drop in housing loan interest rates. Rates have now come down by a full percentage point over the last three months.

Another initiative co-ordinated by the Federal Government was that from 1 July 1987 the funding arrangements for public housing in the Australian Capital Territory would be aligned with the States and the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.
This decision is welcomed because it will ensure consistency and equity of treatment between residents in the ACT and those living elsewhere in Australia.
The Government recognises that the massive housing problems facing low income earners cannot be overcome in one or two years.

This is why the agreement is placed in a 10-year framework. We have entered into a long term commitment to those in housing need. The improvements made to the arrangements following the first evaluation will enhance significantly the effectiveness of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement over the remaining seven years.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Migration Act 1958. As the Act is already nearly 30 years old, obviously it has already been amended a number of times over the years, which is necessary with legislation of this age in order to bring its provisions up to date and to correct anomalies as they arise with the passage of time. This amendment Bill is relatively small. I shall deal with its clauses in order. Clauses 3, 4 and 5 are aimed at correcting an anomaly identified in a recent Federal Court decision which casts doubts on the requirement that the prescribed fee be paid at the time the application is lodged. These clauses are sensible and mean that officers no longer have to decide whether a letter be the formal application or not, and all applications have to be lodged on the correct form with the correct fee.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 of the Bill provides an increase in penalty for a master, owner, agent, charterer or operator of a vessel who brings a person to Australia without documentation, that is, without a visa or return endorsement. Clause 7 of the Bill is explained in the explanatory memorandum as follows:

This clause inserts a new section . . . which provides that passengers . . . seeking to enter Australia are liable to pay a prescribed fee to assist in recovering the costs of immigration clearance . . . and that a passenger's fee is to be collected . . . by the international air operator who brought the passenger to Australia.

The clause poses a number of problems. First and foremost, this is a form of taxation, although it is described as a fee. Secondly, it is a tax that is set by regulation; in other words, it is recommended that the tax should be $5 at the moment, but it could be changed by regulation without an upper limit.

The third problem is the method of collection of the tax-that is, by the air operators. I should like to quote what the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had to say about clause 7 when it looked at this Bill:

Clause 7 . . . may be regarded as a `Henry VIII' clause to the extent that it would permit the amount of a prescribed fee, which would require passengers on international flights seeking to enter Australia after 1 January 1988 to pay a fee for the services relating to their immigration. Arrangements for the collection of the fee, and its amount, will be prescribed by regulation.

Whilst the proposed amount of the fee ($5) may be regarded as no more than recovery of costs, the committee in the past consistently objected to imposition of fees, which may be regarded as a form of taxation, by regulation without a limit set by legislation. The Committee has argued that the Parliament should not lightly delegate its taxing powers. The Committee has taken the view that a ceiling amount on such a fee should be prescribed in legislation.

The Committee accordingly draws the attention of senators to clause 7 of the Bill in that by enabling the setting of a fee by regulation without an upper limit, the Bill may be considered to be an inappropriate delegation of legislation power.

This is a tax which came into the Budget when, in fact, we had been assured that the Government would not put any further taxes in this Budget. I will quote from the speech of Mrs Sullivan in the House of Representatives, which appears on page 1623 of the Hansard for 28 October 1987. Mrs Sullivan stated:
The Treasurer, on 28 May, said:
On the receipt side let me confirm that there will be no tax increases in the 1987-88 Budget.
On 29 May the Treasurer said:
The Government has made it quite plain that it does not intend to introduces new taxes or increase new taxes in the Budget.
On 23 June, when launching the ALP campaign policy, the Prime Minister said:
In the completed Budget in September there will be no new taxes and no tax increases.
The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech on 15 September, said:
Turning to the revenue side, I repeat that we have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes or introduce new taxes.

There is no doubt about it. This so-called $5 fee is, in fact, a tax. The Democrats cannot support this clause in the Migration Amendment Bill. We cannot support the introduction of a fee which is, in reality, a tax which can be set by regulation. The regulations are not available yet. This is why we fully support Senator Short's motion that the committee stage of this Bill should not be discussed until the regulations are to hand.

There is also the problem of the collection of this $5 fee. When discussing this Migration Amendment Bill in the other place, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, was quoted by an Opposition member as having said `A lot of our experience in the immigration field is trial and error'. I would suggest that this clause should not be tried; in fact it is already an error before it really gets off the ground. I would like to discuss the method of collecting the fee by the airlines-that is, by Qantas Airways Ltd and other international airlines which would be involved. Although this fee appears in the Migration Amendment Bill, it will be payable not only by migrants coming to Australia but also by tourists coming to Australia simply as visitors and, of course, by every single Australian who leaves the country and who wishes to return. In his second reading speech, the Minister said of this amendment:

. . . it was announced in the Budget package that passengers over 12 years of age arriving on international flights and who require immigration clearance on arrival will, from 1 January 1988, be required to pay a $5 immigration clearance fee. The fee is to be collected by international airline operators who bring the passengers to Australia. In turn, the operators will pay the fees collectable by them to the Commonwealth.
Later in the speech the Minister also stated:
Consultation with the airline operators is taking place to ensure that the legislation and mechanisms to impose the charge will impose as small an administrative burden as necessary on the airlines.

I am not exactly sure what format those consultations have taken. They certainly could not have taken place before the Budget was brought down because matters of this kind are not discussed before the Budget. But I do know that on 30 October 1987 a telex was sent to a number of Ministers and shadow Ministers, including Minister Young. This telex is from the Secretary of the Board of Airline Representatives of Australia (BARA), Lucio Cardone. Part of it reads:
Dear Minister,

We would like to bring to your attention the strong views expressed by the airlines at our first meeting with your Department on 15th September 1987 concerning the imposition of a $5.00 immigration clearance fee on all arriving adult passengers which is to be collected at the airlines' expense. The members of BARA protest in the strongest terms against the proposed introduction of an immigration clearance quote fee unquote on the following grounds . . .
The first five grounds given by this Board are that the fee would be extremely damaging to tourism. The sixth ground is:

The introduction of the proposed fee appears to contravene previously stated Government policy that there would be no new taxes in the life of this Government. It is apparent that the use of the word ``fee'' has been carefully selected to disguise what is in effect a new tax.
Finally it states:
For the foregoing reasons the BARA strongly requests that the introduction of this fee/tax is not proceeded with.

It is for this and other reasons already stated that the Democrats simply cannot support the introduction of this $5 fee or tax. I know that the Opposition will also put forward an amendment deploring the fact that this fee will be charged to returning Australians. But we feel that we must take the matter further and absolutely oppose this clause.

I really think that the airlines have a problem. I suppose they will discuss it, as a board, but how are airlines such as Qantas, British Airways, Singapore Airlines Ltd, Air New Zealand Ltd, Air India or Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd actually going to collect this fee? What will happen to passengers who stop over in places such as Singapore or Hong Kong on their way back to Australia? Where will the fee be collected? I think this is going to be a real problem in logistics and is simply not worth the $5 fee that the Government hopes to gain. Of course, the airlines have until 1 January to decide exactly how they will do it, but as I said before, I think this will pose a problem.

Clause 8 of the Bill is a minor amendment to section 57 of the original Act and deals with deportation orders. It simply eases the verification of identity of the operator of a vessel. Clause 9 of the Bill introduces a $240 fee for the review of migration decisions. Before I discuss this clause, I would like to read an extract from a speech which was delivered in May this year at the faculty of law at the Australian National University. The title of the paper is The Impact of the New Administrative on Migrants. The paper was written by Ms Mary Crock, legal officer, Ecumenical Migration Centre, Richmond, Victoria. It states:

In immigration, the bureaucratic dilemma between administrative control on the one hand, and justice to the individual on the other is more marked than in perhaps any other jurisdiction. The reasons for the dilemma lie partly in the nature of the migration process itself, which burdens the bureaucracy with the task of regulating the composition of our society. Of equal importance is the persisting belief that migrants are people who are privileged to be in Australia. `Privileged' precludes the notion of `rights'. The old philosophy of governmental supremacy is firmly enshrined in the Migration Act 1958. The Act confers on the Minister and his Department virtually unfettered power to determine who is to enter or remain in the country. Until very recently this left little room for the assertion of individual rights. However, attitudes change with time . . . In a free and democratic society, a system cannot be efficiently controlled if it is perceived to be unjust. Particularly is this so when the system deeply affects the lives of those subject to control.

When this amendment Bill was discussed in the other place Government speakers explained that the whole point of imposing a fee of $240 for the review of the migration decisions was to deter more people from appealing. Senator Short referred to the problem of the tremendous backlog that has been caused by the number of appeals. In June 1986, 3,688 applications were waiting to be considered. By June 1987, just one year later, 10,886 applications had not been finalised. In other words, that number of people were waiting for a review of their applications. Since 16 September, the day after the Budget was brought down, a $240 fee has been imposed on all applications for review on the basis that this Bill and this clause will pass through both Houses of Parliament. Obviously, the backlog of applications is a great problem. It is also a human problem in that 10,866 people are waiting to know whether or not they can migrate to or stay in Australia. In many cases those people are already here. They are waiting to know whether their status can be changed so that they can remain in Australia.

The Government has increased the number of people on the review panels from 32 to 157. It has also increased the number of staff who service those panels and I commend the Government for that. As I understand the position, applications for permanent residency must be reviewed under the provisions that existed when the applications were made.

There has been quite a lot of controversy over the membership of the panels. I asked to see a list of the new members of the panels and I thank the staff in Minister Young's office who made this list available to me. I am pleased to see that the quality of the people has improved insofar as they appear to be more suitably qualified to look at the applications. They are people who understand, or who are more likely to understand, what is involved in the migration process. They have some understanding of administration and fully understand the likely legal aspects. In addition, with the increased number of members, the review panels are now able to sit in all the mainland States. That no doubt will speed up the process.

The $240 fee will be payable only by people who apply after 15 September. As Government members stated in the debate, the fee has been imposed so that not so many people will apply to have their applications reviewed and so, presumably, the backlog will not increase dramatically as it has over the past year. I put it to the Government that this is not a logical way to tackle that problem. People have to have 70 points in order to be approved for migration. Many people who appeal against decisions have a very low number of points, but they are still eligible to appeal. Of course, people who are close to the 70 points also appeal. Although the $240 fee may deter some people with a low number of points from appealing, it is more likely to deter people who simply cannot afford the fee. In many cases we are looking at people who already have spent a great deal of money on their applications because, as everybody knows, various fees are payable at all stages of application for migration. This fee is a very discriminatory fee. It is the sort of fee that kicks people when they are down.

Although I have praised the Government for increasing the number and quality of people on the panels, these panels in themselves are not really a satisfactory form of review. I draw the Government's attention to two reports: one is the 1985-86 annual report of the Administrative Review Council which came out in 1986; the second report is the Administrative Review Council's Review of Migration Decisions, report No. 25, which came out in 1986. The immigration review panels are criticised quite severely in the Council's second report, which states:

Immigration Review Panels are non-statutory bodies which have the function of reviewing on the merits of certain classes of migration decisions made at departmental level and of making recommendations to the Minister as to the final determinations . . .
I will refer briefly to some of the criticisms listed in the report. Paragraph 71 on page 25 states:
Representatives of the ethnic communities who provided information and comment to the Council expressed the following views concerning the operation of the IRP system . . .

The system is criticised for being an internal review. The report criticised the inappropriate membership, which I have dealt with. It criticised the fact that the panels met only in Sydney, Melbourne and later Canberra. It also criticised the lengthy delays, which we hope will now be corrected, and the fact that the review panels exercise a recommendatory power only. The report stated:

The Department has not abided by its undertaking to provide training sessions for ethnic community representatives to enable them to fulfil the role that it intended for them in respect of counselling and assisting applicants;
The quality of the Department's statement of reasons is poor;

The IRPs have not disseminated information to ethnic community representatives about the basis for their recommendations and those representatives consequently have no knowledge of the considerations which the panel regards as important in determining particular categories of cases . . .
It also states:
Clearly, from the viewpoint of ethnic community representatives, the IRP system is not satisfactory.

The Government is asking potential migrants, potential Australian citizens, to pay $240 for a system that is, in fact, not satisfactory. I suggest that the Government would be well advised to try to upgrade that system rather than start charging people for something that is not satisfactory. It would be better not to permit people who obviously have no chance of getting anywhere close to the 70 points to have their cases reviewed and to let those who are reasonably close to the 70 points to have their cases reviewed without the $240 fee.

The Government has compared these review panels with various tribunals, but they cannot be compared with, for example, social services and veterans review systems. Those systems have properly constituted tribunals and, I might add, they do not impose a fee. There has been a lot of pressure from ethnic community groups for parity with the first level review in other jurisdictions, such as social security and veterans' affairs. In fact, they have recommended the introduction of this two-tier structure under which simpler cases can be determined by a panel or under an adjudicator system and other cases looked at by a properly constituted tribunal.

As has already been mentioned, it appears from a report in yesterday's Australian that the Government is advocating a very different method of screening potential migrants. This process really has a delicacy which perhaps the Government has not fully appreciated. Yesterday Senator Reynolds said that the Government would be making its announcement tomorrow, and we all certainly look forward to it. However, this is a strange time to make such an announcement, when the Fitzgerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies is expected to bring down the results of its inquiry at the end of March. As has been stated in advertisements about the inquiry, this inquiry on immigration is being carried out because it is essential that in our immigration policies we should be able to select in Australia's best interests from among the huge numbers who apply. It is not appropriate to have this double system. It could be transferred to the private sector and kept quite apart from other systems.

The Government must remember that in dealing with immigration it is dealing with real people and their lives. It is not always the business person who makes the most successful migrant. We must exercise great caution in this respect. Potential migrants who apply to come to Australia may be uncertain about settling in a new country. Such persons may wish to come here for economic or political reasons. Once they are here they must make the best of it and must put their fullest stake and be committed to their new country. Such persons can be quite different from those who want to come here simply because a lot of money can be made here. In fact, today's newspapers have brought to the fore that it is well known that some people who come here as business migrants do not plough their earnings back into Australia but send them back to their country of origin where they may be put to a number of uses. I ask the Government to be very careful in pursuing this particular path.

I emphasise that the Australian Democrats cannot support clause 9 (a) of the Bill. We cannot support the imposition of a $240 fee which is to be paid for a service in an unsatisfactory system. The details of how this fee will be applied will be the subject of regulations that are not yet available. The Australian Democrats await those regulations with eagerness. We are pleased that this Bill will not go to the committee stage until the regulations are available.

I shall now sum up the problems that will be encountered with the imposition of this $240 fee. The appellants will have no right to appear before an immigration review panel and no right to be heard. In fact, most of the applications must be submitted in writing, and this will pose great problems to people who are not very fluent in English. They will have to rely on other people to fill in the forms for them. It may be that they will have to rely on interpreters and translators to help them fill in the forms. In other words, they will not be able to speak up for themselves, and that is contrary to the basic principles on which our legal system is based. If they are in an overseas country it will not be possible for them to lodge an application. In some cases those who are sponsoring them here in Australia could do that for them. But certainly if they are here in Australia there should be no reason why they should not be able to speak up for themselves.

Members of the immigration review panels are appointed by the Minister and they operate under guidelines laid down by the Minister. Their function is an advisory one. The Minister need pay no attention to their recommendations. There is an enormous backlog of applications. The review panels are very poorly regarded by the ethnic communities and social workers and other professionals who work in the migration area. So, essentially, this provision fails to address any of the underlying problems and it seeks to impose a substantial fee in respect of what is widely regarded as an unsatisfactory product. For those reasons, the Australian Democrats will oppose clauses 7 and 9 (a) of the Migration Amendment Bill.
