PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reynolds) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish in this adjournment debate to pay tribute to the trade union movement and its members, a group of people who are of tremendous importance in this community and who have displayed a keen sense of humanity and caring for others in that community. I wish also to acknowledge their more enlightened approach to the role they play in our contemporary society. Those matters of themselves would be sufficient to require me to take part in this adjournment debate, but there is the added matter of the continued union bashing of Senator Chaney and Senator Michael Baume, to mention only two. I should not forget Senator Stone, who also seems to delight in that pursuit. Those people know very little about the trade union movement, but they seem to think that that makes them experts.

SPEECH.PARA: The person who really takes the cake is one Vince Lester, the Queensland Minister for Employment, Small Business and Industrial Affairs. Mr Lester was recently reported as describing as a scandal the reduction in job classification in the metal industry and said that it would lead to centralisation of union power in Melbourne and Sydney. He is reported further as saying:
The State Government will oppose this totally, and all thinking and responsible Queensland unionists, who don't want to see their rights vanish, should do the same . . .
He is reported further to have said:
There are 326 unions in Australia-
obviously someone told him that-
including 69 Queensland, representing more than three million workers.
How can one or two much larger bodies ever hope to give their members the same levels of service that the smaller, more personal groups can?

If I send him a copy of this speech, he will know the answer to that question. His knowledge of these matters is hopeless. I have in front of me a document headed `Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement'. Page 12 of that document deals with the restructuring of the trade union movement and the bringing into being of a number of large industrial unions. It is proposed that the number of unions be 17. The trade union movement and the highest body that looks after the interests of trade unionists say that there should be 17 unions, by Mr Lester is telling everybody that there will be two or three. That only confirms in my mind the opinion that he speaks from ignorance again and again.

Let us compare the union bashing engaged in by honourable senators opposite with the current Government position as expressed by Ralph Willis in a speech he delivered to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). He said:
What we have learned is that the labour movement, through the co-operation of the trade union movement with a Labor Government, can be an extremely constructive force for national advancement.
He was not concerned simply about the direction of the trade union movement but about national advancement. He went on to deal with the Government's attitude to union amalgamation. He said:

The Government position is that it is determined to implement a substantial package of industrial law reform in the first session of Parliament next year. That legislation will differ from the industrial relations Bill at least in certain important respects. In recent discussion with the parties, for instance, it has become clear that there is a willingness on all sides to support more extensive change to the amalgamation provisions than those proposed in the Bill.

So Minister Willis sees amalgamation as being a good thing, provided it delivers the sort of outcome which the trade union movement says it will and which most reasonable people in the community believe it will. That attitude is in strong contrast to the Opposition's attitude and the attitude of Mr Lester from Queensland.

Let us consider the campaign by the trade union movement to convince people in the Government and in the community of the need to look outwards at other countries as to how their trade unions operate. That is a constructive approach. We should not view it in a questioning way, maintaining that, because in the past trade unionists might have been unreasonable in their approach to matters on which they took industrial action, perhaps disadvantaging people in the community, they are terrible villains for all time and that we should question and resist anything they say. Rather we should consider what this approach means for the whole community. The document entitled Australia Reconstructed states:
Under Strategic Unionism, trade unions recognise that wealth creation is as important as its distribution, and view the two issues as inseparable.

The trade unions are not saying that they have to get it all, that they do not care how the economy operates. They are saying that they believe that there should be wealth creation and that they should be part of that. They want to make sure that they get a reasonable share for their members who, after all, make up 55 per cent of the work force of this country. They also service many others who pay nothing to the trade union movement but who receive many benefits as a result of its activity. The document goes on to talk about and quote the labour organisation in Sweden. It states:

The reason we need democracy in working life. The right to be able to influence conditions for one's own life and work is self-evident. It does not need any justification other than that of human dignity . . . Employers have usually tended to meet workers demands for power with the argument of effectiveness. Nowadays it should be clear to all that more power for workers is likely to be a means of increasing effectiveness and productivity rather than otherwise . . . This freedom of action should be used, not for creating Stock Exchange big shots, but for growth and employment.

The document then goes on to talk about the way the trade union movement structure operates in Europe and should operate in Australia. It puts the lie to the claim that bureaucrats and unthinking, mindless people make up the leadership of various trade unions. The document states:

The structure of the trade union movements in the countries visited by the Mission has influenced the policies they have pursued. Austria, West Germany, Norway and Sweden are characterised by a set of common features:
central co-ordination;
strong local union and workplace organisation and vitality (this is particularly the case in Norway and Sweden);
predominantly industry-based unions; and
a small number of larger unions.
The document goes on:

The success of the trade unions in the consensus countries is due as much to central co-ordination as it is to strong local union and to workplace organisation. The two are not contradictory. Notwithstanding highly centralised bargaining and involvement in tripartite policy formulations, Scandinavian unions are strongly organised at the local level. The point was emphatically made in the report on the LO organisation in Sweden which was discussed at the 1981 Congress. It has been translated as follows:

If one were to accept the idea that the union movement is merely an institution for defending its members' rights according to laws, agreements and guarantees won by a small group of central officials, then it is working well at the present time. But this is a view that the movement itself has never accepted . . . Unionism is and must be a movement that seeks to change working life from the bottom up, which takes up arms against commercialism and passivity, which sets out to democratise society and the economy and make work itself valuable and meaningful. This mission can never be accomplished by a little group of well-trained activists and functionaries by themselves. (Higgins 1985, p.349).

These words put an absolute lie to the claim about bureaucracy and the trade union movement and the lack of opportunity for people in the trade union movement at the rank and file level to make a contribution. A lot has been said about the question of amalgamation. Amalgamation is a very important aspect of the development of the trade union movement to service and look after the interests of its members and also to make a contribution to society. Some comments were made about the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. Unlike Senator Stone and Senator Chaney, I speak from experience as for many years I was an official of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. Let us, for the record, have a look at the way it works. It has a membership of 166,000. It has a Federal Council and Federal conferences. New South Wales has 59,500 members; Victoria, 47,500; Queensland, 22,000; Western Australia, 17,000; South Australia, 11,500; and Tasmania, 4,500.

At the Federal conferences of the union, where decisions are made, there are 24 members from New South Wales, 19 from Victoria, 12 from Queensland, 8 from Western Australia, 7 from South Australia and 3 from Tasmania. The union has a very specific rule that the majority of people in the policy-making body have to be rank and file members who come from the job to the conference. The union has a State structure which is fairly similar. It is a totally and thoroughly democratic organisation.

If any honourable senator wanted to suggest that it was not, I am sure that the Metal Workers Union would be only too pleased to compare its democratic process and structure with that of the Senate. Both start from the same basis: the electorate decides who the officials will be. In the case of the Senate there is compulsory voting; with the trade unions it is voluntary. The union does not accept, however, that once elected the officials are able to go away and make their own policies and be bureaucratic, like us in the Senate. That is a right given to us by the Constitution and the law of this country. Almost every day certain policy matters in different areas and at different levels come up and have to be decided by the rank and file of the union. They have the capacity to prevent absolutely their officials from going in a certain direction. That capacity is available to them every day of every week of every month. We do not have that capacity in the Senate. We can go to the polls and make all sorts of promises as parties and as individuals, but we can then turn our backs on those policies and promises and remain in office for the duration of our time. It is true that we have to come up for examination and judgment at the end of that time but nobody has the legal authority to change our situation. We are bound by the Constitution and certain legal decisions through the common law over the years. But the trade union movement is much more democratic, much more exposed and much more conscious of what its constituents do and have to say.

Let us examine what results from this terrible concept of bringing unions together in large bodies. Mr Lester says that we could not handle it, that we would have head offices in Sydney and in Melbourne and that it would be bureaucratic and horrific for the members. Let us take, for instance, a typical union of a constructive and progressive nature, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. It has a provision, for instance, for 4 per cent of its total budget to go into education. It has full time education officers in each State. These people do not educate and train people how to organise strikes. Many of them are quite ingenious in the way they do that; they have their own native ability to do those sorts of things, but they generally get put in that position by someone else seeking to disadvantage their members. They are trained in how to work within the system-how to understand what the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides, what their rights are, what the rights of particular employers are and how to negotiate from a position of some equality. They are told that the employer has to listen to them and their argument and make a decision as to whether he is prepared to agree to their proposals either partly or totally, and they are told that that should be done without any disruption.

Indeed, many unions negotiate propositions that do not go to the question of dispute solving but to the question of dispute prevention-before it even happens. But it is a bit difficult when we have a position of the employer having a right to sack somebody out of hand while employees are supposed not to go on strike. Many of the proposals we put up suggest that the employer, even though he may have a legitimate right to dismiss somebody-because nobody is perfect and everyone has to answer to certain standards of behaviour-might consult the trade unions and indicate to them what he is about to do and the reasons for it. In many cases that has been done by enlightened employers and there has been no dispute.

The trade union movement also gets involved in all sorts of specialist committees-committees within its organisation, government committees, tripartite committees-all directed in a constructive way in the area of training in particular callings. More recently they have come up with some very interesting and very constructive proposals which look at getting rid of the archaic attitude that holds that somebody who is trained as a motor mechanic or fitter should remain in that job for the rest of his life. They have looked at questions of career paths so that people can have broad training and can move into other areas of skills which will be important and useful in the community. They have done that in many cases in advance of any of the employer organisations. But I must say that there is a general attitude of co-operation as far as that is concerned.

This does not show an attitude of `We don't care; we want our piece of the cake and we don't care what happens as long as we get it'. That is not the the position; it does not happen. The trade union movement in recent years-I refer again to Australia Reconstructed-has set out in some detail a whole number of approaches to improve the efficiency of industry in this country and the benefits that will flow to it and to the whole community as a result. One thing that trade unions are not going to do, and I suggest neither should they be expected to do, is to change different work methods and give guarantees of no disputations over a period, regardless of what may occur as a result of bad management practices or maybe something that is done off the cuff by an employer to create a situation that should never occur. The fact is that trade unions can contribute heavily to improving efficiency in changing the whole approach of the work place and then find, because management is backward and comprised of dunces, that everything they have done has been in vain.

The trade union movement is saying: `We will do our bit. We co-operate with the Labor Government, which is an enlightened bunch of people who understand the contribution we have to make and want us to make it, but who in turn will make agreements with us and see that those contributions are translated into benefits for the trade union movement membership and for the community in general. We will not give ourselves up on the altar of expediency and maximisation of profit. We want job security and a share in the wealth created'. Many people in this chamber and outside in the community, including the employers, realise that and can grasp hold of it and make use of it. If they do not, it will be against the interests of the community, and I think the community should understand that. People should be judged on whether they understand that and whether they are sincere enough to care about the future of this country or not. I leave that judgment to the people of this community who will read my speech in great numbers and be most interested in the detail that is included.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Burns for his very informed and very passionate defence of trade unionism and the constructive role trade unions are playing in their relationships with government in attending to economic problems. I am sure, as he said, many people in the community will read his speech with great interest and benefit from it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
